brilliant piece. Thank you. Most of these young people tend to find employment in high-risk industries . Most workplace accidents happen within the first twelve months of employment; poor communications and human factors i.e., loss of attention, play a role in a significantly high number of all workplace accidents and there are particularly vulnerable groups. Despite numerous intervention and prevention strategies, these ILO statistics were forecast to increase before the pandemic. I can&#8217;t imagine what the new forecast will look like. We know that very significant numbers of people, especially vulnerable groups, with very low levels of literacy and learning ability and no previous occupational Safety and Health (OSH) literacy education, are entering into dangerous and exploitative employment and training environments. There needs to be much more awareness of this issue and collaboration between stakeholders to embed osh into education-to-employment ecosystems or the numbers of workplace deaths, diseases injuries and losses will skyrocket. Organisations such as ENETOSH.net are doing great work in this area.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2022\\/10\\/27\\/children-with-learning-differences-are-being-excluded\\/#comment-51159","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8ac3e7c1edd3d41c049dc0d15b2c0240?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8ac3e7c1edd3d41c049dc0d15b2c0240?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8ac3e7c1edd3d41c049dc0d15b2c0240?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8ac3e7c1edd3d41c049dc0d15b2c0240?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/51159"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/30945"}]}},{"id":51158,"post":30936,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Mohammad **********World Education Blog - Page:2**********

b'[{"id":51152,"post":30766,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Dr. Tusiime Ramadhan","author_url":"","date":"2022-10-17T17:23:26","date_gmt":"2022-10-17T15:23:26","content":{"rendered":"<p>Culture can hinder Girl education<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2022\\/10\\/11\\/the-education-of-tens-of-millions-of-girls-is-at-risk-of-collapse\\/#comment-51152","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8714cd188651b907b3c6984b7eebce90?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8714cd188651b907b3c6984b7eebce90?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8714cd188651b907b3c6984b7eebce90?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8714cd188651b907b3c6984b7eebce90?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/51152"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/30766"}]}},{"id":51149,"post":30854,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"John C Clegg","author_url":"","date":"2022-10-14T12:13:01","date_gmt":"2022-10-14T10:13:01","content":{"rendered":"<p>You will be aware, I&#8217;m sure, that apart from the major reasons which you mention which prevent children from learning to read and getting an education, learning in an additional language is one of the major barriers. It is vital that learners learn to read in a familiar language and spend at least the first six years of schooling learning in that language. After that it is important that if it is necessary for them to change to a less familiar language of learning, this transfer is managed  carefully in a multilingual classroom. These are fundamental principles of language in education, especially in the global south. If they are not practised, no effort to minimise the effects of poverty or to reduce dropout or improve out-of-school education will have any great success.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2022\\/10\\/14\\/every-child-deserves-to-be-able-to-read-a-simple-text-by-age-ten\\/#comment-51149","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/51149"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/30854"}]}},{"id":51146,"post":30766,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Colin Power","author_url":"","date":"2022-10-13T05:00:05","date_gmt":"2022-10-13T03:00:05","content":{"rendered":"<p>Our hearts go out to the women and girls of Afghanistan. In the early 1990s as ADG\\/Ed I confronted the Taliban insisting that under inter national<br \\/>\\nLaw (Convention on Discrimination in Education) they must allow women to teach and girls to go to school.  They refused &#8211; and we refused to acknowledge their regime.  However we did find ways via radio to support women teaching at home, while continuing to pressure the regime to respect the rights of girls and women<br \\/>\\n(see pages 22-23,  235 and 263 of my book C.Power \\u201cThe Power of Education: Education for All, Development and UNESCO\\u201d. In addition to the information on the blog, I would also like to write about the importance of the increase in air temperature in the education system of Uzbekistan.  In the process of secondary special education, it is good to give students a 3-month summer vacation during the hottest time of the year.  but for younger children in early September and May (especially long-distance students), daytime weather is uncomfortable.  As mentioned in the blog, control exams given in the fresh air during the day when it is not hot have a negative effect on the performance of students, this is confirmed.  but we have not only control questions, but also university entrance exams are held at the hottest time &#8211; in August.  I would like to recommend involving people from all walks of life in solving problems like temperature and air pollution around the world through small eco-activities.  Fresh air-fresh knowledge<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2022\\/06\\/20\\/temperatures-and-air-pollution-affect-learning\\/#comment-51143","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/09534cd3cd21410526d6d62ec0edcc04?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/09534cd3cd21410526d6d62ec0edcc04?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/09534cd3cd21410526d6d62ec0edcc04?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/09534cd3cd21410526d6d62ec0edcc04?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/51143"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/30046"}]}},{"id":51139,"post":30640,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Kirsten Pontalti","author_url":"","date":"2022-10-07T00:22:49","date_gmt":"2022-10-06T22:22:49","content":{"rendered":"<p>I would love to believe these estimates, but for the reasons mentioned in the blog, we need to be very cautious about accepting them as evidence of what happened. I was a researcher\\/author for a study on the impact of COVID-19 on child protection and education inequalities in three humanitarian contexts. The qualitative data collected suggests that school closures have had a significant, negative impact on out-of-school rates. Granted, this data was from humanitarian contexts, which could reasonably be expected to be worse, but we reviewed global secondary literature that largely supported this finding. <\\/p>\\n<p>I have The actions comprising \\u201cRAPID\\u201d are surely as relevant to early childhood care and education as they are to the focus of this article &#8212; primary and secondary education.  Thus, Reach every young child and keep them in early childhood care and education programmes; Assess development (cognitive, physical, language, social-emotional) and learning levels regularly and early; Prioritize teaching the foundations of the fundamentals (early literacy and numeracy); Increase the efficiency of pre-primary instruction; and Develop psychosocial health and wellbeing from birth (health and nutrition, social-emotional development, protection, responsive caregiving). b'[{"id":51056,"post":29732,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"PedagoG","author_url":"https:\\/\\/happychildren.life\\/amp\\/","date":"2022-06-18T00:24:01","date_gmt":"2022-06-17T22:24:01","content":{"rendered":"<p>Any king of learning should be courage! Home schooling is excellent for kids of smart and responsible parents, but not so excellent for other kids. By the way, I like this research!<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2022\\/05\\/12\\/should-we-encourage-home-schooling\\/#comment-51056","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/7c43bf3a689d6e46040ffb04a775370f?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/7c43bf3a689d6e46040ffb04a775370f?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/7c43bf3a689d6e46040ffb04a775370f?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/7c43bf3a689d6e46040ffb04a775370f?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/51056"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/29732"}]}},{"id":51055,"post":29432,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"lynn oliver","author_url":"https:\\/\\/mayfieldga.wixsite.com\\/lynnoliver","date":"2022-06-17T04:15:07","date_gmt":"2022-06-17T02:15:07","content":{"rendered":"<p>The belief boys should be strong allows more aggressive treatment as early as one year of age, designed to create more layers of anger, fear, and tension, so they will be prepared to fight, defend, and be tough.  This is coupled with \\u201cmuch less\\u201d kind, stable, (very little kind verbal interaction) and much less mental\\/emotional support, knowledge, and skills for fear of coddling. It is this more aggressive, less supportive treatment, which creates the toughness or extra maintained layers of average stress: anger, fear, preparation for defense, anxiety, etc.  These layers remain in the mind and take away real mental energy from academics, so those boys will have to work two or three times as hard to receive the same mental reward for mental work expended.<br \\/>\\nThis aggressive, less supportive treatment along with less verbal interaction creates more social\\/emotional distance\\/distrust of others \\u2013 parents, teachers, peers, and others in society. It creates much less social vocabulary, knowledge of syntax and other communication we as girls are given on a continual basis from infancy.  I feel this much less interaction also deprives boys, later men of many more areas of knowledge and skills girls are given through much more continual interaction and support\\/communication from everyone.  Worse, this more aggressive and less supportive treatment leads to even more, sustained weights and values of more distance and even less social development over time while girls, later women who are given much kind, caring, verbal interaction\\/support continue are able to develop and use more and more social vocabulary and much more knowledge over time.  From this treatment, I feel boys effectively understand about a third of the communication they have with parents, teachers, and other adults.  The higher average stress creates more activity for stress relief (not genetics environmentally created).<br \\/>\\nThe total effect including less care and support creates much more failure and a feeling of hopelessness, especially with our false genetic models firmly in place.  Also to make it even tougher for boys is the granting of love and honor (feelings of self-worth) only on condition of achievement, status, or image.  This was designed to keep Male esteem and feelings of self-worth low to keep them striving and be willing to give their lives in war for small measures of love and honor from society.  Males not achieving in school or other areas are given more ridicule and discipline to make them try harder.  Support is not given boys for fear of coddling and the false genetic models.  Many boys (as you would expect) thus falling behind in school then turn their attention to sports and video games to gleam small measures of love and honor not received in the classroom.  The belief boys should be strong and the false belief in genetics creates a blatant mental denial of the differential treatment, which is creating the lower academics, low esteem, and other problems many boys are facing today.  So strong is the belief boys should be strong there is an almost emotional cannibalism allowed upon boys and men who appear weak in some way by society: parents, teachers, others, even from many girls and women, especially in the media.<br \\/>\\n\\tNote, this is not about showing feelings or openness from boys and men, it is about support, care, and respect for boys even when appearing weak in some way.  Remember aggressive treatment is increased for any sign of weakness and so boys have much wariness for parents and teachers who feel it necessary and are more freely allowed to use more aggressiveness for any sign of weakness or vulnerability.  This is condoned by many in society today.<br \\/>\\n\\tAs for reading, we need high social vocabulary, much social\\/verbal interaction experience with sentence structure and \\u201clower average stress\\u201d to perform and enjoy the abstract skills of reading: decoding, visualizing, organizing, reaching into their social vocabulary\\/knowledge of words to learn new words in print, and enjoy the process. Boys are deprived in these areas due to much less care, verbal interaction, and much more aggressive treatment.  As for writing, we also need much social vocabulary to understand, plan, and to put words into print.  We also need lower average stress to create more ease of writing. The higher average stress creates significant higher muscle tension, which then creates a much tighter grip and more pressure on their pen or pencil.  This creates poor handwriting and early fatigue.  This kills off their motivation to write, hence more two and three word sentences from boys with and less motivation.<br \\/>\\n\\tI feel the shows of masculinity and misbehavior are pretty much cop outs to both show separation from failure and also to generate small measures of love and honor from their peers.  Their defensiveness from authority is really pretty straight forward, especially in lower socioeconomic areas where strength, power, and status hold very real currency in those areas. For those students it is not just misbehavior but a real tug of war or fight for minimum feelings of self-worth from a continual fight they feel outside the classroom as well as in.<br \\/>\\n\\tThe suicide epidemic for boys and men is the result of Males being deprived sufficiently from essential feelings of self-worth and so being denied love and honor from others.  The more aggressive, less supportive treatment boys are given from an early age is creating much more failure and hopelessness in school, preventing many boys, later men from competing in the information age thus losing the means to secure legally, income, status, and power to earn love and honor from society.  This then creates many more instances of more aggressive, less respectful treatment, which slowly wears down their feelings of self-worth or desire to live right on to the point of suicide.  I feel long before this point is reached, many many more boys and men are already escaping in various harmful ways from video games and sports to drug\\/alcohol abuse in an attempt to live despite the low feelings of self-worth they are feeling.<br \\/>\\n\\tThere is a wrinkle to this. There are a &#8220;very few boys&#8221; given more stable, correct support from a few families which is enabling those few boys to succeed in school.  This enables those boys to do well in school and receive love and honor from others, which they must continually keep doing to keep earning love and honor from society.  This then becomes a never-ending drug for those boys which drives them to continually achieve in school.  Those very few boys will be driven to continually achieve both in school and society with much more success due to the drug of achievement to earn love and honor.  However the vast majority of those boys receiving very little support and much more aggressive treatment will not do well in school. Early on, they go into other areas to generate love and honor such as escaping to sports and video games, later to the military, (far right groups), or other areas just to generate ounces of love\\/honor from others.  I feel the rapidly growing far right groups today are rooted in the hopelessness; anger; misled, inner feelings of inferiority to women; and the yes, now accumulating layers of abuse society and sadly many women are giving many boys and men today due to false feelings of superiority.<br \\/>\\n\\tSadly, indulgence pays in the information age, while less supportive, more aggressive treatment hurts development in the information age.  As girls we are treated much better and enjoy much more hope and care from society. Since we as girls are given by differential treatment, much more continual, positive \\u2013 mental, social, emotional support, verbal interaction from an early age onward, this creates quite the opposite outcome for girls when compared with the boys.  The much more verbal interaction also transfers and creates many small and large arrays of real knowledge and skills, which are \\u201cimportant for learning, communication, and working with knowledge and skills\\u201d.  I feel this is creating a significant advantage for girls and women. We enjoy much more care and support from society, from infancy through adulthood and receive love and honor simply for being girls. This creates all of the good things.  This is even so for lower socioeconomic environments, where even here, girls, later women are able to perform very well in school and society due to much better continual support from everyone.  We enjoy lower average stress for more ease of learning. We enjoy much more freedom of expression from much protection that makes us look more unstable at times. Of course we can also use that same tremendous freedom of expression to give verbal, silent abuse, and hollow kindness\\/patronization to our Male peers with impunity knowing we are protected.  We enjoy much lower muscle tension for more ease and ability in handwriting and motivation to write. We enjoy much more positive, trust\\/communication from parents, teachers, peers, and more support for perceived weaknesses. We are reaping a bonanza in the information age. The lower the socioeconomic bracket the much more amplified the differential treatment from infancy and more differentiated over time through adulthood. Now with girls and women taking over many areas of society, we are enjoying even more lavishing of love and honor from society, while the boys and men are now failing more so and are now given even more ridicule and abuse by society.  Much more on this.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2022\\/04\\/07\\/education-increasingly-becomes-a-boys-problem-at-high-cost\\/#comment-51055","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5425162d0b4d89bd8ebd72368413a53e?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5425162d0b4d89bd8ebd72368413a53e?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5425162d0b4d89bd8ebd72368413a53e?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5425162d0b4d89bd8ebd72368413a53e?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/51055"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/29432"}]}},{"id":51049,"post":30020,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"ABHIMANYU SINGH","author_url":"","date":"2022-06-02T16:26:13","date_gmt":"2022-06-02T14:26:13","content":{"rendered":"<p>Compliments on a good piece recalling the challenges of launching the GMR in 2002. This is a very wrong and narrow way of looking at the matter. Say that there are no private schools in Brazil. Would equity and inclusion be ascertained? Definitely a big NO.<\\/p>\\n<p>Equity and inclusion are but a never-ending race that needs to be adapted in whatever system exists despite whether the state allows public and private entities to exist or not.<\\/p>\\n<p>Imagine the time of the pandemic when the world was forced to teach online; serious equity and inclusion issues also arose. How many children had no access to the internet and online education facilities? How many children faced home-based violence and endured many cases of abuse from close family members that hindered their education? Would you then condemn the whole online education system because of such atrocities? Definitely a big NO.<\\/p>\\n<p>If clear national policies that ensure equity and inclusion are set up, then whatever adapted system will ensure equity and inclusion is abided to. The whole world felt the negative impact of COVID 19. The children were the most hit as more than half of the population of young children in school were forced out of school.<br \\/>\\nThe young learners in the Early Years were not &#8220;carried&#8221; along while the rest of the students resorted to wide technology as a learning support.<br \\/>\\nThe early years children found it difficult to cope with the &#8220;new&#8221; system of education due to the fact that they could not handle the rigorous content of technology without their help of their parents. The dependency of learning with technology prompted the negligence of parents leaving their work to &#8220;teach&#8221; the children. A few facts &#8211; 1) It&#8217;s not community schools OR school choice.  The first operating charter in the US, a number of outstanding charters, are community schools, sharing space with community groups.  There are also outstanding district schools of choice using the community school idea.  It doesn&#8217;t have to be one or the other.  See for example <a href=\\"http:\\/\\/centerforschoolchange.org\\/wp-content\\/uploads\\/2012\\/09\\/saneschools.pdf\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">http:\\/\\/centerforschoolchange.org\\/wp-content\\/uploads\\/2012\\/09\\/saneschools.pdf<\\/a>      2. There are various forms of school choice. There&#8217;s for example, the form of school choice that some districts use, which screen out students who can not pass a standardized test.  I think that&#8217;s bad.  There&#8217;s the form of school choice that allows affluent families to move to exclusive suburbs, where the price of admission is the ability to pay high real estate taxes.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2022\\/03\\/31\\/the-implications-of-school-choice-in-the-united-states\\/#comment-50989","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5bb0ff47f42f4f2c8f63c52d759b337e?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5bb0ff47f42f4f2c8f63c52d759b337e?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5bb0ff47f42f4f2c8f63c52d759b337e?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5bb0ff47f42f4f2c8f63c52d759b337e?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/50989"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/29261"}]}}]'

People can believe that children have a right to education while rejecting the claim that the state has the exclusive right to educate children. I am skeptical of the notion that centralized governmental authority over education will produce better outcomes for students than a network or public and private options.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2022\\/03\\/31\\/the-implications-of-school-choice-in-the-united-states\\/#comment-50971","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/959a1fe7642320222e5792d23ad92ab2?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/959a1fe7642320222e5792d23ad92ab2?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/959a1fe7642320222e5792d23ad92ab2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/959a1fe7642320222e5792d23ad92ab2?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/50971"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/29261"}]}},{"id":50970,"post":14968,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Lul Admadachew","author_url":"","date":"2022-04-02T08:20:09","date_gmt":"2022-04-02T06:20:09","content":{"rendered":"<p>Difficulty to Demarket The State and Non State Ownership Paradigm in Education: Eduaction, Myth and It&#8217;s Expansive Definition during the Digital Era<\\/p>\\n<p>Hello colleagues! Happy Anniversary to UNEVOC-UNESCO.<\\/p>\\n<p>Firstly, I must state that the style hereby is as a review for a journal article, on relevant areas. It is my first time working on a blog.<\\/p>\\n<p>Introduction<\\/p>\\n<p>Here in Ethiopia, we have a mini blackout since the WiFi outlet is turned off overnight. My mobile data is very limited too and I have not familiarised myself fully as to how to customize the optimisation of my mobile data\\/credit. Such limitations can not always define sectors since social class as a state of mind, work ethic, Organisation Behaviour can demarket various sectors. For instance, the engagement of the staff, team work directive and appraisal policy as taskforce can be down to socioeconomic group, often indicated by educational attainment and this defines social class and the class struggle thereof.<\\/p>\\n<p>This can be stating the obvious, yet, the main premise hereby is that demarkation between government, non government and private sector can be the right categorisation and, of course, there is difficulty to demarket them as clear cut entities. But organisation behaviour, change, reform and development does reshape reality in the short and long run. For instance, in tuition fee paying UK Universities, their brand can be catahorised as having charitable status. Charities can also function within such establishmemts. The state is the government so to speak and your blog post seemed to demystify the myth but the categorisation need to be these three sectors and their subsets, without sidelining individual experts. The pitfall of hybridization is that muktiagency and multistakeholder work can lack being joint-up, of equal footing nature, multicultural and multidisciplinary. Yet, goal 17 of the SDG dictates the fact that partnetship for the goals is quintessential. We do somehow need to collaborate, as knowledge transfer partners, to say the least. Strong Institutions is another goal of the SDG and coming together as one and delivering as one, as the motto of the United Nations dictate is important.<\\/p>\\n<p>Eduaction, Myth and It&#8217;s Expansive Usage during the Digital Era<\\/p>\\n<p>Beforehand, I was listening to current affairs, specifically, the briefing of the Committee on the Second Homecoming, which culminates along with the completion of the Hajji pilgrimage of year 2022, and this Ethiopian movement is labelled as &#8220;Eid to Eid&#8221;. The first round was for Christians earlier on during this year.<\\/p>\\n<p>Normally, it is unlike me to read further, for the sake of enlightenment, in Wikipidia, about some Islamic terms, yet I did anyway. More often than not, I prefer the credibility of other encyclopedias. Surprisingly, the references thereby, including various Islam Encyclopedias are rich for the &#8220;Esoteric meaning of Islam&#8221; and related links, including the two unknown letters on Kuran, which is the holy script. It is intriguing becuase the literal meaning of such words or the book, even the Koran states, are concealed. Yet, during this Eid Mubarak season known as the Ramadan Kareem fasting, many are upholding the fact that the Koran is conceived and then inked. The Pen, as the leader Mohamed the Prophet proclaimed, is the most important creation. There is a Surat, which I believe means chapter, in the daily edited Wikipidia which can wipe out a section, about The Pen. Perhaps I have failed to understand this part for esotoric ideals are mystical, to me anyway.<\\/p>\\n<p>On another level, it is head knowledge that for Christianity that this kind of &#8220;passive interest&#8221;, let alone a full blown inclination, can often be dubbed as a wrongful immersion in Myth, which is short for Mythology. But people watch Dan Brown movies and do read books on such genre anyway and the myth buster for such &#8220;myth&#8221;, some being filmed in the Vatican is usually found in the internet.<\\/p>\\n<p>Global Education Monitoring and The Myths Thereof<\\/p>\\n<p>Ironically, the Global Education Monitoring Report lists so many myths and one of them is discussed hereby. It is freedom in a way to read about myth since Occult and Esotoric ideals, whether dubbed as Myth, metaphysical or mystical,to be mocked or downplayed or even labelled as hearsay, do interest me and several others. But I do not have free time to fully explore their Historiography. As already mentioned, the references in Wikipidia are unbelievably from the high end, including Academic Press from Routeledge but be mindful that new editors may extinct such species assuming the daredevil stance.<\\/p>\\n<p>The premise of the blog is about myth so that believing that a sector is clear cut is not to be the normality and formality. That is an  enrichment to Organisation Behaviour as a discpline. Social class, I argue, definrs or demarks private and public education run as bottom up policy or parents&#8217; expert leadership within or independent of education establishments, perhaps with clusterised teams, norming their ideas whilist others ajourn to find their niche market. Classism can not be the case to be a claimed hereby since the University of Leicester in Britisn had also a slogan, or more of a promotion of the brand, which reads as &#8220;Elite without being Elitist&#8221;.<\\/p>\\n<p>After all, the SDG on Education is not about politics at British school gate by the so-called yummy mums in happy wedlocks, non streamlined dress sence, swaying hips, outspokenness leading to informality and coercion at school gates which form such pseudo teams that run sleepovers that falter to allow us to learn about their belief systems, yet, with hypocracy, they can shun Halloween school parties which have &#8220;fun and disco&#8221; as the main themes. There is more. School governance and leadership at teritary level has to erradicate such intricacies in informal networks and mainstreaming emotional intelligence as such. Some argue that intelligence quotient is irrelevant, so streamlining, formality and virtues can not be sidelined as dogma. They are pillars to emotional intelligence and independent education. More so, enterprenerial skills can be upheld for the SDG only through valuing partnership or creativity for the higher good. The avalanche of techology and service realted innovative stance needs to be monitored during the fourth industrial revolution.<\\/p>\\n<p>Leaving the monitised agglomeration aside, no one should pay for the aforementioned behaviours one way or another unless it is their innate pathway. This is not the Montisorri Way. Overall, emotional intelligence and opportunity cost of time have value. Who walks the talk? For Whoes Interest? The whole picture can be different should this be labeled as formalised organisational partnership since hierarchy, some sidelining or silencing expertise, and the competition thereof, would have been entertained as professionalism which creates another circuit for membership or service delivery payment, as privatisation, or academisation to borrow the British term. Innovation, is the mantra of this era and those who question it are the trouble makers or are obsessed with critique. So, in a world whereby the Big Pharma and Corporate Giants play their games, Education is also branding into &#8220;privatisation&#8221;, indeed, with the illusion of delivering, since repression of leadership with diversity at heart gives way to a default position assumed by some who lack knowledge in ethics, equity and emotional intelligence. This fosters Neocolonialism further afield.<\\/p>\\n<p>Again Have a Jappy Twentieth Anniversary to UNEVOC-UNESCO<\\/p>\\n<p>Cordially,<\\/p>\\n<p>Lul Admadachew<br \\/>\\n<a When even your own research wasn&#8217;t persuasive that competition doesn&#8217;t improve education, it seems rather a stretch to call it a myth.<\\/p>\\n<p>Moreover, you seemed to rely on evidence that competition doesn&#8217;t lead to improvement in non-charter public schools. Since education makes money, its the domain of teachers or educationally minded people &#8211; they start a private school even at the cost of public and soon they are driven by self-interest including unionized efforts to protect it.<br \\/>\\nd. often put argument is that it prevents money flying abroad as private schools offers quality for elites who otherwise send their children abroad &#8211; to India in Nepal&#8217;s case, Singapore in India&#8217;s case but the undoing of faith in public schools has immeasurable cost. Depending on the context &#8211; you enter into a slippery downward spiral from where it is hard to come back!<br \\/>\\ne. The cost is at another level when gap is widened and it leads to social strife. We all appear to be waiting for it. Thanks kate<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/contact\\/#comment-50942","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/bfcd11099bb6aed9d3adb3921f510759?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/bfcd11099bb6aed9d3adb3921f510759?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/bfcd11099bb6aed9d3adb3921f510759?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/bfcd11099bb6aed9d3adb3921f510759?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/50942"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/users\\/40884240"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"page","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/pages\\/3944"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/50941"}]}},{"id":50941,"post":3944,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Luis Fernando Coss","author_url":"http:\\/\\/periodismoabc.wordpress.com","date":"2022-02-15T14:05:55","date_gmt":"2022-02-15T13:05:55","content":{"rendered":"<p>Hi!!! Do you know where this graphic comes from? The one said:Hi!!! Do you know where this graphic comes from?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/contact\\/#comment-50941","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a7ce45c60ef68540f06e3fc9b9423d8c?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a7ce45c60ef68540f06e3fc9b9423d8c?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a7ce45c60ef68540f06e3fc9b9423d8c?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a7ce45c60ef68540f06e3fc9b9423d8c?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/50941"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"page","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/pages\\/3944"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=50941"}]}},{"id":50937,"post":14485,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Olukayode Emmanuel","author_url":"","date":"2022-02-07T15:32:27","date_gmt":"2022-02-07T14:32:27","content":{"rendered":"<p>Private tutoring is one of  remedial approaches to correcting a child&#8217;s learning deficiencies  which usually takes place outside the school premises. The classroom is a place where different kinds of pupils having different level of exposures, upbringing, mental acuity and intellectual capabilities converge to be taught which however justify that a classroom is made up of two categories of student; fast learner and slow learner. The importance of private tutoring cannot be undermined as a veritable tool in responding to some personal, financial and economic challenges of an individual and a nation as a whole. In a country like Nigeria where close to 90 million Nigerians live in poverty (NBS, 2020), private tutoring has served as a source of income to many unemployed youths who would rather be paid stipend as a private tutor than to steal. An average Nigerian teacher receives 20dollars (ten thousand naira only) as a salary which is too small for personal survival let alone family upkeep and of such needs additional means of income. Private tutoring also serves as a mental-leveller between fast learner and slow learner.  The mental acuity of a child differs from the other. Some could learn in a noisy classroom while some cannot. Some pupils could understand a concept just at a glance while some could take months to understand. Some could learn without any additional effort of a teacher while some could learn by extra efforts of a teacher and to such, private tutoring could be a solution. A slow learner is however subjected to private tutoring if the parents wouldn\\u2019t want to waste school fees and at the same record child\\u2019s academic progress. In addition to this, private tutoring makes a child mentally busy and academically dutiful at home. It is believed that \\u201can idle hand is the devil\\u2019s workshop\\u2019\\u2019. The prevalent socio-economic crimes in Nigeria among the youths could be traced to laxity of hands at home. Rather than being busy watching immoral movies of corrupting practices, a child could be busied with private tutoring so as to keep his\\/her mind safe and also instill studying culture in the home. Remember, charity begins at home.<br \\/>\\nThe potential implications of the new regulations of shadow education in China could be viewed from two-dimensional angle. One, it could lead to increase in illiteracy ratio as no nation can outgrow its level of education. The illiteracy level of china is close to 6% as at 2020 which if adequate measures are not put in place may increase gradually. There is no bad without a good side. A pupil who understand a concept when spent much time with may lose interest in school where there\\u2019s little or no attention for his deficiencies. Hence, private tutoring is the answer.  Two, it may lower some teachers financial capacity since it is an additional stream of income and this will definitely lead to poverty ratio increment if shadow education is stopped.<br \\/>\\nIn my own point of view, it is necessary that educational authorities regulate shadow education. Using Nigeria as an example, most private tutors are not professional\\/ licensed teachers which has made Nigerian teaching profession to be bastardized in terms of poor methods of teaching, involvement of teachers in examination malpractices and pervasive sexual abuse of pupils\\/students by private tutors. In the case of china, it is germane to regulate shadow education so that the image of its teaching profession can be preserved, respected and valued. Also, it is incumbent upon educational authorities to regulate shadow education so that teachers would put in their best in ensuring every concept in a subject is well taught and understood by pupils without any need for private tutorials. By doing this, the quality of the nation\\u2019s education would be highly, positively and jealously maintained. Lastly, as an educational expert, if shadow education is not regulated, the future of China is questionable because a little excess breeds extremism. To be remembered, there\\u2019s no good without a bad side (vice versa) if not well regulated.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2021\\/08\\/06\\/china-clamps-down-on-private-tutoring\\/#comment-50937","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a4707fd84e798690544f9d9d765116a4?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a4707fd84e798690544f9d9d765116a4?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a4707fd84e798690544f9d9d765116a4?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a4707fd84e798690544f9d9d765116a4?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/50937"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/14485"}]}},{"id":50936,"post":14943,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Sudhakaran Balakrishnan","author_url":"","date":"2022-02-07T08:03:13","date_gmt":"2022-02-07T07:03:13","content":{"rendered":"<p>The aim of education is to develop the physical, emotional and intellectual faculties of young people. So that they grow up to become responsible adults with good knowledge, skills, values and attitudes. One of the skills they must possess is the ability to continuously learn new things.<br \\/>\\nIs it the job of educators to provide skilled man power to industry? Any young person with a decent education must be accepted by industry and trained to the requirements of a particular industry.<br \\/>\\nAs E Serry states, tertiary education should step away from job skills. Almost every teacher use it as an avenue to make extra money. Although it is not completely their fault, I share the blame between the Nigerian government (with no solid education policies on ground), the parents and school leadership who see it as &#8220;ok&#8221; for children to be privately  tutored by the same or another teacher in order to &#8220;pass&#8221; their examinations. We fail to understand that the children are placed under a lot of pressure to pass their examinations. And some parents are not making it any easier for these children. These parents go as far as threatening to withdraw some privileges if these examinations are not passed gloriously because lot of money has been paid to the school and private teachers to make sure success is achieved. This clearly supports the teachers to demand for after school private tutoring even when they are in a position to teach the children as duty demands. They prefer to push their responsibilities to after school where they can get paid for doing what they should have done in the morning at school.<br \\/>\\nSecondly, the school leadership puts the teachers under situational pressure because no student should fail any internal or external examinations. No school wants to appear unsuccessful as this will tag the school as &#8220;low&#8221; achievers! Every school strives to succeed even at the expense of the children&#8217;s emotional well-being not fully cared for. All that matters to them is to brag about their trophies and medals being displayed either as objects or in human form. Some boast &#8220;Our school has high successful results in our examinations!&#8221; How pitiful!!!!<br \\/>\\nI am a teacher and a parent. I will be unfair to my daughter who just got back from school at 4pm, tired and exhausted from all the activities she had to go through at school. Who probably had a bad day with friends and teacher, only for her to come home and meet another teacher waiting for another round of school! What a life of horror?!!<br \\/>\\nI honestly think that after school private tutoring should be banned in Nigeria.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2021\\/08\\/06\\/china-clamps-down-on-private-tutoring\\/#comment-50911","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/9adfd1d568b78a94558999ed2a13b5e4?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/9adfd1d568b78a94558999ed2a13b5e4?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/9adfd1d568b78a94558999ed2a13b5e4?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/9adfd1d568b78a94558999ed2a13b5e4?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/50911"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/14485"}]}},{"id":50910,"post":14930,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Dr. fully.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2021\\/12\\/17\\/call-for-expressions-of-interest-now-open-for-the-2023-gem-report-on-technology\\/#comment-50910","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8714cd188651b907b3c6984b7eebce90?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8714cd188651b907b3c6984b7eebce90?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8714cd188651b907b3c6984b7eebce90?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8714cd188651b907b3c6984b7eebce90?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/50910"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/14930"}]}},{"id":50909,"post":14943,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"E Serry","author_url":"http:\\/\\/britishqualificationsschool.wordpress.com","date":"2021-12-23T13:57:49","date_gmt":"2021-12-23T12:57:49","content":{"rendered":"<p>No matter what we do with tertiary education the gap between industry and education will always be there. In fact the gap between the skills wanted by the employers and the skills produced by the tertiary education will get worse. This reasons for this are quite obvious:<br \\/>\\n1- Industry is more flexible than education when it comes to implementing new technology. Implementing new technology in industry saves money, including new technology in education costs money (both in using and training on).<br \\/>\\n2- The length of time need to implement a change is much faster than in education. While at best scenario both industry and education should be applying a continuous development process, in industry adopting the new ways happens in a much shorter time than the time needed to update curriculum or qualification specifications.<br \\/>\\n3- In the qualification based education (Degree, Diploma) the length of time needed to complete the qualification is too long that by the time the qualification is achieved (3\\/4 years + 1 years to find a job), a lot of what has been taught is rendered obsolete in the work place. This results in the graduate needing either retraining or at best upskilling when they start their first job after graduation.<br \\/>\\n4- Now and more in future industry is seeking creativity and individualism (technology and innovation). The 20th century move towards complete standarisation which was a result of the automation revolution is disappearing. This is due to the introduction of artificial intelligence which allows the machine to react in a creative rather than standardized way. While at the same time education as a whole seeks conformity (one specification teaching one set of skills to all students on the course using set learning outcomes). Only at the research level in education where creativity is allowed.<br \\/>\\n5- The cost of teaching a set of skills inside education institutes is much higher than the cost of teaching the same set of skills in the working environment.<br \\/>\\n6- In the majority of the times the teaching staff in the education system have minimum or no real experience in using the skills they are teaching. The only exception is the apprenticeships. For example how many management professors have run a business or how many entrepreneurship lecturers have started their own successful business!<br \\/>\\nAnd many other reasons &#8230;&#8230;&#8230;<\\/p>\\n<p>In my opinion tertiary education should step away from job skills. Life skills, personality development, research and innovation should be the core of what tertiary education works on with the learners. Apprenticeships and on the job training should be the way to move forward with teaching the job skills.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2021\\/12\\/20\\/is-tertiary-education-still-worth-it\\/#comment-50909","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/1114e78e938dcb9eabdf150dc26c0d86?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/1114e78e938dcb9eabdf150dc26c0d86?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/1114e78e938dcb9eabdf150dc26c0d86?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/1114e78e938dcb9eabdf150dc26c0d86?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/50909"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/14943"}]}},{"id":50907,"post":14885,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"David We observe that the inclusion narrative focuses heavily on physical disabilities, but millions more children are excluded in and out of mainstream schools because of learning disabilities, which are not always as obvious. <\\/p>\\n<p>Dyslexia, a learning disability affecting all the skills required for literacy, is one of the most prominent, affecting up to 20% of any population. There are children on the dyslexic spectrum in every class in Nigerian schools.  Yet, awareness is low and policy support is lacking. <\\/p>\\n<p>We would love to contribute to this important work by giving a context and voice to learning difficulties and inclusive education in Nigeria. <\\/p>\\n<p>I would be grateful for more information, a conversation and an opportunity to collaborate with you. <\\/p>\\n<p>Thank you very much for your consideration. <\\/p>\\n<p>My best Vercauteren","author_url":"","date":"2021-03-14T21:00:29","date_gmt":"2021-03-14T20:00:29","content":{"rendered":"<p>It is heartbreaking to read this article. But it is also understandable in a way, even though, in my opinion, education should always a priority to any country, there are seemingly more pressing dangers at the moment. The whole world economy took a big hit, but especially in poorer countries that difference might make the biggest impact, on the already small budget for education. On the other hand, one day the world will recover from the impacts of Covid-19 and there might be a window of opportunity to transform the education systems that are in trouble. External help from richer countries is a way to help with this, but I&#8217;m seeing a trend, like this article mentions, of investing in the own national problems first and the poorer countries might be forgotten, just like with the distribution of the vaccine. I am hopeful that eventually, the financial troubles will pass and the investment in education will grow again, but it will take a global effort to do so. A decent education for everyone will make the world a better, more prosperous place, I&#8217;m certain of it, but it will take some time to recover from the economic disaster. This in itself is quite important and could be a solution to the challenge of insufficient availability of textbooks in many contexts. Yet, improving access to learning materials does not necessary mean that those that are freely made accessible are gender-sensitive and free of stereotypes. As the copyright permissions on open textbooks (<a href=\\"https:\\/\\/en.wikipedia.org\\/wiki\\/Open_textbook\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">https:\\/\\/en.wikipedia.org\\/wiki\\/Open_textbook<\\/a>) includes the right to adapt them by revising and combining them with other materials, this could be a way to make them gender-responsive. For this to happen, those in charge of adapting these materials need to be aware of gender issues and be trained to address them.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2021\\/03\\/10\\/countries-are-still-falling-short-of-developing-textbooks-free-of-gender-stereotypes\\/#comment-49077","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/bfcd11099bb6aed9d3adb3921f510759?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/bfcd11099bb6aed9d3adb3921f510759?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/bfcd11099bb6aed9d3adb3921f510759?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/bfcd11099bb6aed9d3adb3921f510759?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/49077"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13875"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/49072"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=49077"}]}},{"id":49075,"post":13505,"parent":49063,"author":0,"author_name":"Kate Redman","author_url":"","date":"2021-03-11T09:59:46","date_gmt":"2021-03-11T08:59:46","content":{"rendered":"<p>with pleasure! Stated simply, today\\u2019s children will become tomorrow\\u2019s citizens, workers, and parents. When we invest wisely in children and families, the next generation will pay that back through a lifetime of productivity and responsible citizenship. When we fail to provide children with what they need to build a strong foundation for healthy and productive lives, we put our future prosperity and security at risk \\u2026<\\/p>\\n<p>\\u201cAll aspects of adult human capital, from work force skills to cooperative and lawful behavior, build on capacities that are developed during childhood, beginning at birth \\u2026 The basic principles of neuroscience and the process of human skill formation indicate that early intervention for the most vulnerable children will generate the greatest payback.\\u201d<\\/p>\\n<p>While I appreciate the study\\u2019s initiative, it\\u2019s still for me a disappointing revelation as to our collective humanity when the report\\u2019s author feels compelled to repeatedly refer to living, breathing and often enough suffering human beings as a well-returning &#8216;investment&#8217; and &#8216;human capital&#8217; in an attempt to convince money-minded society that it\\u2019s in our own best fiscal interest to fund early-life programs that result in lowered incidence of unhealthy, dysfunctional child development.<\\/p>\\n<p>Their wellbeing should be more than enough to convince us all!<\\/p>\\n<p>Meanwhile, general society perceives and treats human reproductive &#8220;rights&#8221; as though we\\u2019ll somehow, in blind anticipation, be innately inclined to sufficiently understand and appropriately nurture our children\\u2019s naturally developing minds and needs.<\\/p>\\n<p>As a moral and ethical rule, a psychologically sound as well as a physically healthy future must be all children\\u2019s foremost right\\u2014especially considering the very troubled world into which they never asked to enter.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2021\\/03\\/02\\/allmeansall-a-call-to-action-from-40-million-european-youth-to-mark-zero-discrimination-day\\/#comment-48684","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/2dc2e9f2b34def00c8658f24d64f4f62?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/2dc2e9f2b34def00c8658f24d64f4f62?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/2dc2e9f2b34def00c8658f24d64f4f62?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/2dc2e9f2b34def00c8658f24d64f4f62?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/48684"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13854"}]}},{"id":48674,"post":13726,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Anirbaan Hritiq","author_url":"http:\\/\\/www.twitter.com\\/listenmanzil","date":"2021-02-27T03:47:07","date_gmt":"2021-02-27T02:47:07","content":{"rendered":"<p>Everyone in this world can provide others with food &amp; 2007 study (\\u201cThe Science of Early Childhood Development\\u201d) found and reported that:<br \\/>\\n\\u201cThe future of any society depends on its ability to foster the health and well-being of the next generation. Stated simply, today\\u2019s children will become tomorrow\\u2019s citizens, workers, and parents. When we invest wisely in children and families, the next generation will pay that back through a lifetime of productivity and responsible citizenship. When we fail to provide children with what they need to build a strong foundation for healthy and productive lives, we put our future prosperity and security at risk \\u2026<\\/p>\\n<p>\\u201cAll aspects of adult human capital, from work force skills to cooperative and lawful behavior, build on capacities that are developed during childhood, beginning at birth \\u2026 The basic principles of neuroscience and the process of human skill formation indicate that early intervention for the most vulnerable children will generate the greatest payback.\\u201d<\\/p>\\n<p>It\\u2019s a disappointing revelation as to our collective humanity when the report\\u2019s author feels compelled to repeatedly refer to living, breathing and often enough suffering human beings as a well-returning &#8216;investment&#8217; and &#8216;human capital&#8217; in an attempt to convince money-minded society that it\\u2019s in our own best fiscal interest to fund early-life programs that result in lowered incidence of unhealthy, dysfunctional child development.<\\/p>\\n<p>While some may justify it as a normal thus moral human evolutionary function, the general self-serving Only If It\\u2019s In My Own Back Yard mentality (or what I acronize OIIIMOBY) can debilitate social progress, even when it\\u2019s most needed; and it seems that distinct form of societal \\u2018penny wisdom but pound foolishness\\u2019 is a very unfortunate human characteristic that\\u2019s likely with us to stay.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2021\\/01\\/25\\/time-to-roll-out-educations-recovery-package\\/#comment-48533","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/2dc2e9f2b34def00c8658f24d64f4f62?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/2dc2e9f2b34def00c8658f24d64f4f62?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/2dc2e9f2b34def00c8658f24d64f4f62?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/2dc2e9f2b34def00c8658f24d64f4f62?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/48533"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13734"}]}},{"id":48478,"post":12834,"parent":45707,"author":0,"author_name":"JORGE Dal Pogeto de Deus Cardozo","author_url":"http:\\/\\/www.consultoriassociada.webnode.pt","date":"2021-01-29T22:39:18","date_gmt":"2021-01-29T21:39:18","content":{"rendered":"<p>O impacto da Pandemia na Aprendizagem e no Desenvolvimento<br \\/>\\nA Pandemia afeta a taxa de escolariza\\u00e7\\u00e3o e esse impacto est\\u00e1 ligado diretamente a efetividade e, futuramente, ao desenvolvimento global.<br \\/>\\nJovens que abandonaram a escola custaram R$755 milh\\u00f5es anualmente a sociedade por conta das pol\\u00edticas compensat\\u00f3rias.<br \\/>\\nE, o desenvolvimento nessa faixa et\\u00e1ria de escolariza\\u00e7\\u00e3o acarreta preju\\u00edzo de R$1,2 bilh\\u00f5es.<br \\/>\\nContemplando a m\\u00e1xima import\\u00e2ncia das vari\\u00e1veis ambientais, questionamos as taxas de repet\\u00eancia, evas\\u00e3o escolar, a diminui\\u00e7\\u00e3o ou aus\\u00eancia da socializa\\u00e7\\u00e3o (face to face). Nesse cen\\u00e1rio, quem s\\u00e3o os vulner\\u00e1veis?<br \\/>\\nPartiremos definitivamente para a aprendizagem virtual? Prolongaremos mais um ano um cronograma de ensino nas atuais condi\\u00e7\\u00f5es?<br \\/>\\nQual \\u00e9 o risco maior, a Pandemia ou a desinforma\\u00e7\\u00e3o?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2021\\/01\\/27\\/mekdes-a-covid-19-learning-hero-for-deaf-children-in-ethiopia\\/#comment-48473","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5328725a119eb7944810d3211fad38db?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5328725a119eb7944810d3211fad38db?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5328725a119eb7944810d3211fad38db?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5328725a119eb7944810d3211fad38db?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/48473"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13743"}]}}]'

**********World Education Blog - Page:14**********

b'[{"id":48421,"post":13512,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Lu-Ann Wahl","author_url":"","date":"2021-01-27T19:00:25","date_gmt":"2021-01-27T18:00:25","content":{"rendered":"<p>Stefania, thank you for sharing this insightful post. I have personal experience with bullying and I know first-hand the damage it can cause a child. While I was growing up, we moved around quite a bit. This resulted in me starting the second grade in a new school. Being the new kid in school, I was a target and unfortunately got bullied by some of my peers. I was always very quiet and quite small for my age, so they knew I was an easy target. My parents started to notice that I was becoming very depressed and did not want to go to school so they sat me down had asked me what was wrong. At first, I did not want to tell them as I was embarrassed, but I knew I could keep living like this. I finally told my parents what was going on and they decided to keep me at home for a couple of days. My teacher phoned my mom to find out why I have not been to school and my mom explained the situation to her. Unfortunately, my school did not have a policy against bullying in place and I was told by my principal to suck it up and learn to stand up for myself. With no other choice, I learned to stand up for myself and did not allow anyone to treat me like that again. I wish my school had a zero-tolerance policy for bullying because although I was lucky enough to learn how to stand up for myself, not all students were able to do that.<br \\/>\\nLuckily, things have changed in most schools and educators have realized that bullying creates an unsafe environment in which students cannot thrive. At my current school, we have a zero-tolerance policy when it comes to bullying. We make use of multiple strategies to teach students the effects that bullying has on others including celebrating inclusivity and diversity, bully awareness month, and using PBIS throughout our school.<br \\/>\\nWhen students are reassured and feel safe in their school environment, they are able to concentrate and learn more effectively.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/11\\/04\\/together-against-bullying-in-school\\/#comment-48421","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d30acd6537dd80f3ff838247349f7c69?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d30acd6537dd80f3ff838247349f7c69?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d30acd6537dd80f3ff838247349f7c69?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d30acd6537dd80f3ff838247349f7c69?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/48421"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13512"}]}},{"id":48415,"post":13726,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Millennium@EDU agree. Factors linked to poverty such as unemployment, illness, and the illiteracy of parents, multiply the risk of non-schooling and the drop-out rate of a child. Leaders should focus on this because these young people will be the future of the generation and help to develop their country.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2012\\/09\\/22\\/illiteracy-in-developed-countries-ending-the-taboo\\/#comment-47972","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/290c7dce79a2f1766ff987256996d717?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/290c7dce79a2f1766ff987256996d717?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/290c7dce79a2f1766ff987256996d717?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/290c7dce79a2f1766ff987256996d717?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/47972"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/2299"}]}}]'

This is because the importance and linkage of education to the development of any society cannot be over-emphasized. It argues that for a society to develop, education must be inclusive (including the physically challenged). It examines the prospect of inclusive education within the framework of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) with particular reference to goal number four. It contextualizes this within the challenges facing the education system in Nigeria. The paper adopts a quantitative method of inquiry. A total of 200 copies of the questionnaire were distributed and 188 were retrieved and analyzed using the Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS version 17.0) software. Preliminary findings suggest that the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goal (SDGs 4) in Nigeria\\u2019s education system towards the physically challenged is in serious jeopardy and requires immediate policy revalidation. The study concludes that for a meaningful development to be achieved by Nigeria, every citizen (physically challenged inclusive), must have access to knowledge, skills, and information.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/09\\/02\\/singing-from-the-same-song-sheet-growing-momentum-across-the-disability-movement-to-adopt-a-comprehensive-definition-of-inclusive-education-to-achieve-sdg-4\\/#comment-46124","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5aea8d6be557abae826926ea7fe8708f?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5aea8d6be557abae826926ea7fe8708f?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5aea8d6be557abae826926ea7fe8708f?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5aea8d6be557abae826926ea7fe8708f?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/46124"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13297"}]}},{"id":46114,"post":13279,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Sujay Rao Mandavilli","author_url":"http:\\/\\/sujayraomandavilli.wordpress.com","date":"2020-09-10T15:36:55","date_gmt":"2020-09-10T13:36:55","content":{"rendered":"<p>it is my firm belief that developing counties and non-European cultures must play a key role in the formulation of social science theory in the 21st century. **********World Education Blog - Page:19**********

Their behaviour can then be challenging. In Scotland children have a right not to be placed in special school unless it is not suited to their ability and aptitude;  their education impacts on others, or it is unreasonably expensive.  There is a high level of support (about 77% in recent survey) for principles broadly in line with the UNESCO report.  However many teachers reported that they often did not feel supported and empowered but could feel overwhelmed and not listened to by senior managers and local authorities.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/07\\/08\\/all-teachers-should-be-prepared-to-teach-all-students\\/#comment-44686","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ce08ac52e5cc074cc9770f02111093ca?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ce08ac52e5cc074cc9770f02111093ca?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ce08ac52e5cc074cc9770f02111093ca?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ce08ac52e5cc074cc9770f02111093ca?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44686"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13178"}]}},{"id":44682,"post":13076,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Globaltel","author_url":"https:\\/\\/globaltel.com\\/","date":"2020-07-08T14:04:27","date_gmt":"2020-07-08T12:04:27","content":{"rendered":"<p>Pursuing education during this COVID-19 pandemic is seriously a struggle for everyone.
