**********World Education Blog - Page:22**********

b'[{"id":44652,"post":13160,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"naazodyssey","author_url":"http:\\/\\/naazodyssey.wordpress.com","date":"2020-07-07T14:58:58","date_gmt":"2020-07-07T12:58:58","content":{"rendered":"<p>How can Inclusion exist in mainstream classroom settings when there is a focus on scholarships and high stake exams?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44652","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/76f3e9a82bfb4ba3b5195a04f43fee07?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/76f3e9a82bfb4ba3b5195a04f43fee07?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/76f3e9a82bfb4ba3b5195a04f43fee07?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/76f3e9a82bfb4ba3b5195a04f43fee07?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44652"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}]}},{"id":44592,"post":13160,"parent":44412,"author":0,"author_name":"GEM Report","author_url":"","date":"2020-07-06T10:57:47","date_gmt":"2020-07-06T08:57:47","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thank you Anjela.<\\/p>\\n<p>As you noted, the implementation of inclusion in education remains weak in some countries, which contributes to maintaining segregation in the education systems. The UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities has reported that inclusion strategies have not equally been implemented in schools. In addition, inconsistencies between legislative and policy instruments in the field of education and beyond can be a significant barrier to inclusion, for instance allowing segregation and integration practices to coexist. <\\/p>\\n<p>Even if the political will to foster inclusion has been expressed in strategic documents and\\/or legislation, resistance to inclusion may persist. Follow-up actions are necessary and need to be tailored to the historical, political, cultural and socio-economic contexts. The 2020 GEM Report tries to answer the question: How can common obstacles to implementation of these solutions be anticipated and overcome? <\\/p>\\n<p>First, monitoring is essential to promote the implementation of inclusion. The UN CRPD calls for the establishment of a national framework for its implementation and monitoring (art. 33), which is done by many countries. In this respect, countries have established national monitoring systems to foster inclusion in education. In New Brunswick, Canada, the superintendent monitors the performance of each school based on performance indicators for inclusive education, which include ongoing professional development for administrators, teachers, educational assistants, and other professionals. In the Cook Islands, all principals have the responsibility to monitor the implementation of the inclusive education policy (<a href=\\"http:\\/\\/www.education-profiles.org\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">GEM Report PEER<\\/a>). In general, national Education Management Information Systems (EMIS), helps monitor the inclusion of education programmes and manage the distribution and allocation of educational resources. (You can also consult <a href=\\"http:\\/\\/gem-report-2017.unesco.org\\/en\\/makeitpublic-does-you-country-have-a-national-monitoring-report\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">here<\\/a> the list of countries that have a national education monitoring report).<\\/p>\\n<p>Second, cross-sector collaboration can also help overcome and anticipate the challenges that often hinder implementation. Integrated service delivery to individuals and households with complex disabilities and who need services from multiple providers can be a solution. In Moldova, for instance, ministries and government agencies in the education, social protection and assistance, and health sectors work together on delivering inclusive educational and social services to make the education system more inclusive. <\\/p>\\n<p>Third and as the report highlights, social biases and attitudes towards inclusion can be important obstacles to implementation. Reforming teacher and other personnel education programmes might encourage a shift in the school management practices. In Singapore, teachers in regular schools are initially trained to acquire an understanding of disability, while a more extensive in-service training provides them with the necessary skills to support the inclusion of students with disabilities, with the assistance of trained Allied Educators.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44592","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44592"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44412"}]}},{"id":44574,"post":12892,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Toma","author_url":"","date":"2020-07-05T11:41:01","date_gmt":"2020-07-05T09:41:01","content":{"rendered":"<p>SCHOOL PROTECTION AGAINST COVID-19<\\/p>\\n<p>This is a COVID-19 notification for public &amp; private schools. We represent a pro-gram called \\u201cProtect the Children Now\\u201d, to help safeguard students &amp; teachers from the COVID-19 virus. The system is appropriately called \\u201cThe Protector\\u201d.<\\/p>\\n<p>It can enable you to know every child\\u2019s temperature before they enter a school hallway or classroom or even get on a school bus &#8211; and provide facial recognition at the same time. It can even text the status of an individual child, if and when necessary.<\\/p>\\n<p>A typical alert to a school nurse might say, \\u201cVickie Meyers did not receive a tem-perature screening today, and can currently be found in room 109.\\u201d Or, the assis-tant principal might receive a text that says, \\u201cThe following 8 students came to school today with a temperature in excess of 100.4\\u00b0 and have been directed to go to the nurse\\u2019s office.\\u201d There are 50 such notifications in our system to alleviate the administrative burden that, without our system, you would eventually en-counter.<\\/p>\\n<p>In addition, our integrated design can even provide each child with a Smartwatch. For as little as 7\\u00a2 a day it can automatically transmit a message to the school or parents to notify them of a child\\u2019s elevated body temperature.<\\/p>\\n<p>It can also be used to protect the general public when attending a school sporting event or a graduation ceremony. And we have priced it so that every school can afford it.<\\/p>\\n<p>Within a half-second, The Protector can not only measure the student\\u2019s temperature but, in two additional seconds, using optional facial recognition can notify the school authorities or the child\\u2019s parents, via text or email.<\\/p>\\n<p>It can even detect a child in a small crowd who has an elevated body temperature or notify an attendant if someone is not wearing a mask.<\\/p>\\n<p>To receive a brochure that shows features, specifications, and pricing, please email us at <a href=\\"mailto:info@protectthechildrennow.com\\">info@protectthechildrennow.com<\\/a> or call +1 513-384-4387.<\\/p>\\n<p>Thanks for your consideration and stay safe.<\\/p>\\n<p>Dale Bennett, CEO<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/04\\/24\\/covid-19-school-closures-and-the-summer-break\\/#comment-44574","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/285db158a13870a25a09b598a6a9b553?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/285db158a13870a25a09b598a6a9b553?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/285db158a13870a25a09b598a6a9b553?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/285db158a13870a25a09b598a6a9b553?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44574"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/12892"}]}},{"id":44561,"post":13160,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Basiru Mbenga","author_url":"","date":"2020-07-04T20:48:29","date_gmt":"2020-07-04T18:48:29","content":{"rendered":"<p>1. Watt","author_url":"https:\\/\\/inclusivepracticessite.blog","date":"2020-06-30T18:14:05","date_gmt":"2020-06-30T16:14:05","content":{"rendered":"<p>Rosa &#8211; thanks for your reply. In terms of parental pressure for inclusive education. In Scotland a new group has been set up to move for more inclusive education. it is called A24Scotland drawing its name from Article 24 of the UNCRPD. They have a blog giving some stories about their children&#8217;s school experiences. <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/a24scotland.wordpress.com\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">https:\\/\\/a24scotland.wordpress.com<\\/a><\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44439","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5437b264d68d760db51baa18e26b4bc0?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5437b264d68d760db51baa18e26b4bc0?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5437b264d68d760db51baa18e26b4bc0?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5437b264d68d760db51baa18e26b4bc0?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44439"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44416"}]}},{"id":44419,"post":11838,"parent":44395,"author":0,"author_name":"GEM Report","author_url":"","date":"2020-06-29T21:57:43","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T19:57:43","content":{"rendered":"<p>The responses given to the Covid-19 outbreak and ensuing school closures have varied worldwide by country, school and even by teacher or student. In many countries, the focus has been on establishing or strengthening online platforms, with many people seeing in them as the future of education and an opportunity to \\u2018disrupt and redevelop\\u2019. <\\/p>\\n<p>This is questionable for two reasons. First, the priority should be the present of education: hundreds of millions today have no access not just to internet or devices but even to televisions and radios \\u2013 and are therefore completely excluded from learning. Second, even online solutions are poor substitutes of learning in classrooms and they should be developed to complement learning in classrooms, not to replace it. <\\/p>\\n<p>As you put it in one of the recommendations in your article, systems should pay \\u2018more attention to resilience in the face of systemic risk\\u2019. The pandemic risk should not have been ignored \\u2013 there was a 25% chance that it could happen in the space of a generation, and there were many signs it could break out, but they were ignored. This should not happen again: disaster risk reduction has to be part of education planning.<\\/p>\\n<p>There is no doubt that the \\u2018familiar forms\\u2019 of education have major weaknesses. They have been associated with teaching appropriate for industrial societies where everybody had to fit the system. It therefore depends on how education systems in \\u2018familiar form\\u2019 or \\u2018redeveloped\\u2019 are to be defined. Assuming that the Covid-19 disruption is temporary and that the \\u2018familiar form\\u2019 of a classroom cannot be changed, the only viable option is that of regeneration. The type of regeneration the 2020 GEM Report is advocating for, one where the system adapts to students and their needs.<\\/p>\\n<p>Covid-19 has changed the perception of many teachers who were confronted with the realities of their students and their living conditions. These conditions will worsen as economic recession is expected to deepen inequality and poverty for many. The response should be to build more inclusive systems to build a more resilient society. <\\/p>\\n<p>from Anna Cristina D&#8217;Addio (<a href=\\"https:\\/\\/en.unesco.org\\/gem-report\\/anna-cristina-daddio\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">https:\\/\\/en.unesco.org\\/gem-report\\/anna-cristina-daddio<\\/a>)<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/07\\/18\\/join-the-online-consultation-for-the-2020-gem-report-on-inclusion-and-education\\/#comment-44419","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44419"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11838"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44395"}]}}]'

**********World Education Blog - Page:23**********

b'[{"id":44417,"post":13160,"parent":44378,"author":0,"author_name":"GEM Report","author_url":"","date":"2020-06-29T21:28:16","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T19:28:16","content":{"rendered":"<p>There are two key points to take into account.<\\/p>\\n<p>First, countries should invest in building their capacity. The Report finds, for instance, that only 14 out of 54 countries in Africa have reported data on learning outcomes since 2014. Although reporting is not the ultimate objective, it is a sign that countries are not putting sufficient priority in this area. This should change.<\\/p>\\n<p>Second, country ownership should take priority over international comparability. The SDG 4 monitoring framework is first and foremost a formative mechanism, aimed at prompting countries to do what is needed; it is not an exercise to rank countries. For that reason, it is open to multiple sources of information. In the case of learning outcomes, both national and cross-national assessments can be used to report, provided they meet certain quality criteria. In practice:<br \\/>\\n&#8211; On the one hand, even if countries have experience conducting national examinations, this does not mean they can conduct sample-based learning assessments, which have distinct technical challenges.<br \\/>\\n&#8211; On the other hand, even highly standardized cross-national learning assessments require significant local capacity in order to generate valid data. <\\/p>\\n<p>Greater investment in assessment capacity should also focus on using such assessments to identify inequities and inform policies by tapping into the capacity of local higher education institutions and independent researchers. Making datasets and the results of their analyses publicly available is key and requires a willingness by governments to be held to account by their research communities. Such publicly available results can be a key tool for advocates who can then lobby governments to improve the quality of their assessments.<\\/p>\\n<p>International organisations, including UNESCO and specifically the UIS, facilitate actions on both fronts but more could be done if additional resources were available:<br \\/>\\n&#8211; They need to continue investigating how the prohibitive cost of standards-compliant implementation of internationally comparable assessments can be reduced, and investigate the lessons learned. External assistance is currently uncoordinated and insufficiently focused on ensuring both capacity development and data availability. This is an area in which the Report will be paying more interest.<br \\/>\\n&#8211; Peer learning between countries, as for instance through the Global Alliance to Monitor Learning, is a good starting point but requires more resources.<br \\/>\\nfrom <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/en.unesco.org\\/gem-report\\/node\\/2328\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Bilal Barakat<\\/a><\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44417","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44417"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44378"}]}},{"id":44416,"post":13160,"parent":44394,"author":0,"author_name":"GEM Report","author_url":"","date":"2020-06-29T21:11:16","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T19:11:16","content":{"rendered":"<p>The theme of the 2020 Report \\u201cInclusion and education\\u201d is particularly encompassing of the issues in the education systems globally, and calls for broad changes to education systems in order to reach all in education, particularly the furthest behind. Our report is global in nature, but its recommendations can be implemented by all the countries in the world. Though, we understand that each region has particular characteristics that need to be further analyzed, and probably need region-specific recommendations. To have a more regional-relevant analysis, we are preparing regional reports. In October 2020, we\\u2019ll launch the 2020 Latin American Regional Report, which can be readily used by national governments to mobilize sub-national and local levels with regionally-relevant recommendations. The report is to be used as an advocacy tool, to be used by all the stakeholders of the education process at all levels, including those at the local levels.<\\/p>\\n<p>Locally, the actors that are key to inclusion and education are teachers, parents, communities and civil society in general. For education to be inclusive, inclusive teaching is needed. Inclusive teaching requires teachers to recognize the experiences and abilities of every student, to be open to diversity and to be prepared to teach students with varied backgrounds and abilities. This requires that both teachers and Education official who monitor the implementation of inclusive teaching are trained on inclusive education, that the teaching force has good working conditions.<\\/p>\\n<p>Parents, organizations and civil society in general can drive inclusive education, and hence are allies to implement the recommendations locally. Parents can organize networks to press for inclusive education. For example, in the Russian Federation, parents sued the government for access to schools for children with cerebral palsy. A key challenge is to counter negative attitudes, stereotypes and discrimination and prevent their further development, as they can hamper the education of vulnerable students.<\\/p>\\n<p>Civil society is an advocate and watchdog for the right to inclusive education. While the state bears the duty of education, grassroots NGOs and CSOs often step in, especially in poorer countries, to provide education services for populations not reached by governments. Such organizations also lead the way in putting pressure on governments to fulfil their national and international obligations to guarantee the right to inclusive education for all. For example, in Armenia, an NGO campaign resulted in a decision to roll out inclusive education nationally by 2025. Government leadership, dialogue among all parties and a coordinated approach, aligned with national education policies, are essential.<\\/p>\\n<p>Reply from <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/en.unesco.org\\/gem-report\\/rosa-vidarte\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Rosa Vidarte<\\/a><\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44416","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44416"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44394"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=44416"}]}},{"id":44414,"post":13160,"parent":44400,"author":0,"author_name":"Professor Mel Ainscow","author_url":"https:\\/\\/www.gla.ac.uk\\/schools\\/education\\/staff\\/melainscow\\/","date":"2020-06-29T18:33:21","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T16:33:21","content":{"rendered":"<p>There is extensive research suggesting that when teachers are involved in decision making this is likely to promote a better climate for the learning of all students within a school. There is also evidence that schools which encourage teachers to collaborate in developing their practice are more able to improve student outcomes and reduce achievement gaps. Evidence such as this was part of the justification for the introduction of academies in England (similar to charter schools in the USA). Freed from the restrictions imposed by local authorities, it was argued, such schools would become centres of innovation that would stimulate wider system change. Sadly, the evidence is that this has not been the outcome. Whilst academies have been given space to innovate, this has usually focused on aspects of management and organization, rather than on the development of new, more creative teaching practices. As a result, those learners who do not fit with the standard ways of working are far less welcome. (See: Salokangas, M. and Ainscow, M. (2017)  Inside the autonomous school: making sense of a global educational trend. London: Routledge)<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44414","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/1e832f6caf7909b59872052bbca33ddd?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/1e832f6caf7909b59872052bbca33ddd?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/1e832f6caf7909b59872052bbca33ddd?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/1e832f6caf7909b59872052bbca33ddd?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44414"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44400"}]}},{"id":44412,"post":13160,"parent":44410,"author":0,"author_name":"Anjela Yaneja","author_url":"http:\\/\\/gravatar.com\\/anjelataneja","date":"2020-06-29T18:11:53","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T16:11:53","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thanks for this. Have read the provisions of the draft policy- some are indeed promising. However, past national and state policies also had great provisions. The question was more of how does one move a large complex system from A to Z since these (and many of the provisions in preceding policies) are plain ignored at the stage of policy implementation. How does one move the system to ensure this is implemented.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44412","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/39fd62e8a3fc31898dc417dfc8beb035?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/39fd62e8a3fc31898dc417dfc8beb035?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/39fd62e8a3fc31898dc417dfc8beb035?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/39fd62e8a3fc31898dc417dfc8beb035?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44412"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44410"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=44412"}]}},{"id":44410,"post":13160,"parent":44392,"author":0,"author_name":"GEM Report","author_url":"","date":"2020-06-29T17:35:02","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T15:35:02","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thank you Anjela for your question. <\\/p>\\n<p>As you pointed out in your blog for Oxfam India \\u201c<a href=\\"https:\\/\\/www.oxfamindia.org\\/blog\\/how-can-indias-education-system-escape-vicious-cycle-inequality-and-discrimination\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">How can India\\u2019s education system escape the vicious cycle of inequality and discrimination?<\\/a>\\u201d social inequalities and educational inequalities \\u201cgo hand in hand\\u201d and \\u201cinequality in access or quality in education risks reinforcing social and economic inequalities\\u201d. In response, the 2020 Global Education Monitoring Report affirms that inclusion is the key to breaking the wheel of inequality in education. <\\/p>\\n<p>Inclusion and equity in and through education are at the core of the 2030 Agenda. SDG 4 aims to ensure \\u201cinclusive and equitable quality education\\u201d and promote \\u201clifelong learning for all\\u201d. Equity is the process of ensuring equality in educational opportunities. Inclusion, as a prerequisite for education and a democracy based on equity, provides a systematic framework for removing barriers according to the principles of \\u201call means all\\u201d\\u2018 and every learner matters equally. It is the process to meet the diverse needs of all learners. <\\/p>\\n<p>The 2020 GEM Report approaches inclusion broadly, considering all learners irrespective of their backgrounds and abilities, as \\u201cdiscrimination, stereotyping and stigmatization mechanisms are similar for all learners at risk of exclusion\\u201d. To widen the understanding of inclusive education is a necessary step and overarching recommendations for those involved in education, necessary to break inequality in and beyond education. Commitment to diversity as a resource to be celebrated is essential in this respect.  <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/meae.gov.mt\\/en\\/Public_Consultations\\/MEDE\\/Documents\\/A%20Policy%20on%20Inclusive%20Education%20in%20Schools%20-%20Route%20to%20Quality%20Inclusion%E2%80%8B.pdf\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Malta\\u2019s Policy on Inclusive Education in Schools<\\/a>, for example, defines inclusive education as \\u201cthe valuing and acceptance of diversity, to its value and the rights of learners to not only attend mainstream schools, but also to belong as valued members through active participation and the elimination of the barriers limiting the participation and achievement of all learners, respect diverse needs, abilities and characteristics.\\u201d Actually, 68% of countries have a definition of inclusion, but only 57% cover multiple marginalized groups. Countries also focus on different risk factors as described also in the  Profiles Enhancing Education Reviews (PEER) (<a href=\\"http:\\/\\/education-profiles.org\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">http:\\/\\/www.education-profiles.org<\\/a>). In terms of laws and policies, only 10% of countries reflect  such a comprehensive vision for all learner  in their general or inclusive education laws. Successful practices in inclusion are supported by robust governance frameworks and structures, financial resources, positive attitudes towards inclusion, as well as measures for collaboration, teacher workforce, initial and continuous teachers and other education professional training and monitoring. All these factors are interdependent. It is not enough to move students from special schools to regular schools. It is not enough to interpret inclusion in terms of placement. Inclusion needs also to be understood in terms of learning and requires a complete change of systems to adapt to everyone&#8217;s needs. <\\/p>\\n<p>Considering the relevance of governance mechanisms, the PEER on inclusion in education tries to go beyond education, collecting information on how the country\\u2019s social legislative and policy documents frame inclusion in education and how coordination takes place. Widening the understanding of inclusive education needs soundness and coherence of cooperation across sectors, which  would enhance the possibility to formulate effective policies for inclusion in education. The profile of India refers to the systematic <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/mhrd.gov.in\\/sites\\/upload_files\\/mhrd\\/files\\/Draft_NEP_2019_EN_Revised.pdf\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">2019 draft India Education Policy <\\/a>that was discussed by the Cabinet in May. Reflecting the SDG 4 objectives, Chapter 6 intends to shape an education system that can reach out to and benefit all children, calling for concrete reforms in the school culture and curriculum, including tailored measures, such as the establishment of Special Education Zones (SEZs) in geographical areas with the largest proportions of underrepresented groups. Within the broad approach of inclusion in education, it is important to recognize and address all learners\\u2019 needs, as highlighted in India\\u2019s draft policy, from the education for girls, to education for transgender children and children belonging to scheduled caste communities and other backward classes, as their characteristics and needs are cross-cutting and might be relevant to all. Reply from <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/en.unesco.org\\/gem-report\\/daniel_april\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Daniel April<\\/a> and <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/en.unesco.org\\/gem-report\\/node\\/2689\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Francesca Endrizzi<\\/a><\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44410","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44410"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44392"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=44410"}]}},{"id":44409,"post":13160,"parent":44402,"author":0,"author_name":"keithlewin","author_url":"http:\\/\\/gravatar.com\\/keithlewin","date":"2020-06-29T17:00:50","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T15:00:50","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thanks Yuki<br \\/>\\nEasy to agree with this. The question I put really is an invitation to explore what is meant by the most marginalised both at individual level and at group category level. Never going to school is marginalising and even more so the older you are. But we generally chose to do less for those who are much older than those who are of primary age. Who is most marginalised?    And the problem with the 258 million OOSC is that most of them are over 15 years old &#8211; the minimum legal age of work &#8211; and most of them went to primary school and some lower secondary before dropping out. The most marginalised are therefore a much smaller number globally. But how to balance the needs of the smaller number of most marginalised against the larger numbers of those less marginalised who are nevertheless marginalised beyond some margin. The real world political economy issue is how to reconcile the need for some kind of positive discrimination to compensate for disadvantage with the real politik of power in stratified societies that has difficulty in addressing social inequality in service delivery and quality and in revenue generation.   <\\/p>\\n<p>Thanks for the other points. Borrowing will be especially risky post COVID 19 since the ability to service loans will be compromised by falling tax revenues as recession bites. Thats why grants have to be preserved for those with no other means of investing rather than used to lower loan rates at the cost of foregoing grants to the most marginalised. <\\/p>\\n<p>Good luck in taking this forward<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44409","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/384a9f3e9effc07816406b3b76a8a1db?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/384a9f3e9effc07816406b3b76a8a1db?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/384a9f3e9effc07816406b3b76a8a1db?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/384a9f3e9effc07816406b3b76a8a1db?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44409"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44402"}]}},{"id":44408,"post":13160,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"talentfortransition","author_url":"http:\\/\\/gravatar.com\\/talentfortransition","date":"2020-06-29T16:59:02","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T14:59:02","content":{"rendered":"<p>A further issue raised by the GEM Report relates to the accessibility of this thoughtful,  comprehensive and evidence-led commentary. It needs to be viewed (and acted upon) widely &#8211; rather than being an ubiquitous &#8216;policy on a teacher&#8217;s or others bookshelf&#8217;. 400+ pages will immediately discourage many mainstream teachers from getting to grips with their content. As a starter, nasen (National Association for Special Educational Needs, UK:   <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/nasen.org.uk\\/?gclid=EAIaIQobChMIs8ufgZKn6gIVkuvtCh2oaQZnEAAYASAAEgIj0vD_BwEn\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">https:\\/\\/nasen.org.uk\\/?gclid=EAIaIQobChMIs8ufgZKn6gIVkuvtCh2oaQZnEAAYASAAEgIj0vD_BwEn<\\/a> ) is working on a 2-page GEM &#8216;smartsheet&#8217;, complete with a hyperlink to the main Report and a infographic-style. This is being produced as a quick guide for stakeholders though obviously from a specific cultural\\/professional standpoint.<br \\/>\\nThank you<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44408","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/898e45994613af0a9b41b5fe6a3477c5?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/898e45994613af0a9b41b5fe6a3477c5?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/898e45994613af0a9b41b5fe6a3477c5?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/898e45994613af0a9b41b5fe6a3477c5?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44408"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}]}},{"id":44402,"post":13160,"parent":44388,"author":0,"author_name":"GEM Report","author_url":"","date":"2020-06-29T15:48:05","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T13:48:05","content":{"rendered":"<p>Large domestic education financing gaps remain. One in three countries do not meet either of the two international benchmarks for the percentages of GDP and public expenditure dedicated to education, respectively, which means they either have a poor capacity to collect revenues or they do not prioritize education enough &#8211; or both. <\\/p>\\n<p>Even for the poorest countries, there is no one-size-fits-all answer.<br \\/>\\n1. Domestic resource mobilization is the most sustainable solution. Past editions of the Report \\u2013 and an analysis from the World Bank last year \\u2013 have shown that increased spending on education has been mainly the result of stronger ability to raise revenue through taxes.<br \\/>\\n2. However, as the Report this year further emphasizes, spending needs to be more sensitive to different needs, through two main ways: (i) targeting resources to those furthest behind: many general resource allocation mechanisms do not take such needs into account (or even exacerbate inequalities if they rely on local governments to raise revenues for which the poorest ones have low capacity) and (ii) thinking in joined-up terms: not only education budgets contribute to education outcomes; budgets of other social sector ministries can contribute as much, if not more, to education outcomes when they are properly planned. Governments need a twin-track approach that allocates general funding to all learners to promote a comprehensive learning environment and targeted funding to follow the furthest behind as early as possible.<br \\/>\\n3. The allocation of resources between levels of education is a challenge for many countries. The 2019 edition of the Report (Figure 19.4) showed a natural progression that countries follow in the shares they allocate from pre-primary to post-secondary. Extremes need to be avoided. While lack of access even to primary education remains one of the most serious equity challenges, financing of secondary education should not be squeezed since it is needed to produce skilled workers, not least teachers. We know that limited opportunities for secondary schooling may undermine demand for primary education. We also know that the costs of secondary education can be contained through effective planning.<\\/p>\\n<p>With respect to aid to education, the Report notes that aid in general has been declining as a share of the poorest countries\\u2019 economies, although it remains sizeable at 9% for low-income countries, with a slight increase since 2015 (Figure 21.5). Low-income countries have also seen a slight increase in their share of aid to education in recent years.<\\/p>\\n<p>External borrowing has been proposed for middle-income countries, in response to declining shares of education in the multilateral development banks\\u2019 lending portfolios. However, in the current context, with debt levels potentially growing, there might be some concern about the risk of exposing countries to higher levels of borrowing. Reply from <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/en.unesco.org\\/gem-report\\/yuki-murakami\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Yuki Murakami<\\/a><\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44402","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44402"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44388"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=44402"}]}},{"id":44401,"post":13160,"parent":44399,"author":0,"author_name":"talentfortransition","author_url":"http:\\/\\/gravatar.com\\/talentfortransition","date":"2020-06-29T15:42:49","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T13:42:49","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thank you Bilal &#8211; this is a very reassuring viewpoint! My commentary was that of an educationist, of course. But, hopefully, we&#8217;d start from the premise that &#8216;Education for All&#8217; is one of the very minimum requirements for an inclusive (and therefore humane) society. Thank you again<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44401","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/898e45994613af0a9b41b5fe6a3477c5?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/898e45994613af0a9b41b5fe6a3477c5?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/898e45994613af0a9b41b5fe6a3477c5?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/898e45994613af0a9b41b5fe6a3477c5?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44401"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44399"}]}},{"id":44400,"post":13160,"parent":44384,"author":0,"author_name":"GEM Report","author_url":"","date":"2020-06-29T15:42:29","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T13:42:29","content":{"rendered":"<p>The next Global Education Monitoring Report will explore non-state actors in education. Governments are the primary duty bearers to the right to education. At the same time, non-state actors provide education in many parts of the world. <\\/p>\\n<p>This means that governments do not only need to provide inclusive public schools, but that they need to ensure legislation, monitoring and regulation in order to ensure that private providers operate in a way that ensures equity and inclusion. <\\/p>\\n<p>Parents may choose private schools, because they believe that they are more accountable to them directly. Charter schools, many of which can be found in the US and in UK, receive government funding but are operated independently. This autonomy allows them to have their own management practices. Evidence on better learning outcomes in charter schools, however, is mixed (<a href=\\"https:\\/\\/assets.publishing.service.gov.uk\\/media\\/5bad06c240f0b62ddcfd7029\\/178_non-state_provision.pdf\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Aslam, 2017<\\/a>).<\\/p>\\n<p>As the 2020 Global Education Monitoring Report shows, school choice also depends on parents\\u2019 assessment of their children\\u2019s ability to learn and, in the case of moderate to severe disabilities, their eventual ability to work. Popular beliefs about disability can distort parental perspectives about their child\\u2019s potential. Parents who believe their child has a condition that sets them apart from society (medical model) favour special schools to focus on life skills, while parents who believe social, institutional and attitudinal barriers prevent inclusion (social model) prefer inclusive schools because they encourage social integration (Mawene and Bal, 2018). Parents with negative attitudes towards inclusive education tend to have little faith in the mainstream school system (<a href=\\"https:\\/\\/unesdoc.unesco.org\\/ark:\\/48223\\/pf0000373688\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Opoku, 2020<\\/a>).<\\/p>\\n<p>In Australia\\u2019s Queensland state, a survey of parents of children with disabilities attending public schools \\u2013 whether special or mainstream \\u2013 showed that half favoured special classes, possibly because 70% believed their child required more patient teachers, more substantial changes in classroom procedures and more special training for teachers than they thought were available in mainstream settings (<a href=\\"https:\\/\\/onlinelibrary.wiley.com\\/doi\\/abs\\/10.1111\\/1471-3802.00005\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Elkins et al., 2003<\\/a>). Reply from <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/en.unesco.org\\/gem-report\\/node\\/2957\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Matthias Eck<\\/a><\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44400","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44400"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44384"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=44400"}]}},{"id":44399,"post":13160,"parent":44393,"author":0,"author_name":"GEM Report","author_url":"","date":"2020-06-29T15:32:40","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T13:32:40","content":{"rendered":"<p>We completely agree with this assessment and hope the report is not perceived as purist or distanced from reality. There is one basic premise: that all those engaged in education embrace the value of diversity and believe in the potential of all children to learn. But otherwise, the 2020 GEM Report frames inclusion first and foremost as a process, and acknowledges that different countries&#8217; starting points and histories may call for different pathways towards creating more inclusive education systems. To highlight the fact that inclusion is not a separate agenda for the benefit of certain groups, the Report takes the view that inclusion requires addressing all forms of exclusion and marginalization and individual difference. Reply from <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/en.unesco.org\\/gem-report\\/node\\/2328\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Bilal Barakat<\\/a><\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44399","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44399"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44393"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=44399"}]}},{"id":44398,"post":13153,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Miriam Kingston","author_url":"","date":"2020-06-29T15:31:38","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T13:31:38","content":{"rendered":"<p>Re Laws on inclusion which DO focus on students with disabilities<\\/p>\\n<p>Arrangements for delivery of the right to inclusive education for people with disabilities requires that national  legislative frameworks for inclusion are carefully scrutinised to ensure that discriminatory practices are not embedded, albeit disguised, within the legislation itself.<\\/p>\\n<p>An example of such practice can be clearly seen in Section 2 of the Irish Education for Persons with Special Educational Needs Act 2004. While  &#8216;inclusion&#8217; is not defined within the Act, Section 2 provides as follows:<\\/p>\\n<p>&#8220;2. A child with special educational needs shall be educated in an inclusive environment with children who do not have such needs unless the nature or degree of those needs of the child is such that to do so would be inconsistent with\\u2014<\\/p>\\n<p>(a) the best interests of the child as determined in accordance with any assessment carried out under this Act, or<\\/p>\\n<p>(b) the effective provision of education for children with whom the child is to be educated.&#8221;<\\/p>\\n<p>The section when closely analysed  provides that a student is entitled to inclusive education on condition that the provision of education is deemed to be in the best interests of the student. Furthermore the provision of such education must not interfere with the education of  other non-disabled students. <\\/p>\\n<p>A similar \\u2018get out clause\\u2019 is located in the provisions of the Irish Equal Status Act 2000, (as amended by the Equality Act 2004), which promotes equality<br \\/>\\nand prohibits discrimination, harassment and related behaviour in connection with the provision of services, property and other opportunities to which the public generally or a section of the public has access. While the provisions of the Act are underpinned by a presumption of mainstreaming for disabled students, s 7 of the Act provides that a school will be exempt from the requirement to provide service to a disabled student only to the extent that to do so would (because of the students\\u2019 disability) have a seriously detrimental effect on the provision of service to other students or would make it impossible to provide services to other students. <\\/p>\\n<p>In this context it is clear that the entitlement to inclusive education is circumscribed by provisions which reference disabled students\\u2019 entitlement to inclusive education to the education of other students. Of particular note however, is the fact that disabled students\\u2019 entitlement to inclusive education is not referenced to the education of their non-disabled peers. <\\/p>\\n<p>It follows that many policies conceived within the existing legislative framework, lay the basis for a \\u2018dressed up\\u2019 version of traditional practices which endorse and promote the placement and treatment  of students perceived to be difficult to segregated school settings, separate &#8216;pull out&#8217; support programmes etc where medical model thinking continues to be reinforced.<\\/p>\\n<p>Kingston, Miriam (2006) Restricted Recognition: Teachers in the Irish Education System &#8211; A Barrier to Inclusive Education?\\u00a0The Disability Archive at disability-studies.leeds.ac.uk<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/26\\/jean-paul-gaultier-hillary-clinton-shakira-pele-yalitza-aparicio-and-others-join-in-calling-for-more-inclusive-education\\/#comment-44398","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/34a40adb63ad0d8d9c462fef3ae20e35?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/34a40adb63ad0d8d9c462fef3ae20e35?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/34a40adb63ad0d8d9c462fef3ae20e35?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/34a40adb63ad0d8d9c462fef3ae20e35?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44398"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13153"}]}}]'

**********World Education Blog - Page:24**********

b'[{"id":44396,"post":13160,"parent":44385,"author":0,"author_name":"GEM Report","author_url":"","date":"2020-06-29T14:02:44","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T12:02:44","content":{"rendered":"<p>Beliefs and attitudes should not be the basis for discrimination against anyone in education participation and experience. There are indeed examples of initiatives that guide the understanding of school leaders, teachers and parents.<\\/p>\\n<p>In Kenya, for example, in partnership with the Ministry of Education and UNICEF, Unified Champion Schools has helped assess and refer children identified with intellectual disabilities, following up with workshops on inclusive education with families, teachers and school leaders. The project has enrolled nearly 600 students with intellectual disabilities and has helped develop positive attitudes towards these students in participating schools. Special Olympics contributed to the development of the national inclusive education policy, including drafting an easy to read version. Unified Champion Schools, in partnership with Catholic Relief Services, continues Special Olympics Kenya\\u2019s work on early childhood development for children with intellectual disabilities through the Young Athletes programme. Identifying children in need of services early helps support families, providing a hopeful vision for their children\\u2019s future and disproving widely held myths about ability to learn (<a href=\\"https:\\/\\/www.specialolympics.org\\/stories\\/impact\\/opening-eyes-in-kenya\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Special Olympics Kenya, 2018<\\/a>).<\\/p>\\n<p>Afghanistan is another example regarding the involvement of the community. Afghanistan is marked by several exclusion challenges: security issues that expose schools as targets for attacks; cultural beliefs that systematically exclude girls and children with disabilities; and poverty, which exacerbates geographical and climate challenges in remote mountainous areas. Community-based education has been a key mechanism in addressing these challenges. The system is primarily made up of community-based classes and accelerated learning programmes jointly established and implemented by provincial and district education departments, communities and NGOs (<a href=\\"https:\\/\\/www.humanitarianresponse.info\\/sites\\/www.humanitarianresponse.info\\/files\\/documents\\/files\\/cbe_policy_guidelines_2018.pdf\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Afghanistan Ministry of Education, 2018<\\/a>). Reply from <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/en.unesco.org\\/gem-report\\/node\\/2957\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">Matthias Eck<\\/a><\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44396","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b1706e8b926116b0412f5fa1db375e07?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44396"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44385"}]}},{"id":44395,"post":11838,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"keithlewin","author_url":"http:\\/\\/gravatar.com\\/keithlewin","date":"2020-06-29T13:33:29","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T11:33:29","content":{"rendered":"<p>Professor Keith M Lewin, University of Sussex<br \\/>\\nTwo questions&#8230;.<\\/p>\\n<p>1.\\tRecommendation 2 GEMR 2020 advocates targeting financing on those left behind and especially the quarter of a billion who remain out of school.  UIS Factsheet 56 and GEMR 2018 showed that over 50% of these Out of School Children (138 million out of 258 million)) are over 15 years old and of Upper Secondary age. They are the now the largest age group excluded from education by far. <\\/p>\\n<p>Should financing now shift to favour investment at upper secondary level to reduce these high levels of exclusion or should it be focussed on the smaller numbers excluded at lower levels? Should more borrowing be used to finance expansion at levels above primary or do other strategies need to be developed including more emphasis on domestic fiscal reform?   <\\/p>\\n<p>2.\\tCOVID 19 is resulting from new forms of exclusion and exacerbating old inequalities.<br \\/>\\nThere is much debate about whether the best strategy is to rebuild existing systems or whether to take the opportunity to disrupt and redevelop education systems to address their existing shortcomings (see <a href=\\"http:\\/\\/link.springer.com\\/article\\/10.1007\\/s11125-020-09480-3\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">http:\\/\\/link.springer.com\\/article\\/10.1007\\/s11125-020-09480-3<\\/a>). Is it better to regenerate in familiar forms or is it better to seek more radical innovation and if so why?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/07\\/18\\/join-the-online-consultation-for-the-2020-gem-report-on-inclusion-and-education\\/#comment-44395","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/384a9f3e9effc07816406b3b76a8a1db?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/384a9f3e9effc07816406b3b76a8a1db?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/384a9f3e9effc07816406b3b76a8a1db?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/384a9f3e9effc07816406b3b76a8a1db?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44395"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11838"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=44395"}]}},{"id":44394,"post":13160,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"David Watt","author_url":"https:\\/\\/inclusivepracticessite.blog\\/","date":"2020-06-29T13:28:19","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T11:28:19","content":{"rendered":"<p>How can you now encourage  governments to take action on the recommendations in the Report towards building capacity for collaborations at local levels for more inclusive practices?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/06\\/29\\/your-questions-answered-pose-your-questions-live-to-the-authors-of-the-2020-gem-report\\/#comment-44394","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5437b264d68d760db51baa18e26b4bc0?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5437b264d68d760db51baa18e26b4bc0?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5437b264d68d760db51baa18e26b4bc0?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5437b264d68d760db51baa18e26b4bc0?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/44394"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/13160"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=44394"}]}},{"id":44393,"post":13160,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"talentfortransition","author_url":"http:\\/\\/gravatar.com\\/talentfortransition","date":"2020-06-29T13:15:34","date_gmt":"2020-06-29T11:15:34","content":{"rendered":"<p>Professor Philip Garner, Brunel University London<\\/p>\\n<p> Some questions\\u2026<\\/p>\\n<p> Why is \\u2018Inclusive Practice\\u2019 in schools not viewed as an integral component of the so-called \\u2018Standards Agenda\\u2019? Why do \\u2018inclusive schools\\u2019 not receive substantive official credit for the value they add to childrens\\u2019 life chances? Why is \\u2018individualised learning\\u2019 not more widely validated as a concept (via individualised planning, teaching, assessment and opportunity)? Why do teacher education systems continue to lionise subject-based teaching at the absolute expense (yes, that is the word) of exploration and understanding of learner difference? Why is \\u2018Inclusive Leadership\\u2019 not the ultimate celebratory accolade for a school principal &amp; leadership team? Why do some groups who experience barriers to learning (for example, those who have challenges relating to social, emotional and mental health issues) excluded from much of the \\u2018mainstream\\u2019 conversation regarding inclusive education? Why is inclusive education so often a bolt-on topic for discussion at many major educational conferences, subject association meetings or special interest groups?<\\/p>\\n<p> Finding positive solutions to these questions will materially contribute to making educational communities at large more inclusive. Positive, action-based responses are needed \\u2013 not further \\u2018gazing at the problem\\u2019. In embarking on development we must also recognise the journey, which is continuous and which will have wrong-turnings and imperfections. Please do not obstruct progress by demanding ideological inclusion purity \\u2013 these efforts need to be inclusive in themselves, so that all voices are heard and sythesised into practices and outcomes that directly impact on all children and young people. And so that we no longer have to prefix \\u2018Education\\u2019 with \\u2018Inclusive\\u2019<\\/p>\\n<p>Thank you<\\/p>\\n<p>WordPress.com \\/ Gravatar.com credentials can be The current examination system from primary to higher education forbids thousands of intelligent people   access to many of researches  due to the examination systems in education.  Similarly online work including online teaching will be prevalent through out the world within a few years. So far we are focusing on the &#8220;average&#8221; reaction. But the issue of differentiated reaction should receive attention, as we settle in to live with this&#8230;  We tend to think that the most vulnerable will be the low-income, girls, etc., but there may well be a sub-layer of random inequality that could be huge, introduced by the luck or un-luck of being a city or micro-region that becomes a hot Quarantine policies  have resulted in the suspension of classes at all levels and the temporary closure of institutions. Private institutions are dependent upon the tuition and school fees paid by students to fund institution operations. Since classes are suspended, institutions have difficulty funding payrolls as well as paying for utilities as student payments are also suspended.<\\/p>\\n<p>Due to the need to continue with physical distancing requirements, institutions are considering delivery of programs and courses wholly or partially online. This, however, means being able to fund the hardware and software requirements  of digital delivery as well as the costs of course materials conversion and faculty training. Though online delivery would enable the resumption of delivery of education and training to students, the initial investment to make online delivery possible adds to the financial problems of institutions.<\\/p>\\n<p>Classes have been scheduled to resume in September. Institutions are scrambling to get ready as best they can while telecommunications companies strive to resolve the challenge of slow, limited infrastructure to handle a  super increase in I think that the current situation of organizing online teaching and learning poses indeed major challenges to the delivery of quality education. Most HEIs were moving to it in a rush without much preparedness. But the situation is also an opportunity to break boundaries and to experiment with new modalities, many teachers would probably have opposed an obligation to deliver online education under other circumstances. I hope that HEIs and national authorities will take stock of what has worked well and what were the obstacles, when we move out of the COVID 19 pandemic, and take a fresh look at their systems and to MAIYASHI","author_url":"","date":"2020-04-30T17:41:55","date_gmt":"2020-04-30T15:41:55","content":{"rendered":"<p>Girls; Women education advocacy is perhaps the most crucial agenda facing us today, particularly Africa, the Middle East and Asia. It is a battle we must fight to win.Unfortunately, the front liners in this very important battle often do not command the composure required in fighting a sensitive battle.  Advocacy must be strategic and systematic. in this case, the very important value of girls and women education is often being presented as if it a battle to equalize or fight the men to submission.<br \\/>\\nThe truth of the matter is, that women have SPECIAL VALUE. And this can can bring to bear in the human development process. Besides their huge demographic population, they posses tremendous value even traditional societies. In many societies they are the backbone of the economy. What the advocates of girls and women education ought to fully grasp is to appreciate the fact that every society has it cultural and traditional sensitivities. The cultural sensitivities of Saudi  Arabia are different from Egypt or Tunisia despite their seeming homogeneity in religion . Extending this line of thought to other regions of Africa, the Middle East and Asia gives a multiplicity of cultural and traditional  sensitivities  that should inform any meaningful strategy that is context specific in addressing  this all important global agenda. Many women who are front liners in pushing this important agenda lack the understanding of these critical sensitivities and even the moral carriage to be models of the value of the woman.<br \\/>\\nThe use of the word  EQUALITY naturally evokes aggression or conflict particularly in very sensitive cultures. Equality yes, but the crucial issue is that the girl child and the women have very SPECIAL VALUE even in traditional societies. And that education will surely enhance these values to the benefit of belonging families, the community and society at large. TODAY even in traditional societies women are the backbones of the economies of their families and their communities. With access to quality and functional education the life and economic enlistment of their families and community will shoot to the level of dignity and human happiness.<br \\/>\\nWHAT WE MUST DO is to develop our strategies informed by these cultural sensitivities and surely victory is assured. And African nations particularly must stop paying lip service to the provision of education to all those entitled to particularly the girl child and women. hence forth women should only support office seekers who are committed to providing universal and qualitative education   for the good of all.<\\/p>\\n<p>Lets move on resolutely to push this very important agenda until IT IS WON..<\\/p>\\n<p>The JFK wrote a memo in 1961 in which the policy was designed to ensure non-discrimination in university enrollment. This is important for many parties, especially institution leaders that need to ensure equitable access to higher education. When American institutions take affirmative action, that means that they consider an applicant&#8217;s race in their admission factors. I think it was important that it was noted that there have been declines in the number of minority students enrolling in States that have banned the inclusion of race as a factor in admissions. Data has shown that all parties benefit from diversity in many settings. In sub-saharan Africa, it is not uncommon to lose two months of education during the school year (outside summer break), because of teachers strikes, elections and other phenomenons. The next school year could be an opportunity for teachers to make sure all the pupils have basic competencies and prerequisite (reading, numeracy) before diving into the official program. That would require a switch in teaching mode and a change of the educational culture. The examination preparation has probably too big a role in the teaching practices and orientations. Model of schooling in Africa is based on European end of XIX century schools. farming and parenting as well as the social life of children and parents which will definitely be affected. 2- The effectiveness of online distance education adopted globally which to me may not impart positively to pedagogy in many developing Countries especially in Africa where many rural communities have limited or little access to internet, unreliable electricity supply, and faced with extreme poverty ..This will have a long impact on the quality of outcome and output of the system<br \\/>\\nOf worrisome issue is the scenario of increased in the rate of domestic violence due to Daniela","author_url":"https:\\/\\/www.nost.fr\\/annuaire-des-membres-2\\/1570\\/piana-daniela\\/","date":"2020-04-02T19:07:52","date_gmt":"2020-04-02T17:07:52","content":{"rendered":"<p>The acknowledgement of the authentic nature of the shift from material to immaterial spaces where teaching and learning take place is now a compelling task to be performed by all education institutions and actors all over the world. E-learning and digital teaching are not a transposition of a streaming lecturing. We need to move from a paradigm of teaching based on sessions where one source of knowledge is activated &#8211; the teacher &#8211; to a MODEL WHERE THE TEACHER PLAYS THE ROLE OF A &#8220;NAVIGATOR&#8221; ACROSS SOURCES OF KNOWLEDGE, steering and leading students to engage into a critical questions of the added value each of them bring. Students must valued themselves as critical thinkers. Leading a plural learning process that takes place in the interaction with video recording experiences, witnesses from in context view, imagines, archives, visions of different ways of living that google earth provides, all sources of knowledge that are now standing as separate platform, medium, may become parts of a comprehensive and integrated teaching infrastructure, where navigating knowledge is essential.<br \\/>\\nThis dramatic situation which forces all of us to teach through the digital is also an unpredictable and unforeseen window to dream and to design the education paradigm we want. Dream because no new world can be build without a dream, design because we need to rethink completely the model of knowledge transfer and skill development that we are now encouranged to leave behind. Teachers are called to act in a new way and the experiences they all represent &#8211; as living sources of good practices &#8211; must now be integrated and compounded into an overall portrait that lifts all of us up into a new paradigm. The digital is not just a different channel to replicate the same model in a more cheap manner, it might be a catalyser of a deep, unexpected, but mostly needed and welcome, paradigm change.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/04\\/01\\/covid-19-wheres-the-discussion-on-distance-learning-training-for-teachers\\/#comment-42949","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3681d1421890938335befff49c646c62?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3681d1421890938335befff49c646c62?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3681d1421890938335befff49c646c62?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3681d1421890938335befff49c646c62?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/42949"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/12801"}]}},{"id":42946,"post":12767,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Hameed Hakeem","author_url":"","date":"2020-04-02T14:38:23","date_gmt":"2020-04-02T12:38:23","content":{"rendered":"<p>A useful write-up of the situation from UNESCO . I was rather surprised to read that \\u201cIn Washington State, United States, the schools are not encouraged to provide online learning services unless equitable access is ensured.\\u201d Is the inequity or disparity in access so stark and difficult to address that online learning services are not offered at all by some schools? When can a school decide that \\u201cequitable access\\u201d is ensured? What does this online learning services policy during the Covid19 disruption imply? Equality of no opportunity for online learning unless equal opportunities are available for all to access online learning? Perhaps practical and helpful solutions (as identified in this write up) can be found to ensure education services are offered.
