read!<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/03\\/18\\/coronavirus-could-education-systems-have-been-better-prepared\\/#comment-42841","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/557b529806e036e188e81b921e4290e6?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/557b529806e036e188e81b921e4290e6?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/557b529806e036e188e81b921e4290e6?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/557b529806e036e188e81b921e4290e6?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/42841"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/12752"}]}},{"id":42837,"post":12755,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Radhika Gorur","author_url":"","date":"2020-03-21T00:38:03","date_gmt":"2020-03-20T23:38:03","content":{"rendered":"<p>I suspect the shift will not be from large-scale or standardised exam-based assessments to teacher-led assessments &#8211; because for the latter, you need a lot of interaction with the teacher which may not be feasible in the post-COVID &#8216;classroom&#8217;. I expect various forms of personalised testing options will increase &#8211; following from the personalised learning ones already proliferating like Byju&#8217;s and Khan Academy etc. PISA has already developed adaptive, computer-based testing as has NAPLAN in Australia &#8211; these are likely to become widely available and perhaps even available to individual subscription. Or school systems may buy up subscription to such individualised learning and assessment plans &#8211; side-lining teacher-led assessments. Of course this will massively increase the inequality that already exists with large segments of the population unable to access the technologies required to run these programs. Or perhaps the world will see tablets becoming more evenly distributed, high-speed internet made available widely for free by governments &#8211; and such measures may go some distance towards creating some equality, even though the advantages associated with socio-cultural background will take a couple of generations to overcome. But what about basics like electricity to run these devices? Will the reduced power consumption that may result from reduced consumption in general post-COVID make for a more equitable distribution of these basics?<br \\/>\\nIt is, of course, not clear what effects of &#8216;personalised learning&#8217; and &#8216;personalised assessment&#8217; will have on both learning and on society. In terms of learning, &#8216;personalisation&#8217; will depend very much on some generalised &#8216;standardisation&#8217; that provides the norms that under-grid the adaptive systems. Typically, these will be black boxed and therefore will not be easy to critique. This means that a particular conception of &#8216;learning&#8217; will get even more globalised. As to learning, what happens to epistemology when a social act such as learning, which depends on common sense-making, loses the &#8216;society&#8217; of current classrooms remains to be seen. Perhaps virtual classrooms will replace them admirably, even if not always synchronously. Perhaps not. In terms of implications for society, it is worth pondering how &#8216;individualised learning&#8217; (mimicking individualised medicine and precision medicine) might affect our sociability and sense of social responsibility. But perhaps COVID will teach us that our own well-being depends on the well-being of others, and within that context, people will find ways to make learning more widely available and accessible to all.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/03\\/20\\/could-coronavirus-shape-the-way-assessments-work-forever\\/#comment-42837","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/6b971796815e48dcfc54fc78f46cc2c5?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/6b971796815e48dcfc54fc78f46cc2c5?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/6b971796815e48dcfc54fc78f46cc2c5?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/6b971796815e48dcfc54fc78f46cc2c5?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/42837"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/12755"}]}},{"id":42831,"post":12752,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"\\u042d\\u0434\\u0432\\u0430\\u0440\\u0434 \\u041d\\u043e\\u0440\\u0442\\u043e\\u043d","author_url":"http:\\/\\/robertmgorton.wordpress.com","date":"2020-03-19T12:10:15","date_gmt":"2020-03-19T11:10:15","content":{"rendered":"<p>Very good and high quality text with great tips. It&#8217;s getting worse if they don&#8217;t have education knowledge.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2019\\/12\\/03\\/10-students-with-a-disability-talk-about-the-difficulties-of-accessing-inclusive-education-in-the-usa\\/#comment-42532","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5389ce28170d8834c12e4fd9cb62d44d?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5389ce28170d8834c12e4fd9cb62d44d?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5389ce28170d8834c12e4fd9cb62d44d?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5389ce28170d8834c12e4fd9cb62d44d?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/42532"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/12530"}]}},{"id":42456,"post":12694,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Anthony Hannon","author_url":"https:\\/\\/www.miseancara.ie\\/","date":"2020-02-26T18:25:32","date_gmt":"2020-02-26T17:25:32","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thank you for this interesting blog. While there is little I would disagree with it is, i think, worthwhile noting that there is a very wide spectrum of private actors in education and some (particularly those that are not for profit and working with marginalised communities &#8211; or the &#8220;furthest behind&#8221;) play a critical role in providing access to quality education. Marginalised groups can face a multitude of barriers to education and for systematic, or other, reasons cannot access state schools. Migrants for example may be excluded due to not having the required documentation, xenophobia or because they fear deportation. Indigenous groups, minority ethnic groups, religious minorities etc may have deep distrust of public systems (generally with good reason). In other context, and in fragile or conflict affected states in particular, at best it may take another generation before the state has the resources to fulfill its obligation to provide a quality education for all its citizens (with those most disadvantaged within such countries often the last to benefit from any improved services). And thats even if they were to receive the necessary supports. <\\/p>\\n<p>Private actors, that are not for profit, can play a critical role here in terms of supplementing state provision of education by for example:<br \\/>\\na. providing access to quality education that marginalised groups would not otherwise have access to<br \\/>\\nb. advocating and providing supports to improve state systems<br \\/>\\nc. when appropriate (and particularly when the government are genuinely intent) acting as a bridge between the the marginalised group and the state to build trust and understanding. They may also have established models of education provision that is relevant and effective for marginalised groups (particularly relevant for minority ethnic groups for example). . <\\/p>\\n<p>This of course does not mean that the state is not the duty bearer. It is and need to be supported. And while the private sector is certainly not the solution to achieving SDG 4, they do I think have a critical role to play.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/02\\/26\\/are-private-actors-the-solution-to-achieve-sdg-4\\/#comment-42456","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c5cad3a9ddea59ef1343f786794f1eb1?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c5cad3a9ddea59ef1343f786794f1eb1?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c5cad3a9ddea59ef1343f786794f1eb1?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c5cad3a9ddea59ef1343f786794f1eb1?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/42456"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/12694"}]}},{"id":42428,"post":12654,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"boammaaruri","author_url":"http:\\/\\/boammaaruri.wordpress.com","date":"2020-02-18T07:48:25","date_gmt":"2020-02-18T06:48:25","content":{"rendered":"<p>Do the interventions and programs take into account the differences in career interests between men and women?<br \\/>\\n1. A study, Men and Things, Women and People: A Meta-Analysis of Sex Differences in Interests, conducted the first comprehensive meta-analysis (examination of data from a number of independent studies of the same subject, in order to determine overall trends) of differences in occupational interests between men and women. The study concluded that:<br \\/>\\n\\u201d The present study, however, revealed substantial sex differences in vocational interests. The largest difference between men and women was found along the Things\\u2013People dimension, with men gravitated toward things-oriented careers and women gravitated toward people-oriented careers.\\u201d<br \\/>\\n2. One study looked at gender differences in interests across 53 countries and found the same pattern of gender differences in all countries. Countries that were more progressive and egalitarian did not have smaller gender differences in occupational interests. However, there is research that found the more gender egalitarian countries had larger differences in broad science interest between men and women while there were no differences in ability.<\\/p>\\n<p>Based on these facts should we expect that women will make the same career choices as men?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/02\\/11\\/how-are-donors-helping-to-end-the-gender-imbalance-in-science\\/#comment-42428","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/96059b2760e8c9152c001fde1937062a?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/96059b2760e8c9152c001fde1937062a?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/96059b2760e8c9152c001fde1937062a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/96059b2760e8c9152c001fde1937062a?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/42428"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/12654"}]}},{"id":42404,"post":12649,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Drug Rehab Orlando","author_url":"https:\\/\\/floridarehabexperts.com\\/drug-rehab-orlando","date":"2020-02-13T17:41:14","date_gmt":"2020-02-13T16:41:14","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thank you to Priyadarshani Joshi for such detailed research and awesome blog article! I definitely agree that it is hard for public schools to compete with private schools for various reasons. And the consequences of such a massive increase in the number of private schools are yet to be acknowledged by science. It is clear that the education landscape is changing and public schools are often left behind thus losing the battle for middle-and-higher class students. And it is clear that this situation is a major contributor to societal inequality, especially in countries where such problems are more prevalent.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2020\\/02\\/04\\/the-consequences-and-causes-of-private-school-growth-a-look-at-nepal\\/#comment-42404","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/813c21fd3ec6c10509c0e91486f92e8f?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/813c21fd3ec6c10509c0e91486f92e8f?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/813c21fd3ec6c10509c0e91486f92e8f?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/813c21fd3ec6c10509c0e91486f92e8f?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/42404"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/12649"}]}}]'

From view of this specially sensitive sicentific branch for optimal child self-development I&#8217;ve composed some improvements to existing UNESCO Concept of inclusiion in National School Systems which I think are necessary for better understanding how teachers affect different children in classrooms and cause various positive and negative effects to their development.<br \\/>\\nIn Slovenia progress toward inclussion actually didn&#8217;t happen yet although there are some trials from expert Institution for Education. Slovene Ministary of Education still tends toward exclusive education and graduate pressure on learners with more severe punnishing unwanted behaviors and conflicts in schools without real understanding what&#8217;s the cause of such unwanted behaviors and conflicts. The procedures for excluding learners are progressing through legislation to faster elimination of disturbing learners from educational process. So we can say that actual Slovene School System is highly exclusive in comparison to definition of inclusive &#8220;child-centred&#8221; eduction System (UNESCO 2005, p. 27) where &#8220;Seeing education from the inclucive lens implies a shift from seeing the child as a problem to seeing the education system as the problem that can be solved through inclusive approaches&#8221;. Inclusive shift in Slovenia will not happen if government will proceed with exclusive politics. Maybe a warm admonition to Slovene Government for right inclusive course could be welcome.<\\/p>\\n<p>                                                                      Introduction<\\/p>\\n<p>From aspect of UNESCO documents 1990-2020 as the platform for further development of Inclusive National School Systems (NSS), by my oppinion some improvements and upgrades could be added which could make NSS more &#8220;adapted&#8221; to children optimal self-development.<br \\/>\\nBasic platform concerning mentioned UNESCO documents for inclusive education is very well done, but nothing is so good that can&#8217;t be better. Child self-development can be understood more clear and teachers&#8217; behavioral effects in classrooms less problematic and harming through punnishing and rewarding of unwanted or wanted learners behaviors if understanding how basically Living beings function would be achieved. Psychology, Neurosicence and Cognitive  Science etc.  are not providing enough knowledge for full understanding how basically Living beings function. I&#8217;m proposing MSA approcah which could offer wider knowledge about curriculum organization and optimized realization of school programs in classrooms and thus optimized effects on child self-development.<br \\/>\\nPractice of classical productivity school programs and of course practice in classrooms proves that teacher behavior can lead into stress and psychical and\\/or psychosomatic problems of learners. More or less severe conflicts can take place in classrooms.  Learners are different by their biological (genetical) origins and  that can&#8217;t be changed. But learning environments and teacher&#8217;s actions can be improved to the level that can enable optimal development of biological (genetical) learners potentials and prevent negative developmental effects.<br \\/>\\nAlthough direction of inclusive changes provided by UNESCO are very good and promise critical changes in National School Systems i think that some optional changes should be done with special emphasize to :<br \\/>\\n1.\\tNew Glossary (UNESCO 1990 and UNESCO 2017) should introduce new terms and redifine some already established terms for better understanding of basic processing of school programs and consequently inclusive processing in classrooms.<br \\/>\\n2.\\tMSA aprrocah should be introduced for better clarification of Concepts, Policy statements, Structures and systems, Inclusive practices\\u2026<br \\/>\\n3.\\tNew fundamentals for functioning of human organism (and nervous system) should be used with improved understanding how teachers and learners basically function as Living beings so that understanding of basic relationship between teachers and learners can be cleared up including understanding of what kind of developmental effects different teacher&#8217;s behavior produce on different learners. <\\/p>\\n<p>                                                CONTENT OF PROPOSALS <\\/p>\\n<p>1.\\tBrief overview of actual problems in National School Systems and possible solutions for upgrading classical (integrative) school systems into inclusive.<br \\/>\\n2.\\tGlossary. Terminological improvement. Terms like learning, education, self-regulation, self-development, control, cooperation, conflicts\\u2026 could be defined in MSA manner.<br \\/>\\n3.\\tProblematic &#8220;Black box&#8221; teachers&#8217; approcah in classrooms with punnishments and rewards has to be replaced with improved MSA understanding how human (child) organism function and what kind of consequences can teachers&#8217; expect while applying different behaviors on learners.<br \\/>\\n4.\\tMSA aprrocah to curriculum understanding as the whole approach to creating optimal learning environments for more effective realization of educational plans in the direction of inclusion. Partial scientific disciplinary subjects or interdisciplinary understanding of curriculum has to be improved.<br \\/>\\n5.\\tHigher and long term goals in curriculum has to be directed into support of optimal self-development of individual learners and their potentials as basis for later optimal participation in inclusive society.<br \\/>\\n6.\\tConcrete solutions of slow introducing inclusive strategy into classical productivity NSS will be proposed.<br \\/>\\n7.\\tReplacement of factography in school curriculum with more usefull Life knowledge will be proposed.<\\/p>\\n<p>Brief explanation of basic points :<br \\/>\\n1.\\tShort Overwiev of actual problems in National School systems :<br \\/>\\n\\u2022\\tProductivity. Problem of &#8220;transffering&#8221; teachers knowledge on learners and efficiency of &#8220;school knowledge&#8221; in Life.<br \\/>\\n\\u2022\\tScientific disciplinary and interdisciplinary based curriculum offers too narrow approcah to understanding &#8220;Great picture of the World and Universe&#8221;.<br \\/>\\n\\u2022\\t&#8220;Integration&#8221; and problem of &#8220;special needs&#8221;<br \\/>\\n\\u2022\\tUse of external motivation (fear, punishment, rewards\\u2026as behavioristic theoretical background) instead of internal motivation.<br \\/>\\n\\u2022\\tNot adequate understanding of teachers &#8220;feedback&#8221; to learners while teachers are &#8220;transmitting&#8221; knowledge.<br \\/>\\n\\u2022\\tHealth problems of learners and other side effects of classical productivity schoolling. Beside too narrow intelectual developmental effects, also emotional and other psycho-physiological problems occur during educational process,<br \\/>\\n\\u2022\\tLack of &#8220;Life-skills&#8221; in curriculum or &#8220;Life skills&#8221; are defined too narrow.<br \\/>\\n\\u2022\\tLack of bases for Life-long learning. Life long learning needs MSA support with basic understanding what learning and educating are.<br \\/>\\n\\u2022\\tFactography in curriculum. Too much data and knowledge of no Life-use.<br \\/>\\n\\u2022\\tEtc.<\\/p>\\n<p>All points about actual problems in School Systems arround the World will be compared with inslusive concept of solving problems in School System.<\\/p>\\n<p>2.\\tGlossary (terminology) improvement :<br \\/>\\n\\u2022\\tSome basic terms and definitions already accounted in documents (1990, 2017) needs modification in accordance to MSA approcah, and should be redefined in the course of inclusive paradigm. Some new terms should be added for better understanding what is practically happening in schools and classrooms and how to progress toward inclusion.<br \\/>\\n\\u2022\\tOptimized Glossary could also enable better understanding and inclusive managment of school curriculum and better inclusive management in classrooms. <\\/p>\\n<p>3.\\tProblematic &#8220;Black box&#8221; approach in schools includes problem of understanding how Living beings (organisms) function and the way teacher affect children self-development. Central term is child self-development based on understanding how children psycho-physiologically and socialy function. MSA approach could enable more clear understanding how children (Living beings) function and thus offer possibility of producing more weihgty effects of teacher&#8217;s behavior on different children personalities. &#8220;Black box&#8221; approach can make damage to child self-development if teachers don&#8217;t understand what kind of effects are happening while acting on learners. Also new inclusive strategies for approaches to child optimal self-development will be proposed and teachers &#8220;White-box&#8221; effects will be presented.<\\/p>\\n<p>4.\\tMSA aprroach (&#8220;white-box&#8221;) to curriculum understanding should be added as it could offer more wide and comprehensive understanding of psychological and sociological processes in Human interactions and relations to physical environment. The final goal is to make new form of disciplinary and interdisciplinary approcah as transformation of existing scientific school subject based curriculum which is used in most National School Systems. <\\/p>\\n<p>5.\\tHigher and long term goals in curriculum should be integrated into global (wide) curriculum organization of knowledge which could integrate scientific disciplinary and interdisciplinary knowledge into more Life-sense use and offer new experience of Life-long learning. Also basic principles of Life-long learning on the basis of MSA approach will be presented. <\\/p>\\n<p>6.\\tInclusive strategies for improved organization of school curriculum will be presented that could enable slow introduction of &#8220;child-centred&#8221; principles into classical &#8220;teacher-centred&#8221; schooling in the course of differences that were defined in UNESCO 2005. We can say also that inclusive principles can be slowly introduced into productivity and segregating classical curriculum. <\\/p>\\n<p>7.\\tPossible measures and efforts will be introduced to lower factography (too much unnecessary data) in school programs and replace unnecessary informations with more effective program knowledge to account children needs and consider internal motivation of learners.<br \\/>\\nProductivity, categorization, segregation, stigmatization\\u2026 as basic &#8220;Black-box&#8221; problems in actual National School Systems arround the World make school &#8220;knowledge&#8221; mostly inefficient as learners soon forget such a knowledge. School knowledge mostly does not become part of their life experiences and means of achieving their life goals and inclusive social participation. Participation as the result of classical productive schooling is more likely to be competitive.<br \\/>\\nI hope that my oppinion which is based on my different educations and almost 40 years of work on different levels of schooling, numerous articles in Slovenia will help and thus contribution will be added to improvement of already good Guide for introducing inclusion and equity into National School Systems.<\\/p>\\n<p>Best wishes,<br \\/>\\nBoris Hartman<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/07\\/18\\/join-the-online-consultation-for-the-2020-gem-report-on-inclusion-and-education\\/#comment-41900","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c7fda7bb4e2d210b6eaa2f0e667e630e?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c7fda7bb4e2d210b6eaa2f0e667e630e?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c7fda7bb4e2d210b6eaa2f0e667e630e?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c7fda7bb4e2d210b6eaa2f0e667e630e?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/41900"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11838"}]}},{"id":41893,"post":12572,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"omar.badr@laposte.net","author_url":"","date":"2019-12-17T16:25:56","date_gmt":"2019-12-17T15:25:56","content":{"rendered":"<p>Bonjour, b'[{"id":41692,"post":4901,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Dorcas Mwake","author_url":"","date":"2019-11-16T09:18:14","date_gmt":"2019-11-16T08:18:14","content":{"rendered":"<p>what were the goals of the 1990 JOMTIEMS conference on education for All?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2014\\/08\\/22\\/the-jomtien-conference-in-1990-was-a-game-changer-for-education\\/#comment-41692","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/0c6a4b6aa16f093fbeb93e023cc3feb8?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/0c6a4b6aa16f093fbeb93e023cc3feb8?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/0c6a4b6aa16f093fbeb93e023cc3feb8?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/0c6a4b6aa16f093fbeb93e023cc3feb8?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/41692"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/4901"}]}},{"id":41671,"post":12481,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Sheldon Shaeffer","author_url":"","date":"2019-11-13T07:22:10","date_gmt":"2019-11-13T06:22:10","content":{"rendered":"<p>It&#8217;s just unfortunate that, again, the GEM report does not take into account the important role of early childhood care and education (ECCE) in shaping a child&#8217;s attitudes and values.  The entire text above makes no mention of the need to begin educating for tolerance, the celebration of diversity, empathy, &#8220;shared humanity&#8221;, etc., before children enter primary school &#8212; as if they come into school as an empty slate.   But we know that ECCE can shape values and attitudes in both negative and positive ways.  We therefore simply must pay more attention to the role of ECCE in promoting positive SEL.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2019\\/11\\/06\\/educating-for-the-social-the-emotional-and-the-sustainable\\/#comment-41671","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5e5ce2e317368639b0ffad5976db9141?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5e5ce2e317368639b0ffad5976db9141?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5e5ce2e317368639b0ffad5976db9141?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5e5ce2e317368639b0ffad5976db9141?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/41671"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/12481"}]}},{"id":41615,"post":11981,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"aafrin sheikh","author_url":"http:\\/\\/sciencecolleges228801853.wordpress.com","date":"2019-11-04T12:10:06","date_gmt":"2019-11-04T11:10:06","content":{"rendered":"<p>\\u2018A good education can change anyone. b'[{"id":41278,"post":12394,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Mariel","author_url":"","date":"2019-09-19T22:50:25","date_gmt":"2019-09-19T20:50:25","content":{"rendered":"<p>Hola, en Chubut Argentina la educaci\\u00f3n en general esta devastada, el pasado a\\u00f1o pr\\u00e1cticamente no dictaron clases y este a\\u00f1o ya llevamos muchisimos dias de paro docente. El da\\u00f1o en los chicos con un desarrollo normal es grave, y en los chicos con alg\\u00fan tipo de discapacidad (como mi hijo mas peque\\u00f1o) es terrible. Mi ni\\u00f1o tiene retraso de desarrollo, los dos a\\u00f1os de preescolar pr\\u00e1cticamente se comunico con se\\u00f1as, pero con las maestras maravillosas que le tocaron, los avances fueron impresionantes, por ley, lo obligan este a\\u00f1o a ingresar a escuela com\\u00fan en primer grado, la docente y directivas fueron desastrosas, lo maltrataron y al mes (con consenso de las terapistas) lo cambie a otra escuela, concurr\\u00eda con Acompa\\u00f1ante terap\\u00e9utica y la verdad solo trabajo socializacion, no le hicieron ni una carilla de actividad ludica, cero aprendizaje. Ahora no hay clases por paro, aparentemente hasta fin de a\\u00f1o. Necesito alternativas para educar en otro \\u00e1mbito que no sea la escuela convencional y no se donde, como, estoy muy preocupada. Men operate in gangs, groups, troops.  They make decisions together and get stuff done, even if they hardly know each other.  Gender division of labor is part of primate evolution.  Males rely on physically strong comrades, so they don&#8217;t want women in their midst. They also avoid female comrades to stop squabbles about sexuality.<br \\/>\\nThe result is that a male doctor, engineer, helicopter pilot has a circle of buddies supporting him, but a woman is all alone with everyone speaking against her. Each state has its norms and as one goes up to the North the nuances vary. This should be accepted and there should not be a&#8217; hurry&#8217; like those from the west would like to see. The norms that prevail are the results of changes that had been established and differ from the current changes that are taking place. These basic socio-cultural patterns have to be understood, respected and changes to be slowly interwoven into the prevailing cultural fabric. But changes should be consistent, pursued continuously and incorporated into the learning systems so that the future generations would be responsible for further changes that may be needed in the coming decades.<\\/p>\\n<p>I have served Afghanistan and Pakistan for over a decade and is somewhat conversant about the cultural norms. Perhaps teaching of English through phonics may be ideal for native speakers who have got a considerable vocabulary preschool (and, probably, for a few pupils whose homes speak English for social status) definitely not for those who are exposed to the learning and speaking of English only in school! The sequential learning of the alphabets and the whole word (from simple to complex) approach remains the best. It will be utterly confusing for such a child to grapple with the various sounds of the same letter unless such simple words are learnt holistic. If phonics must be very effective it should be taught only at grade one (after the traditional approach of teaching English at the pre-primary) as against teaching it at the pre-primary level which is the current practice in some private schools in Nigeria<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2014\\/10\\/22\\/nigeria-why-pupils-learning-english-and-mother-tongue-are-not-mutually-exclusive\\/#comment-39686","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/4dfd803d4e3add1cdd132395ccb74226?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/4dfd803d4e3add1cdd132395ccb74226?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/4dfd803d4e3add1cdd132395ccb74226?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/4dfd803d4e3add1cdd132395ccb74226?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/39686"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/5196"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/6614"}]}},{"id":39618,"post":12298,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Manzoor Ahmed","author_url":"","date":"2019-05-31T11:45:50","date_gmt":"2019-05-31T09:45:50","content":{"rendered":"<p>Not surprising, but not acceptable. The &#8220;stuffed suits&#8221; &#8211; diplomats and government officials- who represent the member states of United Nations, (note states, not the peoples of United Nations), are more concerned about making look good their own governments and countries, rather that identify the realities of the people and taking actions to solve the problems. The same is true of the EFA Steering Committee under the auspices of UNESCO, where also it&#8217;s the officials who hold sway rather than the real education constituencies. UNESCO and the Steering Committee have failed to articulate and give the right message to HLPF as much as the HLPF has not been ready to receive the message.<br \\/>\\nIn spite of occasional rhetoric about human capability, agency and action, SDG 4 is too often seen as mere one of 17 goals, rather than a central and cross-cutting concern that place people&#8217;s commitment, vision, capabilities and determination fostered through inclusive quality education and lifelong learning that make realization of all SDGs possible.<br \\/>\\nWe see parallel of what is happening at HLPF at the country level, where the centrality of human capability, empowerment and agency in advancing SDGs is often ignored. There is much talk and not enough action.<br \\/>\\nSome change in the text may happen when the incongruity of the first draft is pointed out, but will the attitude and mindset underlying the dementia will change? Not likely. The uphill struggle will have to continue. The real education community, including the activists, academics, civic groups, real proponents of people, need to come together and have their voices heard at national and international arenas. Side events at the UN may be one avenue. The agencies concerned about education &#8211; UNESCO, UNICEF, UNDP; other bodies such as Global Partnership for Education, Secretary general appointed Education Commission, the Global Campaign for Education, Education International, etc. need to engage in a concerted effort.<br \\/>\\nManzoor Ahmed<br \\/>\\nVice Chair, Campaign for Popular Education, Bangladesh<br \\/>\\nProfessor Emeritus, BRAC university<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2019\\/05\\/22\\/forgotten-or-ignored-education-gets-no-mention-in-the-draft-political-statement-for-the-un-high-level-political-forum\\/#comment-39618","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/beaa4cd8a3f3ed3efff47216cc358ac1?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/beaa4cd8a3f3ed3efff47216cc358ac1?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/beaa4cd8a3f3ed3efff47216cc358ac1?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/beaa4cd8a3f3ed3efff47216cc358ac1?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/39618"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/12298"}]}},{"id":39597,"post":10331,"parent":16188,"author":0,"author_name":"yri2018","author_url":"","date":"2019-05-28T06:41:18","date_gmt":"2019-05-28T04:41:18","content":{"rendered":"<p>The article, the piece, the comments are not only profound but very true. After all, these kids had seen traumatic experiences when they were in Myanmar. Can you even imagine what it must&#8217;ve been like for these kids to have seen their family, friends, neighbors, persecuted or terrorized all because they are Rohingya? More importantly, the fact that these kids who are in refugee camps don&#8217;t get the ability to live a normal life, since these camps often are lacking in resources. By setting up places in refugee camps dedicated towards education, children in these camps would have a chance to live a normal life by going to school, playing games, and having people listen to their problems. While the article is right, these kids and their teachers do have to face problems with stress, considering the environment they are in, it is vital that refugee children get the chance to go to school to get a sense of normalcy in their lives.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2019\\/03\\/04\\/teachers-multitask-in-bangladeshs-coxs-bazar-camps-for-rohingya-refugees\\/#comment-39401","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e5c2b622cc21f19adcc05c8fa6fc42b9?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e5c2b622cc21f19adcc05c8fa6fc42b9?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e5c2b622cc21f19adcc05c8fa6fc42b9?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e5c2b622cc21f19adcc05c8fa6fc42b9?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/39401"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/12224"}]}},{"id":39396,"post":12179,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Kayomin","author_url":"https:\\/\\/www.npti.edu\\/","date":"2019-05-10T12:50:32","date_gmt":"2019-05-10T10:50:32","content":{"rendered":"<p>Nice blog to go through! In the market for assessments producers are competing not directly, but by differentiating and trying to sell a different product.  No one appears to be competing on how to take an existing assessment and just produce it better and\\/or more cheaply (or preferably, both).  Unless we correct for that, we will continue to see a proliferation of different assessments that do something either completely or slightly different, adding to the asymmetries in the market place (more stuff produced non-transparently means consumers and third party payers will stay confused about what products to From the many years of practice teaching this topic, it was concluded that every adult can and should contribute to HIV prevention.<br \\/>\\nWe must help the youth! Absolutely everyone can do it, regardless of financial condition. For example, even if a person simply shares this information that in international practice there are specific lessons on HIV \\/ AIDS prevention for high school students. The migrant women have to endure a lot of daunting pressure, struggle to survive in the new society. They are vulnerable, trying to live and role model ethos to their children and pursue jobs that they hold with values. Unfortunately, they are undervalued and exploited for their skills with no rewards of position or remuneration. Often they have to settle for much less entry-level and service industry jobs.<br \\/>\\nTheir struggles are real, a relentless cause of stress, trauma, and humiliation. In some cases, some women even opt to take up two or more jobs to make ends meet and thus sacrificing their own wellbeing. In some cases, they opt to become beneficiaries of the state as it seems the only best option. Honing one&#8217;s Heritage Language is important as it stimulates brain activity rather than having the dominant language (e.g. English) dictate modes of interpretation. Hence, one&#8217;s heritage language also becomes one&#8217;s cultural capital to build one&#8217;s own academic lineage as education which is worthwhile learning in my book&#8211;&gt;It&#8217;s only natural that the love of life long learning would begin with loving one&#8217;s self and the heritage you&#8217;ve been blessed to inherit as a unique individual brought in this world with the human right to learn in one&#8217;s own customary form of conscience being the language and the cultural attributes and values that shape its modes of communication for language is but a communication tool spelling out our respective realities.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/02\\/21\\/children-taught-in-their-mother-language-are-more-likely-to-develop-literacy-skills\\/#comment-31175","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ce6d27d71c76f21f5b992e970ca020f7?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ce6d27d71c76f21f5b992e970ca020f7?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ce6d27d71c76f21f5b992e970ca020f7?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ce6d27d71c76f21f5b992e970ca020f7?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/31175"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11519"}]}},{"id":30664,"post":12201,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Stephen J. Smith","author_url":"","date":"2019-02-22T05:26:46","date_gmt":"2019-02-22T04:26:46","content":{"rendered":"<p>What about languages which might best be described themselves as &#8216;indigenous&#8217;&#8211;languages which have developed in a particular area, within a particular set of social, cultural and temporal circumstances&#8211;and thus may be best described as &#8216;indigenous&#8217; to that area, region and people? I&#8217;m thinking of &#8216;hybrid&#8217; languages (which some may describe as patois, creole, pidgin) (St Lucian Kweyol, Gibraltarian Llanito, for example) or even dialects (Jerriais on the island of Jersey, Channel Islands, amongst many, many others, for example). These languages are often accorded a lesser status and are often overlooked when it comes to being taught as subjects at school or used as a &#8216;legitimate&#8217; medium of instruction in favour of English, French, Spanish, Chinese Putonghua, etc. They need to be given increased status within education systems as they are an important part of the social, cultural, environmental fabric of any group of people or society.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2019\\/02\\/21\\/respecting-indigenous-languages-in-education-is-core-to-reducing-exclusion\\/#comment-30664","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a164776108ec62589682002bb73ef9f0?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a164776108ec62589682002bb73ef9f0?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a164776108ec62589682002bb73ef9f0?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a164776108ec62589682002bb73ef9f0?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/30664"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/12201"}]}},{"id":30571,"post":4499,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Emongaise This means that at every grade level K-12 boys are competing with girls for grades who are at a minimum three years more mature than they are. This is a huge advantage yet it is seldom ever mentioned when the gender gap in education is being discussed. Why? Its inconceivable that educators are not aware of this maturity advantage girls have over boys. So the best and most likely reason is the powers that be like the status quo. <\\/p>\\n<p>Who would want girls to out perform boys?  certainly the women&#8217;s movement. How do we know. Because every time girls are behind women talk about equality and parity. But as soon as women get ahead all talk about parity ceases and women shift their attention to another area women are behind in and resume their cry for parity. In this manner they hope to put women on top because women feel justified in doing so because they believe they are superior to the male and<br \\/>\\ntherefor should rule the world.<br \\/>\\nGetting same for migrant children. In india also migration within the country is large scale. This migration is of two types.Migration within the state and between states. Intrastate migration poses an additional problem of language as different states speak different languages and many have different scripts as well..<br \\/>\\nBut as a worker at grass root level for last thirty years I can say that having different languages is relatively a minor problem. Major problem lies with teachers\\u2019 attitude, insistence on documents before giving admisdion, ignorance of parents regarding the rules and regulations of school admisdion, lack of pattern in migration such as a particular season, place etc.. lack of availability of easily accessible schools in cities, unsafe traffic conditions in cities and lack of provision of school transport under the \\u2018free schooling benefits given to all children under 14 by the RIGHT TO FREE AND COMPULSORY EDUCATION law enacted in 2009 ..<br \\/>\\n One would expect the improved conditions and easy access to schooling as a result of this act.. in reality it has a counter effect as government has stopped alll aid for non-formal, out of school education to \\u2018out of school \\u2018 children as leagally there should be no \\u2018out of school \\u2018 child any more as all children must be given admission in school without any documents, throughout the year, in age appropriate grades.. The schools use this clause of age appropriate admissions for insisting on age certificate at the time of admission.. Some Givernments have made provision of \\u2018 Education guarantee cards\\u2019 to facilitate admisdion from one school to another but many teachers are not even aware of this facility and those who are consider it as additional work and avoid preparing the document. Many NGOs who used to give non formal education to children before the enactment of law have stopped to do so because government has stopped giving the funds.. the policies are unsuitable to the conditions in which the children live and as a result many children ,children of parents working in different industries such as construction, brick kiln, stone quarries, sugar cane cutters etc.. are There are many Conservatives who believe it is an earned privilege, which is why they have been emphasizing home schooling, vouchers, charter schools et al\\u2014to create an educational system for students who are sufficiently advantaged or who have earned admittance to programs by their demonstrated ability. This leaves the most economically and socially disadvantaged students in dire educational situations\\u2014failing situations\\u2014and their are Republican state legislators in our country who believe we should stop \\u201cwasting taxpayer dollars\\u201d on these failing schools. American Conservatives, the vast majority of whom claim to be Christians, will continue to turn their backs on the poor, and there is nothing to stop them legally. Sdiri","author_url":"","date":"2018-10-23T13:41:28","date_gmt":"2018-10-23T11:41:28","content":{"rendered":"<p>I think  SDG Indicator 4.1.1 was flawed from the beginning. Writing should be added as it represents a core component in literacy development. As for the draft descriptors, I think they are too broad. They are no vigorous indeed. It is very important to raise the awareness of countries, especially underdeveloped countries, of some fundamental concerns. 1- What should students read &#8211; Literary vs Informational texts? 2- How much should students read &#8211; Simple sentences or stories? How should the reading continuum proceed in terms of quantity, range, and complexity? 4- How much time should be allocated to teaching reading? Daily? Weekly? Yearly?<br \\/>\\nWhen I look at the General Descriptor for Reading- Grade 2, I easily observe that it is not vigorous. It is not precise. It could be interpreted in different ways. I think to make sure that the whole world develops in the upcoming years,especially the underdeveloped countries, it is essential to design vigorous and clear frameworks which have the potential to disseminate such invaluable knowledge.<br \\/>\\nI guess that stating that &#8220;Students read and comprehend most of the written words in an instrument given to them, particularly familiar ones, and extract explicit information from sentences&#8221; is neithor vigorous nor clear from a curriculum designer. <\\/p>\\n<p>Best Thus, the more relevant challenge today is related with education for all. Education for rich but for poor people, too. In other words, we are talking about elites. High quality and recognition institutions on one hand, and the rest on the other one. Inclusion should be associated with universalization of high quality. That means no elite institutions. No elites of teachers. No elites of students. No elites of citizens. Inclusion means democracy. How is the effect of rankings on elitization? How bad is the effect of rankings on inclusiveness? To study the impact of rankings on inclusiveness could be a matter of fact. In principle, rankings are a gigant invisible barrier for inclusion and equity.<br \\/>\\n\\u201cLeave no one behind\\u201d means all at the very front. Equal opportunities for everybody.<br \\/>\\nA simple example of social stratification consolidated by the higher education system can be found in a Colombian familiar situation: An Industrial Engineer from the top elite private university is prepared to be the manager of the company, the Industrial Engineer from the top elite public university is educated to be the manager of the plant, and the Industrial Enginner from the less reputation university is prepared to be the plant engineer.<br \\/>\\nOn the other hand, rankings are pushing policies in many countries, to look for the positioning of &#8220;at least&#8221; one o their universities in the Shanghai Ranking (that means economic resources extremely concentrated on very few institutions, usually at the capital cities). Efforts are concentrated on one or only few universities, increase elitization quickly and exclusion increase, too.<br \\/>\\nConsequently, I suggest to evaluate the impact on equity and inclusion generated by the rankings globally promoted with intensity along the current century.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/07\\/18\\/join-the-online-consultation-for-the-2020-gem-report-on-inclusion-and-education\\/#comment-22284","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/2774849f3feb5c02c269c492bd3d6488?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/2774849f3feb5c02c269c492bd3d6488?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/2774849f3feb5c02c269c492bd3d6488?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/2774849f3feb5c02c269c492bd3d6488?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/22284"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11838"}]}},{"id":22273,"post":9489,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Citizenship in India","author_url":"https:\\/\\/www.deshapnayen.org\\/","date":"2018-08-27T08:25:03","date_gmt":"2018-08-27T06:25:03","content":{"rendered":"<p>Great post! b'[{"id":21783,"post":11765,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Maria L Siu Munro","author_url":"https:\\/\\/www.armandoaid.org\\/","date":"2018-07-03T12:05:55","date_gmt":"2018-07-03T10:05:55","content":{"rendered":"<p>Our organisation ArmandoAid has been providing educational programmes to refugees stranded in camps in Greece. From June 2016 until November 2017, we founded and ran a school at Oinofyta camp. We counted with 5 classrooms and an average of 200 students.<br \\/>\\nIt was so great to see the children and adults in this harsh camp environment have a respite that our school provided. We taught children in the mornings and adults in the afternoon, five days per week.<br \\/>\\nWe taught English to many children and adults. We are so proud of their achievements and our volunteers&#8217; dedicated work. Please check us out.<br \\/>\\nSadly, in November 2017, the Greek government decided to close the camp. Our school had to close too.<br \\/>\\nWe are now, preparing the deployment of IT classrooms in suitcases and the provision of an e-curriculum to various educational projects along the European refugee route. We will be starting a pilot programme where three boxes will be deployed. <\\/p>\\n<p>Please check us out!<br \\/>\\n<a href=\\"https:\\/\\/www.armandoaid.org\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">https:\\/\\/www.armandoaid.org\\/<\\/a><br \\/>\\n<a href=\\"https:\\/\\/www.facebook.com\\/ArmandoAid\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">https:\\/\\/www.facebook.com\\/ArmandoAid\\/<\\/a><br \\/>\\nFollow us on instragram too:  <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/www.instagram.com\\/armando_aid\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">https:\\/\\/www.instagram.com\\/armando_aid\\/<\\/a><\\/p>\\n<p>We are also planning to relocate our school in another camp and are raising funds for it. We run entirely through private donations and are a small organisation passionate about empowering refugee communities.<\\/p>\\n<p>We have so many stories to tell and one of them is about an 18 years old student from Afghanistan.<br \\/>\\nHe spent most of his childhood in Iran where he was denied an education.<br \\/>\\nWhen he arrived in Moria camp on Lesvos, he met his first English teacher. The camp&#8217;s authorities would not let, apart from a couple of official NGO&#8217;s anybody else in the camp.<br \\/>\\nSo, our student received his first English lessons through a fence for a 3 months.<br \\/>\\nHe arrived at our school with fairly good English and volunteered to be a teacher&#8217;s assistant. He also received English and Biology lessons with us in the afternoons.<br \\/>\\nRight now, he is in Switzerland and for the first time in his life, he will be seating his first formal exams and taking IGCSE English this summer.<br \\/>\\nThis bright young man, learned to speak fluently, two completely different languages, English and Greek.<br \\/>\\nHis English is enviable and soon he will be able to join University courses in Switzerland. We wish him great success.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/06\\/20\\/are-you-the-voice-of-refugees-on-education\\/#comment-21783","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/002c80a74612df0c1df0b195ab75cee1?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/002c80a74612df0c1df0b195ab75cee1?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/002c80a74612df0c1df0b195ab75cee1?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/002c80a74612df0c1df0b195ab75cee1?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/21783"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11765"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=21783"}]}},{"id":21750,"post":11746,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Pre Kg Admission","author_url":"http:\\/\\/www.chennaipublicschool.com\\/","date":"2018-06-29T15:25:12","date_gmt":"2018-06-29T13:25:12","content":{"rendered":"<p>No objection to this article. the last two years, Europe experienced the largest number of arrivals of refugees and<br \\/>\\nmigrants since the end of the Second World War. The Syrian crisis played an important part<br \\/>\\nin generating this record number, as did conflicts, instability and poverty in many parts of the<br \\/>\\nworld. Migration, asylum and border management systems were put under huge pressure. The<br \\/>\\nUnion and its Member States were not sufficiently prepared to respond effectively. The scale<br \\/>\\nof the crisis had a powerful impact across the EU. The math skills do not drop naturally because of age.  They may be forgotten, however, due to disuse. The graph showing numeracy results by education level and age may imply: (a) the effects of overlearning for those who spent 6 more years doing math; (b) prior differences in SES and math ability that resulted in secondary ed. enrollment; (c) subsequent engagement in professions needing math. They seem to fail to recognize the fact that increasingly people are spending most of their time on Mobile technologies than computers  hence information sharing using M technologies is much more conivinient than the use of computers to most people. Schools in rural areas are more venurables to abuse as reporting mechanisms for accountability, transparency and service delivery satisfaction are very minimal . Teachers absenteeism is still high, projects take more time to be completed or abandoned at all, some central governments have used rural schools as fertile places to grow ghost workers, ghost projects, teaching and learning materials are delivered to schools on paper but in reality nothing may have been delivered to these schools. This limited flow of information is negatively impacting on the quality of education.<br \\/>\\nShould government allow students and teachers engage in M learning, schools will not only improve in administrative functions but more importantly also in the meeting learning outcomes as they will be exposed to vast information the internet has to offer from Pinochet regime this inequitable educational system is put forward by World Bank and OECD as high performing and best practice, shame on this ultraliberal organizations !<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/03\\/30\\/the-chilean-students-are-back-for-more-protesting-for-education-equality\\/#comment-20853","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8d059dcc1ddee9a5ac81a5f3e5fbb3a8?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8d059dcc1ddee9a5ac81a5f3e5fbb3a8?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8d059dcc1ddee9a5ac81a5f3e5fbb3a8?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8d059dcc1ddee9a5ac81a5f3e5fbb3a8?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/20853"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11632"}]}},{"id":20838,"post":11620,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Dave Johnson","author_url":"","date":"2018-03-30T08:30:09","date_gmt":"2018-03-30T06:30:09","content":{"rendered":"<p>Where are the studies to support better outcomes with compulsory education from an earlier age? Where is the evidence to show that this is founded on good, solid research? I am a teacher and a majority of research studies that I have read show better outcomes with a later start. Notwithstanding that, I agree with a legal right to education from age 3, but I do not agree that it should be compulsory. France already has class sizes much larger than the average for this age group and has a very low investment per child. When will the changes take effect? How will they recruit and train 1000 additional teachers in time? It sounds to me like they may just implement \\u201con the job\\u201d training\\u2026i.e. put untrained people in classrooms. Who will support them, when the existing teachers are already stretched teaching big classes? There is some wording in these articles that suggests that it won\\u2019t be just play and that there could be plans for some sort of structured early reading\\/writing education. The neurobiology suggests that for the average child of this age, this may not be a good idea. For me, it is clear that this is not a decision taking on the grounds that this will result on better educational outcomes. My daughter already attends a French \\u201cmaternelle\\u201d class in France. There are 25 kids in her class \\u2013 mostly aged 4. There is one teacher and one assistant, who spends most of her time sticking notifications in the kids\\u2019 \\u201ccahiers\\u201d. There is a total lack of technology and investment to support these staff, We bring our daughter home for lunch as there are 60 kids who use the canteen, with just 2 assistants to supervise. In my opinion, the system isn\\u2019t working very well as it stands and it needs investment, rather than changes like this that do not seem to be based on any real evidence of better outcomes. There is a big difference between a legal right to education for every child from a certain age and making education compulsory from a certain age. Yes\\u2026.a small number of kids in the French overseas territories will possibly benefit, but what will be the effects for parents like us who want to travel for a month or two with our kids while they are young?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/03\\/28\\/more-than-just-symbolism-france-makes-pre-primary-school-compulsory-from-age-3\\/#comment-20838","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3f3512da8a27e3e6b6b04fdd604eb1ce?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3f3512da8a27e3e6b6b04fdd604eb1ce?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3f3512da8a27e3e6b6b04fdd604eb1ce?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3f3512da8a27e3e6b6b04fdd604eb1ce?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/20838"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11620"}]}},{"id":20828,"post":11616,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Gabrielle Wills","author_url":"https:\\/\\/plus.google.com\\/107982836809707889254","date":"2018-03-29T08:11:24","date_gmt":"2018-03-29T06:11:24","content":{"rendered":"<p>But there are also unintended consequences of movements to foster &#8220;accountability&#8221;&#8230;.South Africa\\u2019s \\u2018Fees must fall\\u2019 protests ultimately led to political commitments to provide free higher education for the majority of students. However, I find a great part of it unecessary negative downplaying such a decision. Indeed, by announcing to make education compulsory from age 3 France will at the same time make pre-primary education compulsory, that&#8217;s well beyond what the Education 2030 Framework for Action is asking countries to do (at least one year). In the context where pre-primary education is not compulsory in the majority of European countries even though there is a legal entitlment to it, having a developed country like France that is taking such a decision  should be greeted more. <\\/p>\\n<p>Yes, the decision is definively symbolic since most children of 3 years are enrolled already at this level on average. But, still it is an indication of the attention paid by Mr. Macron to education as said in the blog, but also to SDG Education 2030 agenda, a point that should have been stress as well. <\\/p>\\n<p>May be France is not making that much for pre-primary education compared with some EU countries. But, let&#8217;s wait and see. The new decision will bring with it more money and Investment in pre-primary education.
