It is essential to develop local publishing capacity, as well as developing local linguistic capacity to use appropriate languages for materials in learners&#8217; mother tongues and\\/or bilingually. Two-sided bilingual books (where the content is in the dominant language on one side and the local language on the other side) can be cost-effective if produced locally and if local language teams work together; such bilingual materials help teachers to promote biliteracy, and help students and parents to see how both languages can be used to express academic content.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/02\\/23\\/books-are-essential-to-solving-the-global-learning-crisis\\/#comment-20207","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5e748c21e97a64d7f2eba3fe2a7c39e7?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5e748c21e97a64d7f2eba3fe2a7c39e7?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5e748c21e97a64d7f2eba3fe2a7c39e7?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5e748c21e97a64d7f2eba3fe2a7c39e7?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/20207"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11549"}]}},{"id":20205,"post":11549,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"H. Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2018-02-23T13:06:01","date_gmt":"2018-02-23T12:06:01","content":{"rendered":"<p>The World Bank and GPE have been talking about books at reasonable prices for decades.  Somehow the various parts don&#8217;t come together.  In Africa the textbooks are extremely expensive and beyond the reach of common people.  Giving them for free has had problems.  The private sector is also very astute and set up to absorb all the money that donors put for books.  One way unfortunately has been to buy the complicity of Ministry of Education staff.<br \\/>\\nAt any rate, not any book will do.  Basic textbooks need to meet critical size and spacing parameters and to have lots of text for practice and increasing reading speed.  Math textbooks similarly need many exercises and solved examples.  Often financial restrictions mean that textbooks are too short.<br \\/>\\nThe Global Book Alliance has been around in some form since 2012.  What has it accomplished thus far?  How many books have been delivered in which countries and at which prices?  It would be important to write a blog on that.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/02\\/23\\/books-are-essential-to-solving-the-global-learning-crisis\\/#comment-20205","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/20205"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11549"}]}},{"id":20193,"post":11519,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Julianna Heard","author_url":"","date":"2018-02-22T22:29:31","date_gmt":"2018-02-22T21:29:31","content":{"rendered":"<p>Although some of the evidence in the article may be slightly confusing and seem slightly fuzzy towards proving the hypothesis that the mother tongue is &#8216;better&#8217;, I find that this article is important in bringing up awareness of the importance of speaking many languages rather then conforming everyone in the world to speak less and less. Language is a huge part of life and identity and by attending schools that teach in mother tongue it is a good way to preserve languages and voices and identity of people around the world.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/02\\/21\\/children-taught-in-their-mother-language-are-more-likely-to-develop-literacy-skills\\/#comment-20193","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8ab0d8792559c28dc668224139aa00ed?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8ab0d8792559c28dc668224139aa00ed?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8ab0d8792559c28dc668224139aa00ed?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8ab0d8792559c28dc668224139aa00ed?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/20193"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11519"}]}},{"id":20182,"post":11519,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"H. Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2018-02-21T23:10:29","date_gmt":"2018-02-21T22:10:29","content":{"rendered":"<p>Great findings, but variables are confused.  For comprehension speed and accuracy of content (such as social studies), &#8220;mother tongue&#8221; may be superior.  But to develop reading automaticity, orthographic simplicity initially matters more than comprehension.<\\/p>\\n<p>Local languages are almost always consistently spelled, because they were recently written.  By contrast, formerly colonial languages were written centuries ago and they tend to have older and complex spelling.  Also local languages may use simpler writing systems. <\\/p>\\n<p>The confusion is evident in the graph shown on Ethiopia.  Amharic and related languages are written in a syllabic script that has various complexities and takes 1-2 years to master.  African-derived languages (e.g. Oromo) are written in the Roman script that requires maybe 25% of the time, about 4 months, to teach decently.  The comparison is between mice and dogs.<\\/p>\\n<p>And what if the &#8220;mother tongue&#8221; is pidgin English or Creole French?  Should the students be doomed for years to learn standard English spelling that does not correspond well to what they hear?  The balance of the evidence suggests that they should learn reading in a consistently spelled local language instead.<\\/p>\\n<p>So, the finding does not support the hypothesis that &#8220;mother tongue&#8221; is better for literacy.  Other variables matter more.  It&#8217;s useful to understand how reading and language are learned in the brain in order to guide the policy dialogue better.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/02\\/21\\/children-taught-in-their-mother-language-are-more-likely-to-develop-literacy-skills\\/#comment-20182","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/20182"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11519"}]}},{"id":20177,"post":2581,"parent":2971,"author":0,"author_name":"Reena George","author_url":"https:\\/\\/plus.google.com\\/103970792072918022969","date":"2018-02-21T14:02:16","date_gmt":"2018-02-21T13:02:16","content":{"rendered":"<p>I believe that is also true too. With this data we can see how we can change this world and make it a better place<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2012\\/11\\/09\\/the-bottom-ten-countries-for-female-education\\/#comment-20177","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be81a0bf32e76052d73e51f661e0bc12?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be81a0bf32e76052d73e51f661e0bc12?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be81a0bf32e76052d73e51f661e0bc12?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be81a0bf32e76052d73e51f661e0bc12?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/20177"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/2581"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/2971"}]}},{"id":20168,"post":11514,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Christine","author_url":"","date":"2018-02-20T15:36:07","date_gmt":"2018-02-20T14:36:07","content":{"rendered":"<p>This is a good report highlighting the progress made with Comprehensive Sexuality Education. We look forward to collaborating with stakeholders in ensuring young people are reached with CSE and ensuring an AIDS free generation by aiming to reach the UNAIDS 909090 and the ESA targets.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/02\\/19\\/comprehensive-sexuality-education-and-the-global-vision-for-the-education-agenda\\/#comment-20168","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/42d837fc35ff3c48e503bcdad88f714d?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/42d837fc35ff3c48e503bcdad88f714d?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/42d837fc35ff3c48e503bcdad88f714d?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/42d837fc35ff3c48e503bcdad88f714d?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/20168"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11514"}]}},{"id":20077,"post":10855,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Padmaja","author_url":"https:\\/\\/www.doorstepschool.org\\/pune","date":"2018-02-17T08:36:12","date_gmt":"2018-02-17T07:36:12","content":{"rendered":"<p>\\u2018Our greatest natural resource is the minds of our children\\u2019 Mr. Walt Disney quotes. This famous quote beautifully ignites our thought process to understand the importance of well nurtured minds in development. As included in UNs Sustainable Development Goals, obtaining a quality education is the foundation to improving people\\u2019s lives and sustainable development. The Society for Door Step Schools (DSS) believes in this vision and has been working on it since its inception in 1988-89 when it was founded in Mumbai, India by Mrs. Rajani Paranjpe and her ex-student Mrs. Bina Lashkari and expanded to Pune, India in 1993. It has been working with the aim of addressing illiteracy among the marginalized sections of society; by bringing education to the &#8220;Door Step&#8221; of these underprivileged children.<\\/p>\\n<p>Pune, a city with ample of job opportunities is considered as Oxford of the East due to its quality of education. Even in this educational hub of India, education of underprivileged children possesses a challenge. Only a small percentage of the children of migrant laborers attend school, the rest remain out of school because of various reasons &#8211; they need to stay at home to take care of the younger siblings, or schools are inaccessible or simply they can\\u2019t cope up with schools having stayed out of school for prolonged time. For addressing this issue DSS came up with an initiative called Every Child Counts \\u2013 A Citizens\\u2019 Campaign (ECC).<br \\/>\\nThe ECC model has unique methodology to identify out-of-school children and enroll them to school.<br \\/>\\nIn the first stage, mapping of the area is done, after mapping a systematic survey is conducted of each and every street in the city to cover Housing and road Construction sites, to identify temporary settlements, semi-permanent settlements to determine the presence of labor camps and children who are in the 6-7-year age group. Considering the vast population, ECC had a way out to include citizens in process. Involving citizens helped in reaching out to masses within less time. Citizen would survey the locality, identify out of school children between the age of 6 and 10, and collect the details. Given that the citizen volunteers had minimal experience in such surveys, the DSS teams help and monitor the survey. The next step is to map each site to the nearest school based on the list of schools, map location of the school obtained from school authorities.  Once children are located, parents are approached and counseled on the importance of education, informed of the nearest school and the process of getting the children enrolled into schools. Wherever children and parents have no exposure to the concept of schooling, the team starts &#8220;Preparatory camps&#8221; for the children. A temporary classroom is setup in a tent or a room provided by builders and children are introduced to the idea of schooling and learning. The children are taught basic hygiene and get used to sitting for a longer period, say their names, a few important phrases in the local language, making it easier for them to adjust in a bigger school with many children.<br \\/>\\nIn second stage, Enrollment and support: Sites with children identified during the survey phase are revisited before the start of the enrollment period and parents encouraged to visit the schools by themselves to enroll their children. A simple identity card called &#8220;My Card&#8221;, carrying details of the children and the name of the school is given to the parents to help them provide the required details to the school.<br \\/>\\nIn third stage Follow up: During this stage the campaign team with the help of volunteers monitors the progress of children by visiting sites and schools. Parents are educated on their role in getting involved in parent meetings and schooling. Other barriers to children attending school regularly such as lack of parental awareness, particularly among migrant parents, lack of safe transportation to school and school attitudes towards migrant children are addressed.<br \\/>\\nAs a result of structured efforts across programs in DSS, we can see that in 2012-13, 4270 children were identified and out of that 1757 (41.14%) children were enrolled to schools in Pune. This number increases significantly over the period and in last year i.e. 2016-2017 total 7185 children were identified, out of which 4221 (58.75%) children were enrolled to school. Since 2012-13, ECC has identified 30000+ out-of-school children and enrolled 16000+ children into mainstream schools in and around Pune city. The program is still continuing and has already enrolled 1500+ children in the current year. The same model is successfully implemented in IT Hub of India Bangalore with great results. Success of this model in city like Pune is a good example of high potential held by the model. ECC is contributing continuously towards UN\\u2019s goal and wish this model could be an inspiration for many like-minded people.<br \\/>\\n<a href=\\"http:\\/\\/www.doorstepschool.org\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">http:\\/\\/www.doorstepschool.org<\\/a><\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/09\\/25\\/two-years-down-13-to-go-checking-in-on-our-progress-towards-the-sdgs\\/#comment-20077","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ee5c977bbe2e1eb0c757af6e1e086a22?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ee5c977bbe2e1eb0c757af6e1e086a22?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ee5c977bbe2e1eb0c757af6e1e086a22?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ee5c977bbe2e1eb0c757af6e1e086a22?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/20077"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10855"}]}}]'

b'[{"id":19998,"post":11497,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Teopista Birungi Mayanja","author_url":"","date":"2018-02-12T17:01:53","date_gmt":"2018-02-12T16:01:53","content":{"rendered":"<p>Civil Society in Africa should now focus on addressing the paradox of &#8221; Africa, the richest continent on the planet, with the youngest population living in the worst human conditions&#8221;.  Do we have the right strategies???<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/02\\/09\\/what-next-for-the-global-partnership-for-education-after-a-transformative-replenishment\\/#comment-19998","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3a496f978e09e25016ce0263b6e6cb92?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3a496f978e09e25016ce0263b6e6cb92?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3a496f978e09e25016ce0263b6e6cb92?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3a496f978e09e25016ce0263b6e6cb92?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/19998"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11497"}]}},{"id":19986,"post":7303,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"arpitaa outlaw","author_url":"http:\\/\\/b231889421.wordpress.com","date":"2018-02-12T07:40:11","date_gmt":"2018-02-12T06:40:11","content":{"rendered":"<p>Indeed it is a great effort to tackle the education crisis. As I also seen a stats which shown that students from European Countries are less interested in Us Degree Programs.<br \\/>\\n<a href=\\"https:\\/\\/www.avriq.com\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow\\">avriq<\\/a><\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/04\\/05\\/last-chance-to-join-the-call-for-the-new-education-crisis-platform-to-be-adequately-and-sustainably-financed\\/#comment-19986","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/0fdf10c882546eeedb1658b496959816?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/0fdf10c882546eeedb1658b496959816?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/0fdf10c882546eeedb1658b496959816?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/0fdf10c882546eeedb1658b496959816?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/19986"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7303"}]}},{"id":19974,"post":11497,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Steven Klees","author_url":"","date":"2018-02-09T16:31:24","date_gmt":"2018-02-09T15:31:24","content":{"rendered":"<p>While David Archer&#8217;s points are well-taken, what needs to be front and center is that the $2 billion spread over a few years &#8212;  which GPE had to beg for &#8212; falls far short of the additional $39 billion each year that UNESCO estimates is needed from the international community to make SDG4 a reality.  To me, this is more cause for shame than celebration.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2018\\/02\\/09\\/what-next-for-the-global-partnership-for-education-after-a-transformative-replenishment\\/#comment-19974","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/4d1e91ff4d13dee3c05b2ef7efac1b5c?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/4d1e91ff4d13dee3c05b2ef7efac1b5c?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/4d1e91ff4d13dee3c05b2ef7efac1b5c?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/4d1e91ff4d13dee3c05b2ef7efac1b5c?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/19974"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11497"}]}},{"id":19973,"post":11497,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Alberto Begue","author_url":"","date":"2018-02-09T16:25:58","date_gmt":"2018-02-09T15:25:58","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thank you, David for this interesting approach, especially on the BUTs. I would like to bring to your attention a curious change that I have recently noticed. For many years, we have considered 20% as the benchmark to be reached by governments on their national education budgets. For example, the GPE Results Framework includes that target. The Education 2030 Framework for Action mentioned the Addis Ababa Action Agenda (2015), where the target was &#8220;at least 15% to 20%&#8221;. However, I noticed that the GME (page 23) reduced the target to &#8220;&#8230; minimum 15% threshold proposed in the Education 2030 Framework for Action (GPE, 2016a).&#8221; This GPE reference is the Policy Brief on &#8220;GPE\\u00b4s engagement on domestic financing for education&#8221;, where it is said, &#8220;Several countries are still far from reaching the internationally-set minimum education expenditure benchmark of 15 percent&#8221; (page 13). Therefore, there is a change from considering a benchmark of the 20%, to a target of 15% to 20%, and now a threshold of 15%. I don\\u00b4t know where this change is coming from, but I think this is a dangerous indication, as some governments could reduce their education budget following this new benchmark. I would like to know what do you think about this. latham","author_url":"","date":"2018-01-15T09:40:32","date_gmt":"2018-01-15T08:40:32","content":{"rendered":"<p>It seems so obvious &#8211; ask the customer what she or he wants in order to drive improvement but in the education sector we have barely got to the stage where we gingerly ask the client (the parent) through school management committees or councils or some such what is or is not working. We have not started to ask the beneficiary (the student) what we have done right, what could be done better and how. So what examples do we have that: (i) use students to assist with the assessment of learning, particularly non-cognitive learning acquisition; or (ii) that compare learning acquisition in a controlled trial in a system where students are empowered versus in the traditional &#8216;top-down structures? Going forward though, as cognitive learning is acquired and\\/or accessed differently and technical skills acquisition requires constant re-tooling&#8230;then non cognitive acquisition will come more to the fore and this can only be assessed in partnership with the learner. At the end of the day if I am not happy then I am not motivated and if I am not motivated then I don&#8217;t learn and retain learning&#8230;and you can only assess this if you ask And since there are no effective sanctions against me, I can just tell you the story, and you figure out what to do&#8221;.    <\\/p>\\n<p>Getting the right people spotted and forced to do what they need is sometimes difficult, and sanctions are required. Of course these are the views of the writer and I do not think so we all can agree on these ideas. The same events can be explained different ways through different perspectives. Only what I can say that the past event in the should be explained in the time of that period. Of course we can learn from the past.<br \\/>\\nFor me in the past we have conflict, its very difficult for me to name it as a civil war. It gives me different meaning, this may be because of my limited understanding. Again it could be the perspectives what we are using to explain the event.<br \\/>\\nIf we see the education development of the country in the past 15 years, we have achieved the remarkable gain the areas of expansion of schooling facilities, participation, increasing females and other disadvantaged groups in teaching positions. We should keep this in mind. But the gray area is in efficiency and quality of education. It was a right time to invest in quality and efficiency improvement but we were\\/are compelled to invest scarce resources on the development and maintenance of infrastructure which were damaged by the devastating earthquake.<br \\/>\\nTeaching forces in Nepal are highly influential in terms of political affiliation towards the political parties. I agree with the writer that if we blame only teacher for the low quality and efficiency it will be unfair to them. We all are responsible for this. There is a vicious circle of the graduates who are in teaching profession, the journey starts from school, then university, then job market, then profession, then work culture, then monitoring and accountability. In order to improve the quality of the graduates and make them accountable, we should consider all these aspects, not only those teachers who are in teaching profession.<br \\/>\\nThere are some schools who produces good results and highly attractive for many people. They are under the same policies, curriculum and monitoring system. So for me the most important thing is about the work culture. And politics is the overall for developing such culture. Let us hope that the forthcoming election will bring leaders with new visions and work culture who can guide us in the future where our children will have high quality education.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/11\\/17\\/accountability-in-education-in-post-conflict-nepal\\/#comment-18662","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d1ddfb49804b2c4cf531111e3cc608ee?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d1ddfb49804b2c4cf531111e3cc608ee?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d1ddfb49804b2c4cf531111e3cc608ee?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d1ddfb49804b2c4cf531111e3cc608ee?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/18662"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11223"}]}},{"id":18604,"post":11223,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Sushan Acharya","author_url":"","date":"2017-11-24T03:59:34","date_gmt":"2017-11-24T02:59:34","content":{"rendered":"<p>The blog is interesting but needs some reflections upon the blogger&#8217;s generalized view about teachers.  We, who are in Nepal, are also closely watching and in contact with schools and teachers directly or indirectly.  It was true that teachers were targeted as were other members of the public public for presumably taking the side of either the Maoists or the Army. Yes, there are teachers who did suffer and were victimized during the conflict. But the situation has changed a lot and many decisions in favor of teachers have been made during these past 10 years irrespective of their competence and political affiliation. One group is stronger as the other due to their affiliation with political parties. All the teacher unions\\/organizations are visibly sister organizations of political parties.   I wonder how the writer could be so deterministic when he said &#8220;Don\\u2019t blame teachers, blame the politicisation of education\\u201d.  Yes it is politicization &#8211; but who is politicizing? And politicization just doesn&#8217;t happen. People are involved in this act. <\\/p>\\n<p>Therefore let&#8217;s not be abstract here. The writer has very carefully omitted the role of political parties, who are mobilizing teachers and most teachers are loyal (accountable) to them. If the politicization was for education it would do good.  But the politicization is done for personal and party benefits. In other words utter &#8216;balkanization&#8217;.  Nevertheless, the Teacher Federation has been talking about quality education. It has been organizing training for teachers, organizing interaction programs, etc.  But we have not seen satisfactory results from all these initiatives in terms of the learning achievement of community school children. <\\/p>\\n<p>Right now, the ninth amendment of the Education Act is an example of keeping all the incompetent teachers in the system.  The amendment has proposed internal examination of 75% of the temporary teachers. And only 25% of seats are allocated for free competition.  This clearly restricts good people to enter the system and give continuity to the same burnt out and incompetent teachers.  It is crystal clear.  The 8th amendment was not even implemented before they brought the 9th amendment. It was done in agreement with all the major parties. After only a few days of the formation of the High Level Education Commission this decision was made. The Commission had not even started its work the amendment came. Two of the renowned educationists immediately resigned from the Commission. Now our education students are in protest against the amendment. But the teachers unions are very happy. Despite the debate, protest which was in the newspapers every day, teachers lobbied and got the President to endorse the Act.  The teachers\\u2019 leaders were requested not to do it and rather to ask the President to have the 8th amendment (in which there was a clause for the Teacher Commission to announce vacancy periodically so that many young people who possess teaching license could get opportunity to compete for teaching jobs). They didn&#8217;t listen.  Then a group of lawyers filed a writ against the amendment, which they claim is against the Constitution.  The Supreme Court has not yet made any decision.  <\\/p>\\n<p>Therefore it is not a straight game BUT what is true is that there are community schools that are doing really well, despite the teachers&#8217; political affiliation and political parties&#8217; pressure. How is this possible? Again all because of committed head teachers and management committees and also committed teachers.  How is it possible? Why were these few not influenced or affected by &#8216;politicization&#8217;? <\\/p>\\n<p>So, as the writer also hints, the issue and situation need to be viewed and analyzed in context, and should not be generalized as the writer himself has done.  Please see- <a href=\\"http:\\/\\/www.edukhabar.com\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">http:\\/\\/www.edukhabar.com\\/<\\/a> , tcmd.org (teachers can make a difference) for how and why a good community school could be good, and how and why another school with same resources and under the same legal provisions couldn&#8217;t do well.   But these websites are in Nepali language &#8211;  sorry about that!<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/11\\/17\\/accountability-in-education-in-post-conflict-nepal\\/#comment-18604","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c0e5aac28ecd5ecb1c08640c6a69fcc1?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c0e5aac28ecd5ecb1c08640c6a69fcc1?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c0e5aac28ecd5ecb1c08640c6a69fcc1?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c0e5aac28ecd5ecb1c08640c6a69fcc1?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/18604"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11223"}]}},{"id":18579,"post":11249,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"KhaulaRiz","author_url":"http:\\/\\/khaulariz.wordpress.com","date":"2017-11-22T12:29:39","date_gmt":"2017-11-22T11:29:39","content":{"rendered":"<p>Hello, <\\/p>\\n<p>I am interested in submitting a blog about the status of Pakistan\\u2019s education and technology. a big believer in every child having a right to an education! So thank you for sharing!<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/09\\/21\\/losing-out-on-learning-action-to-ensure-refugee-children-get-an-education\\/#comment-18373","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/839857d9d158c5122a10048afacea348?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/839857d9d158c5122a10048afacea348?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/839857d9d158c5122a10048afacea348?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/839857d9d158c5122a10048afacea348?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/18373"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10805"}]}},{"id":18358,"post":11159,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Angela Arnott","author_url":"","date":"2017-11-13T14:32:52","date_gmt":"2017-11-13T13:32:52","content":{"rendered":"<p>Its in the interests of effective teaching and learning that there is common understanding by both on the part of teachers and administrators of why and how frequently teachers are absent . Nobody wants to unduly penalize teachers working under difficult conditions but teacher absenteeism is a critical factor in the education delivery equation untracked by most governments. In Africa, as elsewhere we are aware that teacher absenteeism varies from being manageable (&lt;19%) to being alarming (25-35%) (Mozambique, Uganda among others). These\\u00a0are\\u00a0actually\\u00a0conservative\\u00a0 estimates of\\u00a0absence,as teachers may be present but not actually teaching in the classroom and this would push the rates \\u00a0considerably\\u00a0higher.\\u00a0\\u00a0A 2009 World Bank study in Zambia indicates that  a 5 per cent increase in the absence rate of teachers reduced learning by 4-8 percent of the average gains during the year . To\\u00a0design\\u00a0policy\\u00a0to\\u00a0improve\\u00a0school\\u00a0quality,\\u00a0it\\u00a0is\\u00a0important\\u00a0to\\u00a0know\\u00a0the\\u00a0pattern\\u00a0of\\u00a0 absences:\\u00a0\\u00a0who\\u00a0is\\u00a0most\\u00a0absent,\\u00a0and\\u00a0when and for what reason. With these issues in mind, Program4Results with Saltracker, has developed a teacher attendance management system which provides panoptic reporting on both teacher and learner daily attendance via a mobile app designed to be both on and off line. The incentive for teachers to participate is that in addition to this EMIS tool which supports the school head in a variety of ways, the app provides teacher development through an LMS on key subject materials which are conveyed and individually monitored by the time a teacher spends on subject related activities and knowledge quizzes. This builds the teachers knowledge and provides lesson plans for teaching difficult topics. Learning deficits are identified and can be addressed. An additional incentive is that a teacher can earn &quot;factokens&quot; by being registered as in attendance and by time spent on LMS activities which can be exchanged for study leave, performance merits or anything the Ministry decides upon. Promising results are indicated in two pilot studies.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/11\\/09\\/punishing-teachers-is-often-counter-productive\\/#comment-18358","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/33a84fe71e30deb065af0aee718e21dc?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/33a84fe71e30deb065af0aee718e21dc?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/33a84fe71e30deb065af0aee718e21dc?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/33a84fe71e30deb065af0aee718e21dc?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/18358"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/11159"}]}}]'

**********World Education Blog - Page:53**********

b'[{"id":18337,"post":10964,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Gabriellina Pedrotti","author_url":"http:\\/\\/buckeyemaestra.wordpress.com","date":"2017-11-12T16:14:51","date_gmt":"2017-11-12T15:14:51","content":{"rendered":"<p>Reblogged this on <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/buckeyemaestra.wordpress.com\\/2017\\/11\\/12\\/let-teachers-teach-the-dangers-of-expanding-teacher-workloads\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow\\">Dissecting Literacy<\\/a> and commented:<br \\/>\\nI would like to tackle this issue as I see this happening a lot.  Some teachers leave the profession mainly because they are so mentally drained by the end of the day.  I know I am juggling multiple projects and trying to enjoy my free time.  While I have found a rhythm, it seems there is one more thing added to that list.  I also think there needs to be a realistic expectation for some teachers to focus on.  If there are too many things to focus on, they will grow to resent their job which most principals should keep in mind.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/10\\/05\\/let-teachers-teach-the-dangers-of-expanding-teacher-workloads\\/#comment-18337","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/10f15c793b3f4fc6586b939ca40d23ed?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/10f15c793b3f4fc6586b939ca40d23ed?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/10f15c793b3f4fc6586b939ca40d23ed?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/10f15c793b3f4fc6586b939ca40d23ed?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/18337"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10964"}]}},{"id":18319,"post":11111,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Sujit Kumar Datta","author_url":"","date":"2017-11-11T17:50:24","date_gmt":"2017-11-11T16:50:24","content":{"rendered":"<p>It is the tragedy of education. UNESCO did not like the idea, but that does not invalidate it.  If you don&#8217;t show up at your office and don&#8217;t do what you are asked, you are like to face some sanctions &#8211; unless you are a political appointee.<\\/p>\\n<p>Nevertheless, one big reason is missing:  cognitive difficulty, inability to deal with the content or manage the class, that may have 70-90 students.   Also the boredom of repetitiveness.  Teachers in public schools of poor countries often struggle to bring into working memory content to answer questions or ask good ones, to spot mistakes in students&#8217; calculations, or to deal with endless noise. analysis of the GPE 2015\\/16 Results Report, particularly for pointing out GPE&#8217;s role in catalyzing more and better domestic and external finance for education in partner countries. <\\/p>\\n<p>GPE is a global partnership, and our results report is an important tool for mutual accountability across our developing country partner, donor, multilateral organizations, civil society organizations, teachers, and the private sector and foundation constituencies. GPE is a strong collective effort across these actors, all of whom are also represented on the GPE Board of Directors.<\\/p>\\n<p>Results that GPE reports upon are those of this wider partnership, not just GPE\\u2019s financial contributions. Specific indicators in the results report highlight the contributions and commitments of GPE partners (for example, the indicator on international financing) while others focus on outcomes to which GPE\\u2019s financing contributes alongside domestic financing from developing countries and other donors.   <\\/p>\\n<p>The very foundation of GPE is the recognition that no single organization, sector or even government can  build an inclusive, equitable and efficient education system. Despite the WDR\\u2019s resounding conclusion that \\u201ceducation systems perform best when their teachers are respected, prepared, selected based on merit, and supported in their work\\u201d, it then draws attention approvingly to the idea that replacing the least effective 7\\u201312% of teachers could help bridge the gap between student performance in the United States and Finland. Treating education as a production process with substitutable inputs is not a good starting point. <\\/p>\\n<p>I do think there is another, better option. Making sure that the least experienced teachers aren&#8217;t getting the most difficult classes to teach (cfr TALIS-report by the OECD) would be a great start. b'[{"id":17230,"post":10746,"parent":17172,"author":0,"author_name":"Pauline Rose","author_url":"","date":"2017-09-18T23:37:35","date_gmt":"2017-09-18T21:37:35","content":{"rendered":"<p>many thanks, Helen. Some important policy issues to consider here. Nowhere did I say 60% is insignificant. Rather, I was pointing out that there are other programmes that have achieved much larger gains within a year, so it is important to put in this context. <\\/p>\\n<p>Also, nowhere in my blog do I suggest giving up on PSL. But, like the evaluators, I would suggest that there is not yet enough evidence to support substantial scaling up. Indeed, having information for more than one year at the current scale would be valuable, as the evaluators propose.<\\/p>\\n<p>Rather, my blog is about considering other forms of evidence alongside the important results identified by the RCT including to consider the conditions under which a programme like PSL can work. This includes looking beyond the contractual arrangements to also looking at the practices within the classrooms.<\\/p>\\n<p>By the way, am I correct that you are Vice President, Measurement and Evaluation, Bridge International Academies (if @stevecmeasures is your twitter profile)?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/09\\/12\\/what-matters-for-education-reform-lessons-from-the-partnership-for-liberia-experiment-and-beyond\\/#comment-17229","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d3f32fa106b0d8f0ea786867a694b8b6?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d3f32fa106b0d8f0ea786867a694b8b6?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d3f32fa106b0d8f0ea786867a694b8b6?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d3f32fa106b0d8f0ea786867a694b8b6?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/17229"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10746"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/17156"}]}},{"id":17173,"post":10746,"parent":17172,"author":0,"author_name":"H. Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2017-09-15T10:33:54","date_gmt":"2017-09-15T08:33:54","content":{"rendered":"<p>Using a larger screen, I looked at the data annex more carefully.  Scores of variables are reported, some more relevant than others.<\\/p>\\n<p> The schools given to private providers seem to be well below the Liberian average. TIMSS sample test items and words per minute suggest that.  The USAID scores were 8-10 wpm higher either as treatment or as control than the scores of the private providers (or their controls).  see p. 82, table H.1, for example. This makes scores hard to compare with those of earlier measures that were more representative of the country.<\\/p>\\n<p>Contractor schools seem to have better student attendance, but they were chosen to be 4 minutes away from the rd. rather than 24.  Contractors constrained the numbers of students in classes and did not want to go to remote areas.  If governments had the same option, they would be performing much better.<\\/p>\\n<p>Some variables related to memory and consolidation had effects.  For example, student attendance was much higher in some contractors than others.  a 30% vs. 56% attendance for example would raise expectations for greater long-term retention, assuming the class taught some links in the chain needed to read.  But many differences with control schools in various situations were statistically but not practically significant. Do 2 words per minute justify management change when students only read 15 wpm?  And the counterfactual is really not known. Contractors in most cases did not report those.<\\/p>\\n<p>Overall, the benefits and hassles of using contractors to teach literacy through English are confused and modest.  The government will get much better outcomes by teaching reading automaticity in the Roman script through local languages or Creole English transparently spelled.  Maybe these results will nudge them in that direction.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/09\\/12\\/what-matters-for-education-reform-lessons-from-the-partnership-for-liberia-experiment-and-beyond\\/#comment-17173","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/17173"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10746"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/17172"}]}},{"id":17172,"post":10746,"parent":17142,"author":0,"author_name":"H. Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2017-09-15T09:22:36","date_gmt":"2017-09-15T07:22:36","content":{"rendered":"<p>Pauline, I looked at the data annex, and the content is very hard to interpret.  PAL may be showing its statistical prowess, but this does not help.  Results are in terms of standard deviation units rather than words per minute or some other concrete metric.  Students should be reading 45 words per minute at least in order to make sense of the text.  So it&#8217;s unclear whether the benefits of the private schools translate into ability to learn information from texts.<br \\/>\\nReported data include the Stallings classroom snapshot, so we see info on what the teacher was doing.  Private teachers were more likely to be in the school and in the class, and more likely to engage in &#8216;active&#8217; vs. &#8216;passive&#8217; instruction.  So, students are getting more instructional time, and they have on average a few more books.  They should be performing better, therefore.<br \\/>\\nSome providers also replaced most teachers, and one of them has 60% new teachers.  We all want to see bad teachers go, but the crux is qualified replacements. And will they stay? young people may teach for a while and leave for better opportunities.  The program is being evaluated for short-term effects, and it&#8217;s unclear what the long-term effects will be.  Supervision matters a great deal, and it&#8217;s also expensive.  The data are unclear about the incidence of supervisors.<br \\/>\\nThe data do not show how the complex English spelling is taught and how much reading practice students get.  This is what matters.  And frankly, there are very good interventions in Liberia for that. A few years ago Marcia Davidson spent 2-3 years for USAID developing a very detailed reading program with scripted lessons for Liberian English that gave very good outcomes.  Why has that fallen into disuse and when did private providers develop a similar program?  How do they teach English spelling?  All that is unclear.<br \\/>\\nSometimes money and public relations obscure the substance.  A sleek exterior discourages people from asking questions.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/09\\/12\\/what-matters-for-education-reform-lessons-from-the-partnership-for-liberia-experiment-and-beyond\\/#comment-17172","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/17172"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10746"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/17142"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=17172"}]}},{"id":17156,"post":10746,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Steve Cantrell","author_url":"","date":"2017-09-13T19:01:49","date_gmt":"2017-09-13T17:01:49","content":{"rendered":"<p>Not sure why you say 60% more learning is insignificant. 0.18 standard deviations (sd) is clearly less like 0.1 sd (a weak effect) and more like 0.2 sd (a moderate effect). Also, not sure why you are giving up on PSL after a single year. Given that some school operators saw truly large effects, equating to more than an additional year of learning, I&#8217;d be more optimistic.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/09\\/12\\/what-matters-for-education-reform-lessons-from-the-partnership-for-liberia-experiment-and-beyond\\/#comment-17156","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/37919c7abbe6a3a9074fa642ec211106?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/37919c7abbe6a3a9074fa642ec211106?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/37919c7abbe6a3a9074fa642ec211106?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/37919c7abbe6a3a9074fa642ec211106?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/17156"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10746"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=17156"}]}},{"id":17153,"post":10746,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Prachi Srivastava","author_url":"http:\\/\\/www.prachisrivastava.com\\/","date":"2017-09-13T15:38:32","date_gmt":"2017-09-13T13:38:32","content":{"rendered":"<p>Pauline, thanks for inviting me to comment. You raise some pertinent points, in particular regarding the limits of what an RCT, and especially the design of this one, can and cannot tell us. WHY have certain providers done better? WHY have their been relative gains? We don&#8217;t know. <\\/p>\\n<p>That matters. It matters for replication. It matters in making the decision to scale-up or not. And it matters in trying to figure out what measures we can institute in all schools.<\\/p>\\n<p>As you point out, and as we have discussed, relative gains need to be translated to absolute terms, and those absolute terms need to match desired learning outcomes. That matters if we want all our children (and I do mean &#8216;our&#8217; children) to learn, and learn well.<\\/p>\\n<p>The relative funding differences between government schools and among the different private providers, is certainly an issue that needs further exploring. Money matters especially in contexts that are severely under-funded. <\\/p>\\n<p>Those are my 2 cents, or 0.124 pence!<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/09\\/12\\/what-matters-for-education-reform-lessons-from-the-partnership-for-liberia-experiment-and-beyond\\/#comment-17153","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/bed322913469ba6e6352f30d54a90ab6?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/bed322913469ba6e6352f30d54a90ab6?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/bed322913469ba6e6352f30d54a90ab6?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/bed322913469ba6e6352f30d54a90ab6?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/17153"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10746"}]}},{"id":17148,"post":10746,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"careerbuildersnet","author_url":"http:\\/\\/mycareerbuilders.wordpress.com","date":"2017-09-12T23:25:31","date_gmt":"2017-09-12T21:25:31","content":{"rendered":"<p>This is hitting the nail on the head as it concerns our attitude to educational development in the so called &#8220;third world&#8221;, especially Africa. The issue of educating our young people is not taken as seriously as it should by almost everyone across the board in the education value chain. From the politicians to the policy implementers, down to the teachers and other stakeholders. This is quite ironical, because it should be the greatest priority for us, seeing that the overall backwardness of the nations in this bracket of the nations of the world is mainly due to the backwardness in education. Until this is realized, and corresponding attention and appropriate actions taken to redress the present poor attitude towards educational advancement, the situation will not improve, hence these nations would continue remain backward.<br \\/>\\nIt is our passionate desire and cry to all concerned to give everything they can give, of their time, energy, resources, and passion to the cause of improving the educational climate, which would lead to relative high educational Rose","author_url":"","date":"2017-09-12T17:48:46","date_gmt":"2017-09-12T15:48:46","content":{"rendered":"<p>Hi Helen &#8211; thanks for your comment. Appendix H (graph on page 84) includes information on words per minute in the sample. It would be interesting to hear your interpretation of this. Your point on language is an important one. Ultimately bringing in the private sector alone to support government schools cannot fix the problem, if the problem is to do with these kinds of issues. This isn&#8217;t to say that involving the private sector cannot bring benefits, but perhaps is a sticking plaster in the current context if more fundamental changes are needed, as you suggest?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/09\\/12\\/what-matters-for-education-reform-lessons-from-the-partnership-for-liberia-experiment-and-beyond\\/#comment-17142","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d3f32fa106b0d8f0ea786867a694b8b6?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d3f32fa106b0d8f0ea786867a694b8b6?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d3f32fa106b0d8f0ea786867a694b8b6?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d3f32fa106b0d8f0ea786867a694b8b6?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/17142"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10746"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=17142"}]}},{"id":17140,"post":10746,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"H. Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2017-09-12T16:43:23","date_gmt":"2017-09-12T14:43:23","content":{"rendered":"<p>Surely the private sector will proclaim the results as a great success, to be expanded to other low-income countries.  Somehow people don&#8217;t scrutinize the data.  But effect sizes or fractions of a standard deviation are difficult to interpret empirically, so it&#8217;s good to make these comprehensible.  How many words per minute did the students read before and after the grade?  what was the difference, given information from other countries?  e.g. students in the US increase about 25 words per year.  How many did Liberian students get?<\\/p>\\n<p>The other question is why teach the complex English spelling as a way to learn reading. The Liberian government has better options. Liberian Creole is spelled transparently, and students could start with that.  They can also start reading in African languages, such as Kpele.  They can simultaneously learn oral English, until they are fluent in transparent orthographies and can learn the English complexities.<\\/p>\\n<p>There have been dialogues with the government on this option, but there is always a status issue.  So instead of teaching all children transparent orthographies inexpensively, the government opted for this complicated private-public partnership.  It&#8217;s unfortunate.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/09\\/12\\/what-matters-for-education-reform-lessons-from-the-partnership-for-liberia-experiment-and-beyond\\/#comment-17140","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/17140"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10746"}]}},{"id":17132,"post":10717,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Abu Harris","author_url":"http:\\/\\/rayharris57.wordpress.com","date":"2017-08-11T20:09:16","date_gmt":"2017-08-11T18:09:16","content":{"rendered":"<p>Reblogged this on <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/rayharris57.wordpress.com\\/2017\\/08\\/12\\/promoting-literacy-in-a-multilingual-society\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow\\">Capacity Building for Sustainable Development<\\/a> and commented:<br \\/>\\nIn Tanzania we are working in 7 regions, 5 of which have many children (70% of our target population) do not speak the language of instruction (Kiswahili) at home. These children arrive at primary standard 1 knowing very little Kiswahili and therefore understanding very little of what the teacher is saying. Obviously by standard 3 these children are noticeably failing and are vulnerable. Through EQUIP-Tanzania&#8217;s short 16 week School Readiness intervention, some of these children (200,000 at present) are not only surviving their first taste of formal education, but are actually thriving. The least we can do is be more child centred and welcome all children into school.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/08\\/11\\/promoting-literacy-in-a-multilingual-society\\/#comment-16652","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/16652"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10609"}]}},{"id":16626,"post":10562,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Thakurdas Murmu","author_url":"http:\\/\\/Google","date":"2017-08-10T01:24:12","date_gmt":"2017-08-09T23:24:12","content":{"rendered":"<p>Each and every child has right to education. **********World Education Blog - Page:58**********

b'[{"id":16446,"post":10531,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"H. Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2017-07-25T22:04:47","date_gmt":"2017-07-25T20:04:47","content":{"rendered":"<p>The measurement issues discussed are sensible, but whom does measurement help?  The most direct beneficiaries seem to be donor staff doing their jobs. In which poor countries was measurement used to improve instruction with practically significant result? The author perhaps can give us examples.<\\/p>\\n<p>It will be interesting to see when instruction will get the attention and detail that measurements get.<br \\/>\\nWhen will when blogs and bloggers start dealing with information processing in students&#8217; heads?  Hopefully some time before 2030.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/07\\/25\\/poor-quality-learning-assessments-are-crumbling-under-the-weight-of-the-decisions-they-inform\\/#comment-16446","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/16446"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10531"}]}},{"id":16443,"post":10475,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Allan Onunga","author_url":"","date":"2017-07-25T10:50:31","date_gmt":"2017-07-25T08:50:31","content":{"rendered":"<p>I&#8217;m an educator in Kenya with passion for education commentary. Hill","author_url":"","date":"2017-07-12T15:06:19","date_gmt":"2017-07-12T13:06:19","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thanks for your comment. You are right to say that as a literature review, the report responds to the assessments that are out there and therefore leaves gaps where there are gaps in the literature. The author does discuss what she understands to be the most significant gaps. The report also focuses on assessments rather than all aspects of literacy. It&#8217;s purpose is not to review different views of &#8211; or theories about &#8211; literacy development. However, our understanding of how literacy skills develop should shape the assessments we use and the way we analyse results.<\\/p>\\n<p>I&#8217;m sure we also agree that the limited access to reading materials in many contexts is a factor in restricting practice and slowing progress. Interestingly, this relates to the previous comment in a somewhat contradictory way. If a lack of print materials is a significant impediment to learning then in order to teach literacy in a language, we need to establish a reasonable base of materials in that language &#8211; a significant task in many cases.<\\/p>\\n<p>Is there evidence you could point me to about the importance of perceptual skills in later literacy development?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/06\\/16\\/literacy-assessments-the-importance-of-reading-with-understanding\\/#comment-16195","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/558b4f625927445197aebc20b1732ba2?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/558b4f625927445197aebc20b1732ba2?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/558b4f625927445197aebc20b1732ba2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/558b4f625927445197aebc20b1732ba2?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/16195"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10331"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/15719"}]}},{"id":16188,"post":10331,"parent":15718,"author":0,"author_name":"Peter-Sam Hill","author_url":"","date":"2017-07-12T13:12:05","date_gmt":"2017-07-12T11:12:05","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thank you for your comment. **********World Education Blog - Page:60**********

b'[{"id":15722,"post":8211,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Dr.S.B.Ekanayake","author_url":"https:\\/\\/sbekanayake.blogspot.com","date":"2017-06-16T13:01:27","date_gmt":"2017-06-16T11:01:27","content":{"rendered":"<p>Mundiya Kapanga&#8217;s statement on the significance of culture truly awakens all indigenous people to see the extent to which they have sincerely protected the earth not taking more than is needed for survival and leaving the rest to replenish itself for the future.This is unlike most who grapple to acquire much more than they need leading to exploitation of resources too soon not providing space and time for nature to recharge. There is, however, the value of modern sciences and development paradigms which have to abide by the laws of nature which MK and similar tribes\\/leaders universally have respected. to bring about sustainability into our fore.  We all have to face the truth of the need to learn from both MK and the modern day scientists. GEM report plays a great role in bringing the past into the present and creating awareness of the dangers of the future if we are not taking correct steps for the benefit of the future generations.<br \\/>\\nDr.S.B.Ekanayake.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/09\\/15\\/in-my-tribe-we-go-to-a-different-type-of-school\\/#comment-15722","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d774734ea8effe56f2cfb33bbd1935c4?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d774734ea8effe56f2cfb33bbd1935c4?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d774734ea8effe56f2cfb33bbd1935c4?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d774734ea8effe56f2cfb33bbd1935c4?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/15722"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8211"}]}},{"id":15719,"post":10331,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"H. Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2017-06-16T12:02:08","date_gmt":"2017-06-16T10:02:08","content":{"rendered":"<p>This is one more review which sets literacy in the context of other language, cognitive and social skills. Unfortunately this puts the cart before the horse. The review skips the essential first stage of perceptual learning, where the poor fail: Concatenating letters through practice to the point where the brain recognizes them as faces.  Only then is comprehension necessary. Letter-by-letter practice is crucial to get to this stage.  Working memory requires speed, so this stage is crucial for comprehension. But the very poor get too little practice, so they don&#8217;t get to that stage for years. So they don&#8217;t understand. <\\/p>\\n<p>The perceptual learning aspects of reading are poorly known, so the otherwise excellent report excludes them.  But this unfortunately means that interventions based on reading as language will fail. And DFID funds will again be wasted.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/06\\/16\\/literacy-assessments-the-importance-of-reading-with-understanding\\/#comment-15719","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/15719"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10331"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=15719"}]}},{"id":15718,"post":10331,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"John Clegg","author_url":"","date":"2017-06-16T11:57:54","date_gmt":"2017-06-16T09:57:54","content":{"rendered":"<p>Can I make one key point in relation to this post. It is one which I and colleagues in language in development education feel we need to make again and again until it is taken on board. I take no issue with the very proper matters which the post deals with in respect of the teaching and assessment of reading; they have been the bread and butter of the teaching of initial reading for decades. However, a more fundamental question is: are children learning to read in &#8211; and then continuing to get their education through &#8211; a language which they speak well. Many, throughout the developing world are not. The fact that this is the case puts a low ceiling on what they can learn and grossly depresses their educational achievement. Low school achievement as a consequence of, quite simply, not understanding the content of lessons, is very widespread, very damaging to the education of individuals and very probably a key factor in the failure of developing countries to grow economically at the rate they they should. It is often this more than anything else which accounts for poor reading ability levels. Medium of instruction is a first-order issue: it undermines &#8211; or facilitates &#8211; everything else. NGOs and aid agencies all over the developing world, however, are only just waking up to this issue and ministries are largely still blind to it. We need as a matter of urgency to face this language question and get it right, Only then can we move towards thinking about the very important matters which this blog is concerned with.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/06\\/16\\/literacy-assessments-the-importance-of-reading-with-understanding\\/#comment-15718","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/15718"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10331"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=15718"}]}},{"id":15695,"post":10323,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Wendy","author_url":"http:\\/\\/chinchi87.wordpress.com","date":"2017-06-15T12:36:14","date_gmt":"2017-06-15T10:36:14","content":{"rendered":"<p>With so many adults seeking education and knowing the process, how is it there are unsurmountable barriers for those trying to learn? you for the excellent article. We often think of greater access to education as being important to economic growth and workforce development. These are real and important issues. However greater access to education is also an important factor for increasing political inclusion and for creating a more constructive social and political dialogue in the society. We have seen in several countries, and recently lately in the USA, the divisive effect that a significant segment of the population that has not benefited from educational resources can have on the political situation and a country&#8217;s international stature. With national educational levels being of increasing importance to the ability of the state to compete in a globalized world, local differences in access to education also give rise to different world views among the population. Improving access to education is a state&#8217;s responsibility to its communities, its national interests, and its international neighbors.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/05\\/16\\/inclusive-higher-education-in-south-africa-not-just-a-policy-project-but-also-an-ethical-project\\/#comment-15078","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/db4faae643702784a995340ba2f98ece?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/db4faae643702784a995340ba2f98ece?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/db4faae643702784a995340ba2f98ece?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/db4faae643702784a995340ba2f98ece?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/15078"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10194"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=15078"}]}},{"id":15077,"post":10153,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Heseg","author_url":"http:\\/\\/www.xn----zhcdjajnmhc4duf.co.il\\/","date":"2017-05-16T12:04:30","date_gmt":"2017-05-16T10:04:30","content":{"rendered":"<p>So It&#8217;s also important to evaluate what kind of affirmative actions to take, in order to make them fair to all. Race and class are big factors here, but they are also limited and they may take opportunities from others who are disadvantaged and more qualified. I was told in Ethiopia, to introduce an affirmative action to increase female enrollment in higher education, they lowered the cutting point of admission exam for female students and as a result, many female students who were not prepared to study at the university level enrolled and could not perform well and eventually dropped out. And how do male students feel, who perform in the admission exam better than female students but could not enroll?  I think rather than lowering the standard, it is more important to provide remedial courses or preparatory courses to help them meet the same standard as others.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/05\\/01\\/growing-demand-for-higher-education-puts-affirmative-action-in-the-spotlight\\/#comment-14881","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3aae4468349c7e8e3d4a0c5415f45cd9?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3aae4468349c7e8e3d4a0c5415f45cd9?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3aae4468349c7e8e3d4a0c5415f45cd9?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/3aae4468349c7e8e3d4a0c5415f45cd9?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/14881"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10104"}]}},{"id":14876,"post":9936,"parent":14676,"author":0,"author_name":"Stanfill","author_url":"http:\\/\\/www.seancody.com","date":"2017-05-01T16:55:47","date_gmt":"2017-05-01T14:55:47","content":{"rendered":"<p>Not good at all.
