Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2017-04-18T16:42:45","date_gmt":"2017-04-18T14:42:45","content":{"rendered":"<p>Do tests reflect student learning and capabilities?<br \\/>\\nThe fashionable trend is to rail against testing and say no because children surely know a lot more.  But tests require instant and effortless retrieval. So if students &#8220;know&#8221; something and retrieve it an hour later or do it too slowly to fit into working memory, it&#8217;s the same as if they don&#8217;t know it the opportunity to use it passes.<\\/p>\\n<p>The same thing happens in real life.  We either can read an understand a sign or not.  We can either guesstimate unit prices when comparing items in a store or not.  All this means that someone should be accountable at teaching basic skills to fluency and automaticity.   There is a chain to choose from.  Let the readers think about this.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/04\\/18\\/whosaccountable-we-want-to-hear-from-you\\/#comment-14730","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/14730"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/10008"}]}},{"id":14682,"post":9973,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"H. b'[{"id":14295,"post":9607,"parent":14284,"author":0,"author_name":"John Clegg","author_url":"","date":"2017-03-01T16:51:42","date_gmt":"2017-03-01T15:51:42","content":{"rendered":"<p>I completely agree with Carol Benson&#8217;s comment. The questions raised in the article are important, but the question of the language of learning and teaching is more fundamental. The issues raised in the article are not relevant if, as in many parts of the world, learners cannot read the books, because they cannot understand the language they are written in.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/02\\/28\\/the-challenge-of-target-4-7-in-fragile-and-low-resource-contexts\\/#comment-14295","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/14295"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/9607"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/14284"}]}},{"id":14293,"post":7990,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Dr.S.B.Ekanayake","author_url":"https:\\/\\/sbekanayake.blogspot.com","date":"2017-03-01T14:20:02","date_gmt":"2017-03-01T13:20:02","content":{"rendered":"<p>Indigenous knowledge and practices are closely linked in indigenous societies and cultural milieus. What they learned and taught were based on the realities. There were no outside elements to determine agendas for them. All these were in keeping with the present day SDG. In fact, all traditional religious practices and stories related to the religious norms contained the current day principles of SDG. Thus, for example,  Buddhist philosophy contains stories of the previous births of Lord Buddha which were conveyed through sermons to the laity by the priests  regularly and continued to date. The Afghans are great story tellers. So are other cultures all of which had centuries of homegrown literature with full of stories containing good deeds and behaviors of man. The indigenous populations in Asia, Australia, and elsewhere in the world had great respect to fauna and flora ( well-known speech of the Chief of Seattle ). Hence, SDGs were well followed,  observed and respected by one and all, least exploiting the nature and polluting the same. Hence what is urgently needed is to study these valuable lessons and practices and use the same amongst the communities rather than look for alien actions and lessons.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/08\\/09\\/promoting-indigenous-knowledge-within-the-sustainable-development-agenda\\/#comment-14293","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d774734ea8effe56f2cfb33bbd1935c4?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d774734ea8effe56f2cfb33bbd1935c4?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d774734ea8effe56f2cfb33bbd1935c4?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d774734ea8effe56f2cfb33bbd1935c4?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/14293"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7990"}]}},{"id":14292,"post":6995,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Dr.S.B.Ekanayake","author_url":"https:\\/\\/sbekanayake.blogspot.com","date":"2017-03-01T13:23:00","date_gmt":"2017-03-01T12:23:00","content":{"rendered":"<p>It is true that English is more or less the lingua franca of many nations today. The solution to the  problem of teaching English should be focussed on what the stakeholders expect to do with the knowledge of English. Do they want to be teachers\\/professionals or want to migrate to developed countries for employment or do they aspire to be tourist guides in their own country etc.. Thus the course and methodologies should vary with the needs of the client. However, if we commence teaching standard English with grammar as the basis it would be well nigh impossible for them to comprehend, understand and be versatile, well-knowing the complications of the language of English, for them to pursue learning taking an interest in the subject.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/02\\/26\\/when-the-challenge-is-teaching-teachers-english\\/#comment-14292","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d774734ea8effe56f2cfb33bbd1935c4?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d774734ea8effe56f2cfb33bbd1935c4?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d774734ea8effe56f2cfb33bbd1935c4?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/d774734ea8effe56f2cfb33bbd1935c4?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/14292"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6995"}]}},{"id":14285,"post":9607,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Vincent Funi Dusabe","author_url":"http:\\/\\/ncdc.go.ug","date":"2017-02-28T16:32:41","date_gmt":"2017-02-28T15:32:41","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thank you every one for the effort to achieving goal #4.7. Special thanks go to PEIC\\/EAA for funding NCDC to come up with CDRM materials. Specific and more thanks go to Dr. Margaret Sinclair for ensuring that the physical and financial support is given to NCDC and to Dr. Jean Bernard of Spectacle Learning Media for the Technical Guidance on coming up with Nationally and Internationally acceptable materials.<br \\/>\\nNCDC is looking forward to getting more support to print for circulation in all Ugandan schools. In a country like Nigeria, where we have a wide array of indigenous languages with the most prominent three languages being Yoruba, Ibo and Hausa, the English language has been adopted as the national official language and language of instruction in schools. If we decide to promote instruction in the mother tongue, we would probably eventually be unable to boast of any official language in the country and as such communication between people of diverse cultures and languages will become difficult. b'[{"id":14123,"post":9497,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"David Archer","author_url":"https:\\/\\/plus.google.com\\/117240338748655327487","date":"2017-02-16T19:32:28","date_gmt":"2017-02-16T18:32:28","content":{"rendered":"<p>For those who are interested in this continuing debate please see here the detailed response I have provided to Justin Sandefur&#8217;s original blog for CGD:<br \\/>\\n<a href=\\"http:\\/\\/www.actionaid.org\\/case-qualitative-research-complement-rct\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">http:\\/\\/www.actionaid.org\\/case-qualitative-research-complement-rct<\\/a><\\/p>\\n<p>There is a strong case for the complementarity between the RCT and the qualitative research we have proposed with Education International, There has been some unfortunate selective quoting used to criticise us (and admittedly some unfortunate phrasing in the call for proposals) &#8211; but our TORs are clear that the research we propose may either &#8220;verify or challenge some of the initial concerns and observations\\u201d.<br \\/>\\nAt the same time we do not claim to be entirely neutral &#8211; as we have a long track record of evidence based work that informs our advocacy in this area.    See for example the report Private Profit Public Loss which we made substantial contributions to and which offers a very comprehensive review of the evidence around low fee private schools:<br \\/>\\n  <a href=\\"http:\\/\\/www.campaignforeducation.org\\/en\\/news\\/global\\/view\\/690-private-profit-public-loss-gce-s-report-shows-scant-evidence-that-low-fee-for-profit-private-schools-are-better-than-public-schools\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">http:\\/\\/www.campaignforeducation.org\\/en\\/news\\/global\\/view\\/690-private-profit-public-loss-gce-s-report-shows-scant-evidence-that-low-fee-for-profit-private-schools-are-better-than-public-schools<\\/a><\\/p>\\n<p>We recognise the Liberia case is different &#8211; and this is one of the reasons for us wanting to do new qualitative research to inform (and possibly challenge) our advocacy work. However once the group who benefitted by this got into power they abolished free tertiary education and instituted a range of deferred debt repayment which is indexed twice per year so one is encouraged to pay off the debt sooner rather than later once the repayment threshold is reached or migrate to another country and default with little or no hope of the government recovering this money. So in a way tertiary education can still be free if the ethical and moral considerations are repositioned.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/02\\/14\\/taxing-the-rich-to-pay-for-college-education-for-the-poor-in-san-francisco\\/#comment-14119","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/9db2e8a2f9a510cdcc854f87c332378c?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/9db2e8a2f9a510cdcc854f87c332378c?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/9db2e8a2f9a510cdcc854f87c332378c?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/9db2e8a2f9a510cdcc854f87c332378c?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/14119"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/9482"}]}},{"id":14017,"post":3981,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"brittany yates","author_url":"http:\\/\\/drsebispelltemple.wixsite.com\\/spelltemple","date":"2017-02-11T17:32:58","date_gmt":"2017-02-11T16:32:58","content":{"rendered":"<p>There is nothing more powerful than educating yourself on the subject so that you know what you can do to protect yourself against the AIDS virus as well as understand it. People need to educate themselves to also promote understanding and eliminate the negative stigma attached to it. I have to recommend a fantastic memoir that covers the authors first hand experience treating, understanding, and trying to cure the AIDS virus. The book is called, \\u201cDon\\u2019t Stop Dreaming\\u201d by dr sebi  (<a href=\\"http:\\/\\/drsebispelltemple.wixsite.com\\/spelltemple\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">http:\\/\\/drsebispelltemple.wixsite.com\\/spelltemple<\\/a>). The book definitely addresses the issue of fear and hysteria dominating and how compassion and understanding is thrown to the wayside. It is so wonderfully and personally written I was hooked from beginning to end. However, while not wishing to appear a wet blanket, I do need to point out that textbooks also need to be understood. The example shown is unreadable by Grade 4 learners in Rwanda, whose ability to read textbooks in English is much lower than that which is required by this text. The book is aimed at learners at the beginning of English-medium education in Rwanda; they will approach this book with minimal ability to read in English. I have spent a lot of time analysing textbooks used in Rwanda in grade 4. Almost all are wholly unreadable by their learners; they are written for native-speakers of English; indeed this book would be far more difficult to read than an equivalent text designed for native-speaker readers at the same age level in the UK. <\\/p>\\n<p>We must face this question of readability in textbooks for learners working in a second language. It is a first-order question: that is, however good this book may be at conveying its social studies contents and specifically the issue of gender equity, that issue is wholly lost on the learners for whom the book is designed, because they cannot read it.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2017\\/01\\/19\\/gender-equality-in-post-genocide-rwanda\\/#comment-13716","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/13716"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/9219"}]}},{"id":13694,"post":9267,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Jon Temple","author_url":"http:\\/\\/www.improvetuition.org\\/bradford-tuition\\/","date":"2017-01-17T21:11:50","date_gmt":"2017-01-17T20:11:50","content":{"rendered":"<p>Wow. Clegg","author_url":"","date":"2016-12-15T12:37:23","date_gmt":"2016-12-15T11:37:23","content":{"rendered":"<p>The focus on the content of textbooks is important. But even more important is a focus on whether young people in schools can read them or not. There is ample evidence that in developing countries, where learners are working in a second language, the textbooks are far too hard for them to read. There is also good evidence that the books &#8211; even if they reach the schools &#8211; are not used by teachers and learners. These two issues are clearly related. Many learners learning in a second language are not reading in school.  It is a source of unending frustration for those of us concerned with levels of ability in the medium of instruction, that this issue is not taken up by ministries, publishers, teacher-educators, NGOs and even websites such as this one. The content of the textbook is important, but it is actually a second-order question. The ability to read it is a first-order question. We must pay more attention to this.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/12\\/15\\/out-of-date-textbooks-put-sustainable-development-at-risk\\/#comment-13122","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/13122"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/9100"}]}},{"id":13121,"post":3981,"parent":13120,"author":0,"author_name":"Kate Redman","author_url":"","date":"2016-12-15T10:41:22","date_gmt":"2016-12-15T09:41:22","content":{"rendered":"<p>Dear nicole, It was written by the GEM Report (or GMR as we were known at the time). b'[{"id":13050,"post":8898,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"aromap","author_url":"http:\\/\\/aromapatrick.wordpress.com","date":"2016-12-07T00:15:43","date_gmt":"2016-12-06T23:15:43","content":{"rendered":"<p>Reblogged this on <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/aromapatrick.wordpress.com\\/2016\\/12\\/07\\/lifelong-learning-will-help-with-our-much-needed-shift-to-greener-economies\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow\\">aromapatrick-Good Governance Network Blog<\\/a>.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/11\\/18\\/lifelong-learning-will-help-with-our-much-needed-shift-to-greener-economies\\/#comment-13050","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e9d18e5d1329ea91b86bff7a2ca4335d?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e9d18e5d1329ea91b86bff7a2ca4335d?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e9d18e5d1329ea91b86bff7a2ca4335d?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e9d18e5d1329ea91b86bff7a2ca4335d?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/13050"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8898"}]}},{"id":13047,"post":8917,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"mella_s@hotmail.com","author_url":"","date":"2016-12-06T16:09:54","date_gmt":"2016-12-06T15:09:54","content":{"rendered":"<p>Dear Bfwandfox, I agree with you, there are many practical difficulties and resource constraints in measuring such a diverse range of skills. There are also obvious benefits to keeping it simple by focusing on core, age-appropriate literacy and numeracy skills within a set of common metrics that will produce internationally comparable data \\u2013 although here I imagine that many low income countries will still encounter significant difficulties in survey design, data collection and subsequently transforming that data into useful pedagogic tools that can be used by teachers to advance learning. After all, this is what it\\u2019s all about.<br \\/>\\nOr maybe not\\u2026.<\\/p>\\n<p>The essential point I was getting at is that children need to feel recognition and validation for what they can do, their skills, creativity and talents, not just what they know. And we should do more to make more children feel validated by the years they spend in schooling. Many public exam systems accross the world are not set up to do that. Recognition  can be a great confidence builder and sets children up to aim higher and go further.<\\/p>\\n<p>Again, as you mention, many of the skills now needed to get ahead are acquired elsewhere and fall outside of the conventional box of schooling. So what are we saying? Does this mean that if a primary school-age child does not reach a standard score on a test for his\\/her age level, we can neatly summise that no learning is taking place, or that a child isn\\u2019t developing? <\\/p>\\n<p>There may be a multitude of cognitive leaps and many layers of social and emotional development taking place, but we might never know because, as Pauline Rose wrote in a recent blog post for the Global Partnership for Education, the child may be unable to read the questions on the test, let alone know what the correct answer is.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/11\\/28\\/national-learning-assessments-theres-more-to-gain-than-valuable-data\\/#comment-13047","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/88e2597be7144e529f2aca53e3a7d676?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/88e2597be7144e529f2aca53e3a7d676?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/88e2597be7144e529f2aca53e3a7d676?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/88e2597be7144e529f2aca53e3a7d676?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/13047"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8917"}]}},{"id":13009,"post":5532,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"johnbosco mulindwa","author_url":"http:\\/\\/www.unik.ac.ug","date":"2016-12-01T14:12:35","date_gmt":"2016-12-01T13:12:35","content":{"rendered":"<p>AM JOHNBOSCO MULINDWA DEPUTY HEADTEACHER   ST KIZITO SECONDARY SCHOOL , MUKONO DISTRICT, UGANDA KAMPALA, EAST-. Education for the majority is about employment, and employers seek out grades and qualifications above all else? Secondly, teaching these &#8220;new skills&#8221; and ongoing assessment requires more qualified teachers, time in the curriculum and money, which is limited on all fronts, and while &#8220;education for all&#8221; and inclusivity are great ideas, the practicality is that resources are spread too thinly.<br \\/>\\nI have a very simplistic view. needs to be implemented as soon as possible, all over the world. It&#8217;s in school that kids are most impressionable. Unfortunately, most Indian schools have lackluster regard to water wastage, electricity consumption, and things like that. It&#8217;s a shame, and it&#8217;s what breeds complacency about the environment when they grow up. I&#8217;ve been a victim of this as well.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/11\\/15\\/what-is-the-whole-school-approach-to-environmental-education\\/#comment-12914","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5ec0dae82f363723331042914ea2d5ae?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5ec0dae82f363723331042914ea2d5ae?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5ec0dae82f363723331042914ea2d5ae?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5ec0dae82f363723331042914ea2d5ae?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12914"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8865"}]}},{"id":12911,"post":8772,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Debra Severan","author_url":"","date":"2016-11-15T07:06:08","date_gmt":"2016-11-15T06:06:08","content":{"rendered":"<p>Including the link to the New Urban Agenda report helps one to understand the breadth and depth of the 175 goals documented and committed to by international governances. Thank you for sharing with the world the challenges and obstacles that young girls and women encounter in pursuit of an education.  I agree with your comment about men becoming involved and serving as mentors to help women rise to their full potential by putting their talents on display.  I imagine that these gentlemen will come from all aspects of a young girl\\u2019s life.  In other words, the collaboration to protect a girl child and provide her with opportunities for education should emerge from her father, brothers, and male teachers to male leaders in the community who witness such atrocities against these young children.  As someone who became a teenage mom at 16 years old, I can attest to the value of having not only strong women but men as well (my high school male teachers) who rose to the occasion to make sure that I completed my education.  As a result, I have obtained a bachelor\\u2019s and master\\u2019s degree, and am now working on my doctoral degree. Post<\\/a><\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/11\\/10\\/how-to-reach-a-consensus-on-reporting-learning-globally\\/#comment-12893","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/687b5f4bbfb4f28f43ed62559d8293a6?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/687b5f4bbfb4f28f43ed62559d8293a6?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/687b5f4bbfb4f28f43ed62559d8293a6?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/687b5f4bbfb4f28f43ed62559d8293a6?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12893"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8832"}]}},{"id":12890,"post":8832,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Carolyn Benson","author_url":"","date":"2016-11-10T21:47:48","date_gmt":"2016-11-10T20:47:48","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thank you for this interesting post, Aaron. I would like to call attention to a point you made that could easily get lost: &#8220;The second issue involves the importance of knowing about the CULTURAL AND LINGUISTIC CONTEXT in which assessments are carried out so as to improve how we interpret differences within and between countries.&#8221;<\\/p>\\n<p>Serious consideration of languages and world views is not only for interpretation of results&#8211;  it is for assessment itself. Testing in a language that learners do not speak or understand well, especially if their teachers are in a similar situation, is a big waste of time and resources, and I would say does more harm than good, because it causes people to believe that learning can only be communicated and assessed in dominant languages. &#8220;Serious consideration&#8221; means actually translating assessments into appropriate languages (as Ethiopia does, for example, on its national grade 4 and grade 8 assessments depending on the &#8220;nationality language&#8221; used as medium of instruction&#8211; see e.g. Heugh et al 2011) and ensuring that those translations use the appropriate terminology as well as illustrations\\/examples that are comprehensible in learners&#8217; contexts. This requires back-translating and piloting so that the instruments actually assess the intended content. (Since this is done on &#8220;standardized testing&#8221; in high-income countries, why would we not insist on the same standards?)<\\/p>\\n<p>Where learners&#8217; own languages are not used for teaching and learning, I would argue that NO assessment can be valid, because it will mainly assess the ability to memorize (in the case of curriculum-based testing) and\\/or luck (in the case of general skills testing). Needless to say, this is highly unfair to individual learners, as well as to schools and to school systems.<\\/p>\\n<p>I feel that cross-national assessments do to curriculum what the push for universal access did to quality&#8211; put the cart before the horse. Why not work toward quality teaching and learning first, then worry about getting children into (good) schools? Then it&#8217;s time to assess, to show what learners CAN do.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/11\\/10\\/how-to-reach-a-consensus-on-reporting-learning-globally\\/#comment-12890","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/29f77959cf9d2483057178096655cf10?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/29f77959cf9d2483057178096655cf10?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/29f77959cf9d2483057178096655cf10?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/29f77959cf9d2483057178096655cf10?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12890"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8832"}]}},{"id":12889,"post":8832,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Jean Bernard","author_url":"http:\\/\\/www.spectaclelearningmedia.net","date":"2016-11-10T16:44:59","date_gmt":"2016-11-10T15:44:59","content":{"rendered":"<p>If part of the role of education is to bring about world peace, another dimension of the assessment question is how to measure domains of learning that foster social-emotional growth and skills for &#8216;Learning to Live Together&#8217;. You present a very careful and well-balanced outline of the issues.  I&#8217;d draw your (and your followers&#8217;) attention to this blog by Silvia Montoya of UIS and myself, here: <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/norrag.wordpress.com\\/?s=crouch\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">https:\\/\\/norrag.wordpress.com\\/?s=crouch<\\/a>. There, we propose that there is an implicit, and possibly efficient, division of labor that could emerge out of the various ideas floating around on learning assessment, coming from GAML, the A4L initiative, and the  &#8220;The Learning Generation&#8221; report from the International Commission on Financing Global Education Opportunity. I think that these processes need to be open, transparent, and in some sense a construct of many stakeholders. However, the lacunae that prevails in TE does not assist the  responsibility to do justice to meets its logical ends. Hence the need to transform TE to meet the tasks set for changes in education and development. Thus the need for owning learning (OL) of the teacher becomes sine quo non. What is OL? Simply it is owning what you learn than become slavish to knowledge that that is given to you. IOW avoiding the dangers of the &#8216;banking concept&#8217; of learning forced on the learners from primary to Uni levels in the developing countries highlighted by Paulo Freire. OL is a creative way of learning where you search for answers than look for what is given to you by others.SDG could be achieved through followingOL<\\/p>\\n<p>Dr.S.B.Ekanayaje<br \\/>\\nBasic Education Adviser for UNESCO\\/UNHCR<br \\/>\\nCentral asia<br \\/>\\nCurrently CEO Association for Educational Research and Development Sri Lanka<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/10\\/10\\/target-4c-what-is-at-stake-for-monitoring-progress-on-teachers\\/#comment-12871","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c6d94837139229e62ba0524273469fd0?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c6d94837139229e62ba0524273469fd0?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c6d94837139229e62ba0524273469fd0?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c6d94837139229e62ba0524273469fd0?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12871"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8462"}]}},{"id":12870,"post":8780,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"petermittler","author_url":"http:\\/\\/petermittler.wordpress.com","date":"2016-11-04T15:27:45","date_gmt":"2016-11-04T14:27:45","content":{"rendered":"<p>Given that children with disabilities account for at least a third (and in some countries 80%) of primary age out of school children, is the UN now insisting on Member States providing disability-disaggregated data for the SDGs, in line with  the General Assembly resolution to that effect? Nakitende","author_url":"http:\\/\\/www.umu.ac.ug","date":"2016-10-12T15:58:35","date_gmt":"2016-10-12T13:58:35","content":{"rendered":"<p>\\u2022\\tIn  reference to the article, I think helping donors understand better how scholarships are leading to expected results we should use strategies that  go beyond implementation, monitoring to evaluation. Despite the purpose of the scholarship, monitoring and evaluation forms the basis for modification  and assessing the objectives and quality of activities funded and results achieved.  It is through monitoring that planners, managers, implementer, donors are able to acquire the information and understanding they need to make changes needed or make informed decisions about programs progress.  Evaluation helps with identifying the most valuable and efficient use of resources.  It is through evaluation that manager can develop clear objectives that lead to concrete conclusions regarding the extent to which scholarship or programs\\u2019 success.  Monitoring and evaluation together provide the necessary data to guide strategic planning, to design and implement programs and to allocate, and re-allocate resources in better ways. It is through evaluation that donor can determine what kind of scholarships produce more successful. Much can be learned from monitoring and evaluation that can help donors or managers understand better whether scholarship or programs are leading to expected results.  Evidence on what kinds of strategies are effective in giving scholarships, categories of scholarships provided, groups and number of beneficiaries and results achieved can all be achieved through monitoring and evaluation strategies. This information is essential for resourcing scholarships in poor areas, where difficult decisions need to be made with respect to funding priorities.  Dr. Marie Nakitende<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/10\\/12\\/target-4b-what-is-at-stake-for-monitoring-progress-on-scholarships\\/#comment-12686","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a39ede720acf283753f9fcc3abb37467?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a39ede720acf283753f9fcc3abb37467?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a39ede720acf283753f9fcc3abb37467?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a39ede720acf283753f9fcc3abb37467?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12686"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8506"}]}},{"id":12672,"post":8462,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Dr is the case for Pakistan. There is no standardization and\\/or regulation for intake of teachers as well as training for incumbent teachers. In government schools, teachers are hired with a minimum of Bachelors in Education and a test set by govt. Although this sounds standardized, the quality of this degree and test is highly sub-standard. <\\/p>\\n<p>In low income and high income private schools, there is no specific pre-requisite for hiring teachers; the criterion as well as salary vary according to the socio- econ context in which the school exists and the demand and supply. Many choose teaching profession as a bridge in their career hence both schools and teachers are limited in their investment in in-service trainings.<\\/p>\\n<p>Some private institutions do provide training like Aga Khan University Exam board, Teacher Dev Centre, Teacher Resource Centre, ERDC, however their scope of work is highly reatricted and amongst these inst there is no standardization. <\\/p>\\n<p>Another factor imp while setting indicators for quality training is assessment. It demonstrates the need to drastically increase the support for basic skills upgrading of the labor force in the non-formal farm and non-farm sectors, especially in most sub-Saharan African countries. While around 80% of their labor force is employed (often under-employed) in these sectors, this large shares of the population and economy benefit very little from public education spending, or from education aid. Where is sustained economic growth going to come from if these sectors are not transformed through increased productivity? And, as shown, to improve productivity requires provision of basic skills relevant to peoples daily occupations, provided in a way that facilitate attitude change, especially with respect to women&#8217;s role in the family, the economy and society. This is all part of the type of basic education required to transform traditional economies.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/09\\/28\\/learning-how-to-farm-the-impact-of-farmer-field-schools\\/#comment-12548","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ca264c654d1edb65aef7c45dd3dcbe83?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ca264c654d1edb65aef7c45dd3dcbe83?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ca264c654d1edb65aef7c45dd3dcbe83?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ca264c654d1edb65aef7c45dd3dcbe83?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12548"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8236"}]}},{"id":12538,"post":8236,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"sajwansk","author_url":"http:\\/\\/sksajwan.wordpress.com","date":"2016-09-28T10:39:47","date_gmt":"2016-09-28T08:39:47","content":{"rendered":"<p>Reblogged Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2016-09-26T12:05:29","date_gmt":"2016-09-26T10:05:29","content":{"rendered":"<p>The program in inspirational, and pictures show people with open newspapers.  But how many words per minute do they read?  Somehow the speeds of neoliterate adults are never assessed.  <\\/p>\\n<p>There is research which shows that adults cannot easily become fluent readers.  They are stuck reading letter by letter and run out of patience.  They write notes that they cannot read!  And if they don&#8217;t use the letters for a few days, they forget the sounds. Furthermore, the Arabic script has configural complexities that slow down reading, as many studies have shown.<\\/p>\\n<p>Research is needed to understand better this curious &#8216;adult neoliterate dyslexia&#8217;.  Otherwise money and hopes are wasted.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/09\\/26\\/afghan-police-better-their-lives-and-others-with-literacy\\/#comment-12510","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12510"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8247"}]}},{"id":12509,"post":8247,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"sajwansk","author_url":"http:\\/\\/sksajwan.wordpress.com","date":"2016-09-26T12:02:02","date_gmt":"2016-09-26T10:02:02","content":{"rendered":"<p>Reblogged **********World Education Blog - Page:73**********

b'[{"id":12423,"post":8191,"parent":12415,"author":0,"author_name":"petermittler","author_url":"http:\\/\\/petermittler.wordpress.com","date":"2016-09-16T11:00:56","date_gmt":"2016-09-16T09:00:56","content":{"rendered":"<p>We can&#8217;t abandon the UN commitment to Education for All in favour of Education for Some.<br \\/>\\nThe girls who have been able to go to primary schools since 1990 have enriched  their communities and become leaders and role models. The 2030 Sustainable Development Goals were launched with a commitment to Leave No One Behind; Goal No. 4 is about education.  Some clocks just cannot be turned back, It&#8217;s a matter of fundamental human rights.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/09\\/13\\/why-have-countries-committed-to-development-targets-they-might-never-reach\\/#comment-12423","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8585860d8687bbe2e995b8482bb746d6?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8585860d8687bbe2e995b8482bb746d6?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8585860d8687bbe2e995b8482bb746d6?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8585860d8687bbe2e995b8482bb746d6?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12423"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8191"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12415"}]}},{"id":12420,"post":8211,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Dr Darol Cavanagh","author_url":"","date":"2016-09-16T02:48:01","date_gmt":"2016-09-16T00:48:01","content":{"rendered":"<p>I suspect the writer has incorporated your issues on his three leg scaffold. Within curriculum theory a community centered approach can be the organizing focus for knowledge acquisition . The organization of problems for study are based in community concerns e.g maintaining the first two pillars and extracting from the third. So language 1 and language 2 are incorporated in the design program . By language I refer of course to dual cultures extracting from them worthwhile knowledge from both. Thus female circumcision or mutilation or exclusion from education from the old culture would be replaced by modern reference to women&#8217;s rights from the newer culture.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/09\\/15\\/in-my-tribe-we-go-to-a-different-type-of-school\\/#comment-12420","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5da5cdabff4312a0903e802450363daa?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5da5cdabff4312a0903e802450363daa?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5da5cdabff4312a0903e802450363daa?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5da5cdabff4312a0903e802450363daa?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12420"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8211"}]}},{"id":12416,"post":8211,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Helen Balderama","author_url":"","date":"2016-09-15T15:45:31","date_gmt":"2016-09-15T13:45:31","content":{"rendered":"<p>Reblogged this on <a href=\\"https:\\/\\/helensedufolio.wordpress.com\\/2016\\/09\\/15\\/in-my-tribe-we-go-to-a-different-type-of-school\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow\\"><\\/a> and commented:<br \\/>\\nI\\u2019m called Mundiya Kepanga. I\\u2019m the chief of the Huli tribe in Papua New Guinea. &#8230;If we want for our children to live in a sustainable world, their education must be based upon three big pillars: the respect of cultures and traditional knowledge systems, the main principles that are important for our family, and the lessons that can be learnt from modern education systems. Mundiya attended the launch of the 2016 Global Education Monitoring (REM) Report in London and met Director General of UNESCO, Irina Bokova.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/09\\/15\\/in-my-tribe-we-go-to-a-different-type-of-school\\/#comment-12416","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c349cd0ad9bf1722726072121e93957a?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c349cd0ad9bf1722726072121e93957a?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c349cd0ad9bf1722726072121e93957a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c349cd0ad9bf1722726072121e93957a?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12416"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8211"}]}},{"id":12415,"post":8191,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Stephen Tweed","author_url":"","date":"2016-09-15T15:27:53","date_gmt":"2016-09-15T13:27:53","content":{"rendered":"<p>I think most people in the education community realise that many of the MDG targets were missed, and that even if they were achieved, the outcomes were not as expected; for instance enrolments increased but standards fell dramatically. Millions and probably billions of dollars have been wasted as no-one was monitoring or measuring or setting targets for attainment. From the outset the SDG&#8217;s\\/ GEM Report have indicated that the benchmarks being set are impossible to hit, in the hope that, &#8220;we shoot for the stars and hit the moon.&#8221; We have accepted that the targets are unlikely to be reached before we even start, an own goal in my view, a way out for donors and governments.  The GEM Report discusses the importance of managing education data and measuring improvements, and on-going assessment to improve teaching and learning. Yet donors and governments, and others responsible for delivering SDG&#8217;s4 will not have plausible, achievable targets themselves, to be judged by and be accountable for.<br \\/>\\nThe reality is, that we (so called first world) cannot afford to pay for what is so desperately needed around the world; increase educational standards, improve attainment, investment, create jobs, build economies and raise families out of poverty, thereby providing a more secure world for everyone. It is either not possible or we are not willing to pay. So we need to look at things differently, by asking what can we afford to do?<br \\/>\\nFor me, Universal Primary Education, and &#8220;no-one left behind&#8221; is all very good and idealistic (it is what I wanted as much as anyone), but it does not look like people are prepared to pay for it. What is needed is a more pragmatic approach, one I have never seen discussed but I think it needs to be said. If we cannot afford to educate all, then we need to be able to educate fewer, to a better standard. These then become the engineers, teachers, doctors, entrepreneurs of the future. Imagine 15 years go, had we focused on some rather than all, but on 50% &#8211; and taken them all the way through to secondary education for free, where we might be now? Or 30% through to university? The situation is running out of control, if it isn&#8217;t already. Nothing is changing, in fact it looks like it might be getting worse. We need to change, not keep reproducing the same kinds of reports.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/09\\/13\\/why-have-countries-committed-to-development-targets-they-might-never-reach\\/#comment-12415","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5435d113bb94f2d458b7d7635f8b4541?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5435d113bb94f2d458b7d7635f8b4541?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5435d113bb94f2d458b7d7635f8b4541?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5435d113bb94f2d458b7d7635f8b4541?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12415"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8191"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=12415"}]}},{"id":12414,"post":8211,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Jean Bernard","author_url":"","date":"2016-09-15T15:13:07","date_gmt":"2016-09-15T13:13:07","content":{"rendered":"<p>Thank you for making Mundiya Kapanga&#8217;s wisdom heard around the world. It is important to note  he does not dismiss the knowledge that children will need from modern education systems, but stresses that the other &#8220;two legs of the chair&#8221; are equally important.  Respect for indigenous cultures and traditional knowledge systems are, in fact, essential to the survival of the planet.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/09\\/15\\/in-my-tribe-we-go-to-a-different-type-of-school\\/#comment-12414","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/78638e3d557323df416a8b3a5041e5a8?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/78638e3d557323df416a8b3a5041e5a8?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/78638e3d557323df416a8b3a5041e5a8?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/78638e3d557323df416a8b3a5041e5a8?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12414"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8211"}]}},{"id":12413,"post":8211,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"H. as I welcome this recognition of progress made, children with disabilities have not benefited from Education for All and are now at risk of being forgotten in the SDGs<\\/p>\\n<p>In 2007 UNESCO estimated children with disabilities accounted for a third of all out of school children. Little has been done nothing to monitor this finding in successive EFA GMR reports, despite protests from the disability NGOs.  UNESCO regretted the absence of data while collecting revealing data on gender, poverty and urban-rural differences.<br \\/>\\nOptimism that disability-disaggregated would be included in the monitoring of SDG4 on education was created by a very strong UN General Assembly resolution and also by a commitment from the UIS that such data would be included in future.<br \\/>\\nThe 2016 GEM report is in many ways a great improvement on its predecessors in at least including disability in a section on equity but doesn&#8217;t even mention out of school children: here is the relevant paragraph:<\\/p>\\n<p>&#8220;Determining progress on equal access to education for people with disabilities requires an internationally comparable measure of disability, yet disability takes diverse forms. By one measure, across 30 education systems in Europe, 3.7% of compulsory education pupils were identified as having a special educational need in 2010. UNICEF and the Washington Group on Disability Statistics are leading efforts to develop an operational measure of disability. It is also important to monitor whether educators are well prepared and school infrastructure adapted to address the needs of learners with disabilities\\u201d.<br \\/>\\nI think the millions of  children still out of school deserve better than this and that the international community needs to take it more seriously. Much hope was pinned on the Oslo Summit because UNICEF and other organisations made a submission  on disability-disaggregated data Gordon Brown, the Global Envoy was well briefed.<br \\/>\\nThe UN Human Rights Commission has a complaints procedure for &#8216;grave and systemic discrimination&#8217;  by Member States. Tweed","author_url":"","date":"2016-09-08T13:06:22","date_gmt":"2016-09-08T11:06:22","content":{"rendered":"<p>The way I would manage the improvement in literacy globally is via the Lexile Framework, it measures comprehension and understanding of a piece of graded text, and the learner and the text can be measured on the same scale. I have used it in Africa, in Private Schools, but also mentioned it to various NGO&#8217;s and officials, all of whom have never heard of it but see the benefit of it, and have al been willing to trial it. With the company I used to work for, I wanted to begin Exiling African literature in schools but they lacked the vision to continue, and when I left there was no-one to carry the initiative forward. As a global measure of the improvement in reading ability it is as good as any I have seen, not perfect, but simple to implement.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/09\\/08\\/its-a-little-bit-early-to-celebrate-international-literacy-day\\/#comment-12379","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5435d113bb94f2d458b7d7635f8b4541?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5435d113bb94f2d458b7d7635f8b4541?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5435d113bb94f2d458b7d7635f8b4541?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/5435d113bb94f2d458b7d7635f8b4541?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/12379"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/8024"}]}}]'

Shaeffer","author_url":"","date":"2016-09-06T09:30:40","date_gmt":"2016-09-06T07:30:40","content":{"rendered":"<p>And &#8220;universal early childhood development, care, and preprimary education&#8221; &#8212; Target 4.2?  Why is this constantly neglected in GEM summaries?  The target, of course, is treated in the Executive Summary and the main report, but leaving it out in this blog completely &#8212; when, as usual, primary and secondary education are mentioned &#8212; simply marginalises it This year, we have 26 trainees[both male and female] whom we have sponsored to train on this course and hopefully upon their graduation they will become peer educators of the negative effects of gender based violence. However, our challenge is that of resources so as to reach as many people as possible. Our country is also faced with one of the highest numbers of HIV-AIDS, a situation worsened by gender based violence. Please if there is a donor out there willing to partner with us may we know. In many countries the public education system has failed. Too much corruption being one of the major causes. The question is: can drawing on the private sector improve the quality of (public) education? Maybe. As food for thought: after the recent  garbage strikes in Paris, I learned that private companies collect and process garbage for 12 euros less a ton than the city&#8217;s public garbage system. Interesting isn&#8217;t it? And of course garbage collection is in no way to be compared to education. The question is: can the private sector be more efficient in performing selected public services?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/06\\/23\\/when-is-state-funding-of-private-schools-a-violation-of-human-rights\\/#comment-11864","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ba5c842fcb0279d92ad25776c1a5815d?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ba5c842fcb0279d92ad25776c1a5815d?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ba5c842fcb0279d92ad25776c1a5815d?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/ba5c842fcb0279d92ad25776c1a5815d?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11864"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7785"}]}},{"id":11860,"post":7738,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Anwar","author_url":"","date":"2016-06-23T10:23:20","date_gmt":"2016-06-23T08:23:20","content":{"rendered":"<p>Amazing, outstanding efforts are being done. How can we involve people in the monitoring of inclusion and education for all? The excluded are the ones who know their context best though we have less well developed methodologies for such work. However, work in health education and research and development shows that when stake holders are involved then everybody gains. This is also dealt with in the report Science Education for Responsible Citizenship, that I was involved with. <\\/p>\\n<p>Without education, how do we expect to reduce poverty? Indeed without education equality how do we expect to do this?<\\/p>\\n<p>The organisation I work with aims to tackle this problem head on. The Grace Foundation for Education and Development was set up to invest in the next generation of Nigerians by providing young people with the tools they need to break the poverty cycle in a sustainable way through education. We focus on three key areas: primary to post secondary education, employment &amp; enterprise training and girls&#8217; education, seeking to create a pathway of effective education from young childhood right through to finding employment post secondary.<\\/p>\\n<p>We have some really exciting projects coming up, if anyone would like to find out more visit <a href=\\"http:\\/\\/gracefoundation.global\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">http:\\/\\/gracefoundation.global\\/<\\/a>.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2013\\/09\\/10\\/spotlight-on-nigerias-education-crisis\\/#comment-11720","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/f98dbcf407dc1a886802209fe4121c81?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/f98dbcf407dc1a886802209fe4121c81?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/f98dbcf407dc1a886802209fe4121c81?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/f98dbcf407dc1a886802209fe4121c81?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11720"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/3705"}]}},{"id":11719,"post":5860,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Grace E R Norman","author_url":"http:\\/\\/gracefoundation.global\\/","date":"2016-06-01T16:50:08","date_gmt":"2016-06-01T14:50:08","content":{"rendered":"<p>Interesting read- thanks for posting. Governmental policy is crucial to widespread educational reform but what about the role of non-governmental organisations and charities? Like the other responses above, I agree that credentialing is absolutely essential and that online education cannot and should not replace the social experiences of attending a physical institution, I do wonder how organizations and global policy can balance these needs especially when host country governments may have restrictive policies about what kinds of online education they will recognize officially. For instance, some countries hosting Syrian refugees in the region do not recognize online higher education especially if the online components require students learning more than 50% of the course requirements online. This creates a dissonance between the needs of students and communities, what is available globally, outside an existing system, and what they can finally avail within an existing system given host country Innovation in education is a remedy to most of the crises induced traditional education challenges that have minimized the transformation ability of education in the past. <\\/p>\\n<p>However, the trend has favored mere initiatives than efficient implementations. Countries should therefore find synchronous patterns to bridge brilliant initiatives with effective and efficient implementation modules.<\\/p>\\n<p>&#8220;Today&#8217;s excluded children become tomorrow&#8217;s marginalized youth&#8221; (EFA, UNESCO 2000).<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/05\\/25\\/reaching-all-children-with-education-lebanons-national-education-response-strategy-to-the-syria-crisis\\/#comment-11684","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b6dc0606375586362d837f7aa6956cc2?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b6dc0606375586362d837f7aa6956cc2?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b6dc0606375586362d837f7aa6956cc2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/b6dc0606375586362d837f7aa6956cc2?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11684"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7522"}]}},{"id":11671,"post":7562,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Carol","author_url":"","date":"2016-05-26T17:48:45","date_gmt":"2016-05-26T15:48:45","content":{"rendered":"<p>Facebook used online education as an example of why Internet access for all is a good thing. Sheryl Sandberg shared this example at Davos.<br \\/>\\nThinking about the merits of online\\/virtual education as a whole&#8230;. I&#8217;m convinced that my higher education could not have been transmitted in online format at the same quality.<br \\/>\\nIndeed, I think we shouldn&#8217;t use online as a full replacement to the &#8220;real thing&#8221; and my concern is that countries will rely on online education instead of putting real infrastructure into place for in-person education. This  infrastructure shouldn&#8217;t be neglected in the place of online &#8211; there is much value in having a coffee with your fellow students after a lecture to discuss certain points.<br \\/>\\nIntegration of social technologies and VOIP can of course help bridge the gap between online and &#8220;in person&#8221;.<br \\/>\\n.<br \\/>\\nMake higher education available? Absolutely!<br \\/>\\nIn 100% online format? Only when necessary, such as is the case in many countries today unfortunately &#8211; and yes, if this is a way we can help refugees integrate into our society more smoothly.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/05\\/24\\/virtually-educated-the-case-for-and-conundrum-of-online-higher-education-for-refugees\\/#comment-11671","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8dc459be63624227cd5df3a62bd59bc2?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8dc459be63624227cd5df3a62bd59bc2?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8dc459be63624227cd5df3a62bd59bc2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8dc459be63624227cd5df3a62bd59bc2?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11671"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7562"}]}},{"id":11669,"post":7562,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"SarahDryden-Peterson (@drydenpeterson)","author_url":"http:\\/\\/twitter.com\\/drydenpeterson","date":"2016-05-26T15:32:26","date_gmt":"2016-05-26T13:32:26","content":{"rendered":"<p>Great overview of a critical topic. What are they? who wrote them and on what basis, with which populations were they piloted?  How do the organizers know how much learners will remember in, say, a year and will implement in a class?<br \\/>\\nThen there is a big question about the &#8220;memorability&#8221; of online material.  Various studies show that we remember less from e-books and screens, for reasons that at this moment are unclear.<\\/p>\\n<p>Donors typically leap over these details, assume that they are somehow fulfilled, and go on to the big policy picture.  But without the pixels, the big picture becomes virtual reality.<br \\/>\\nUNESCO can add a great deal of value by focusing on the above trivial details. Donors see the effect and assign funds to other priority sectors. The poor outcomes should not surprise anyone.  Donors are interested in testing and systemic issues, they are not  interested in promoting efficient teaching methods. So, information in many classrooms is simply not delivered in ways that most brains process it.  And perhaps a third of the students in subsaharan Africa fail to learn basic skills.  <\\/p>\\n<p>Illiterate students and dropouts must have significant trauma and a sense of failure. Ironically, it may be easier on them to never enroll in school than to attend and fail.  Until governments and donors use the available science and teach students efficiently, it may be safer for the marginalized to stay out of school.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/04\\/27\\/funding-education-in-sub-saharan-africa-can-the-momentum-be-maintained-during-the-current-economic-slowdown\\/#comment-11401","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11401"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7368"}]}},{"id":11384,"post":6455,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"GreenEyeEnvironment","author_url":"http:\\/\\/gree-vn.com","date":"2016-04-26T11:31:11","date_gmt":"2016-04-26T09:31:11","content":{"rendered":"<p>Interesting and comforting report.<br \\/>\\nAs said global education at school is an important way of making the youth aware of environmental issues and how it can impact their own life. **********World Education Blog - Page:84**********

b'[{"id":11281,"post":7303,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"ah-med sulaimana agbovi","author_url":"","date":"2016-04-05T23:29:34","date_gmt":"2016-04-05T21:29:34","content":{"rendered":"<p>Education is for the purpose of being able to perpetually and positively influence mind of the individual so that he or she could use knowledge, skills and right dispositions to create the future desired. The test of this is not a certificate but the quality of thinking the student desplays after training. This is more urgent in crises situation than   otherwise. So, let us  emphaisize these in educating crises zone child so that they will be better prepared to adapt to non-crises life after the passage of the crises.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/04\\/05\\/last-chance-to-join-the-call-for-the-new-education-crisis-platform-to-be-adequately-and-sustainably-financed\\/#comment-11281","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/0144395779dea3fbb8f2ec345662bc4d?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/0144395779dea3fbb8f2ec345662bc4d?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/0144395779dea3fbb8f2ec345662bc4d?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/0144395779dea3fbb8f2ec345662bc4d?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11281"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7303"}]}},{"id":11270,"post":7283,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Helen Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2016-04-04T14:15:47","date_gmt":"2016-04-04T12:15:47","content":{"rendered":"<p>The phenomenon we witness makes sense only from the perspective of evolutionary psychology.  Males have been set up by evolution to coalesce in tightly knit groups that have hunting or military goals.  Throughout the ages they could thus feed families.  Women are set up to marry the victors and maximize the chance that their children will survive.  Men feel great belonging to tightly knit groups, and doing military operations somehow feels right.  Women feel somehow that that these are the right men to marry.<\\/p>\\n<p>This behavior has been linked to Islam, but this is not the only example.  Consider the Central American gangs.  They operate on the same evolutionary principles but they have no profound rationale other than feeling good and getting money.  And women go along with that.<\\/p>\\n<p>One likely fuel for the events that we see has been the decades-long escalation in TV and videogame violence.  Young males see dozens of murders a day as well as weapons pointed at them.  With the adaptive imitation ability that our brains have, they learn what to do.  Various studies have raised concerns.  But though verbal violence seems to have risen in general as a result of TV violence, actual performance seems to involve only a minority; perhaps those of higher testosterone levels.  So, researchers have been ignored.<\\/p>\\n<p>One way to reduce the complex military attacks would be to reduce violence exposure. Given its links to evolutionary dictates, there should be international conventions to ban such content.  But we know that this will not happen.  So, what we see nowadays may only be the beginning, as cohort after cohort learns the craft of violence from cradle.<\\/p>\\n<p>One phenomenon that has been hard to understand has been the suicidal bombers. But Moslems are not the only ones.  In recent history there had been Japanese kamikazi and Tamil bombers. This practice reveals a tendency for young men to sacrifice themselves so that their relatives&#8217; DNA will live on. Similarly, social insects sacrifice themselves so that their hive will live.  Somehow the Islamic practices used make this trait reliably emerge in many young males.  <\\/p>\\n<p>So, in the 21st century we look for rational explanations, and we see that our genetic behavior tendencies are running circles around us.  Much thought is needed on how to neutralize destructive genetic tendencies. It&#8217;s useful to understand the dictates of evolutionary psychology and take measures.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/04\\/04\\/learning-from-former-extremists\\/#comment-11270","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11270"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7283"}]}},{"id":11248,"post":7124,"parent":11105,"author":0,"author_name":"Daw it&#8217;s a good start, I wonder how well the indicators will be able to measure global citizenship education (GCE) or education for sustainable development (ESD) in schooling. For example, we know in England that GCE and ESD is not currently mainstreamed through education policy and the national curriculum, but comes more from the drive of teachers and senior leaders in schools, and the support they get from NGOs, development education practitioners and national programmes such as GLP and Connecting Classrooms. Much of this work takes place in the informal rather than formal curricula. Schools in England are doing some of the most innovative work in this field in the world and yet the monitoring mechanisms suggested wouldn&#8217;t necessarily pick up on this. On the other hand, there are countries with strong evidence of GCE \\/ ESD in policy and curricula, but with less evidence of good, practical engagement at the school level. I wonder if there needs to be an additional indicator that can link more to practice \\/ access to information or resources \\/ civil society support?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/03\\/02\\/good-news-gender-equality-has-made-its-way-into-the-global-education-indicators\\/#comment-11188","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e46c516b8cbd5dd5c4a841074111b03d?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e46c516b8cbd5dd5c4a841074111b03d?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e46c516b8cbd5dd5c4a841074111b03d?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e46c516b8cbd5dd5c4a841074111b03d?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11188"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7035"}]}},{"id":11169,"post":7172,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"DHA Prism","author_url":"http:\\/\\/bakhxirealestate.com","date":"2016-03-12T17:37:41","date_gmt":"2016-03-12T16:37:41","content":{"rendered":"<p>world education blog is one of my favorite blog.
