And if homework in Nigeria includes writing papers, the girl is probably attending a private school.  To write an essay, there is no need for Word.  Handwriting in fact may create a better memory trace according to some studies.<\\/p>\\n<p>Computerized learning seems like a no brainer, so it is surprising that it does NOT work as expected.  Several studies of ICT have shown disappointing results.  And countries like Rwanda have wasted a lot of money in buying computers that became expensive doorstops.<\\/p>\\n<p>One powerful reason for failure is a scarcity of software for teaching really basic skills. Prof. Negroponte had hypothesized that students would program the computers themselves!  And  what software exists basically gives a few exercises adapted from textbooks.  It typically does not get tested for effectiveness with low-income people.  So, much time can be wasted before anyone realizes that students did not learn what was expected.  One XO laptop trial in Nepal left children with much less English knowledge than if they had gone to traditional classrooms.<\\/p>\\n<p>In education, the counterintuitive usually proves to be correct.  If something is considered a &#8220;no brainer&#8221;, then it&#8217;s the wrong thing to do.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/03\\/07\\/can-mobile-learning-bridge-the-digital-divide-and-learning-gap\\/#comment-11079","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11079"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7172"}]}},{"id":11075,"post":7035,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Ed Burke","author_url":"","date":"2016-03-06T23:24:01","date_gmt":"2016-03-06T22:24:01","content":{"rendered":"<p>I agree fully with Jennae Bulat&#8217;s who wrote &#8220;&#8230; gender equality within the global education indicators will, indeed, be yet another important step in promoting full access for all to quality learning opportunities&#8221; but actually changing traditional and cultural community attitudes towards females is the root  problem. So governments always have sound evidence for committing to huge investments?<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/03\\/04\\/kenyas-primary-schools-or-those-with-electricity-to-get-laptops-any-time-now\\/#comment-11066","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/22ea6d45ba1b5e54e24b74e1c8e431ff?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/22ea6d45ba1b5e54e24b74e1c8e431ff?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/22ea6d45ba1b5e54e24b74e1c8e431ff?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/22ea6d45ba1b5e54e24b74e1c8e431ff?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11066"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7064"}]}},{"id":11065,"post":7064,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Helen Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2016-03-04T10:25:11","date_gmt":"2016-03-04T09:25:11","content":{"rendered":"<p>What software will be loaded into the laptops?  In particular, how have the basic reading and math tasks been developed?  Who and where piloted them with the poorest children?  How have executive function issues been dealt with (i.e. to minimize the likelihood of abandoning the tasks)?<br \\/>\\nSuch inconvenient questions lie behind the very disappointing outcomes of computer use in schools worldwide.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/03\\/04\\/kenyas-primary-schools-or-those-with-electricity-to-get-laptops-any-time-now\\/#comment-11065","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11065"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7064"}]}}]'

Central to such access is the recognition that teaching and learning materials can play a central role in either reinforcing or helping to break harmful stereotypes. The USAID Guide for Strengthening Gender Equality and Inclusiveness in Teaching and Learning Materials (<a href=\\"https:\\/\\/www.eddataglobal.org\\/documents\\/index.cfm?fuseaction=pubDetail&#038;id=840\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">https:\\/\\/www.eddataglobal.org\\/documents\\/index.cfm?fuseaction=pubDetail&#038;id=840<\\/a>) promises to be a useful, and user-friendly, tool for evaluating and developing curricular materials that are free of bias and that promote equality and inclusiveness of all marginalized, disadvantaged, and underrepresented groups.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/03\\/02\\/good-news-gender-equality-has-made-its-way-into-the-global-education-indicators\\/#comment-11064","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/74bce00796a296b89b13c64795c1f8b7?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/74bce00796a296b89b13c64795c1f8b7?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/74bce00796a296b89b13c64795c1f8b7?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/74bce00796a296b89b13c64795c1f8b7?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11064"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/7035"}]}},{"id":11047,"post":5911,"parent":8168,"author":0,"author_name":"Soledad","author_url":"","date":"2016-02-29T18:18:44","date_gmt":"2016-02-29T17:18:44","content":{"rendered":"<p>Hello,<\\/p>\\n<p>I agree with you. UNESCO should make sure they facilitate education system to have teachers who are proficient in teaching the mother tongue by motivating teacher training institutions to train teacher who are competent in mother tongue. this is because today very few people especially in the colonized countries can competently read, write and use mother tongue grammar as it should be. most countries insist teaching English or French  even where the language policy is mother tongue in the early  years of school(class1-3).<br \\/>\\nCountries where english is a second languages exams are poorly pefomed a case of kenya r<\\/p>\\n<p> I would propose mother tongue is taught all the way to university to preserve peoples identity. they should also learn other languages alongside mother tongue because we are in a global community not seclusion. bilingualism is the way to go from the early years. Harris","author_url":"http:\\/\\/rayharris57.wordpress.com","date":"2016-02-23T12:56:21","date_gmt":"2016-02-23T11:56:21","content":{"rendered":"<p>Reblogged this on <a Development<\\/a>.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/02\\/23\\/language-and-learning-photo-blog-classroom-challenges\\/#comment-11010","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11010"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6847"}]}},{"id":11007,"post":6700,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Gr\\u00e9gory H\\u00e4uptli","author_url":"http:\\/\\/www.pestalozzi.ch\\/en\\/home\\/","date":"2016-02-22T17:55:54","date_gmt":"2016-02-22T16:55:54","content":{"rendered":"<p>Please let us share some other evidence of the benefit of Mother-Tongue based Multilingual Education (MTB-MLE). Supported by the Pestalozzi Children\\u2019s Foundation (PCF) is a world-wide operating Non-profit organisation, headquartered in Switzerland, The Foundation for Applied Linguistics (FAL), devel-oped a project that focus on Mother-Tongue based Multilingual Education (MTB-MLE). It was developed based on a MTB-MLE model for solving literacy problem in Thai language for ethnolinguistic minority children established by the Thai Office of the Basic Education Commission (OBEC) and the Ministry of Education. <\\/p>\\n<p>Throughout the last 9 years, the project has implemented the Multilingual Education with its emphasis on Thai and mother languages in 6 pilot schools across 3 ethno linguistic minority communities. It focuses on helping students to learn the national language better and thus achieve national learning standards in every subject. As a result, school based curriculum in each language group from pre-school to grade 3 level of primary school are being developed. Students\\u2019 have completed primary schooling in ethnic and national languages, achieved their academic potential and become self-confident members of their multi-cultural society.<\\/p>\\n<p>Thank you for your attention<\\/p>\\n<p>Gr\\u00e9gory H\\u00e4uptli, Specialist PCF International Programme; Rahel K\\u00f6lbener Intern PCF International Programme<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/02\\/19\\/language-in-school-if-you-dont-understand-how-can-you-learn\\/#comment-11007","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/25efe199c4c9926087e32224b956f679?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/25efe199c4c9926087e32224b956f679?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/25efe199c4c9926087e32224b956f679?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/25efe199c4c9926087e32224b956f679?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11007"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6700"}]}},{"id":11006,"post":6914,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Helen Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2016-02-22T17:31:23","date_gmt":"2016-02-22T16:31:23","content":{"rendered":"<p>The travails of the South Africans have been unprecedented, but the focus on language is a bit misunderstood. Everywhere language is linked to status, and the blacks wanted higher status and respect.<br \\/>\\n Africaans strangely is a language native to the blacks.  It arose from Dutch in the 1600-1700 through intermarriages with natives and other immigrants.  For many, particularly the &#8216;Cape colored,&#8217; it has been the home language.  In the rebellion, the blacks demanded use of English, which was linked to the higher-status British who also did not like apartheid.  They did not demand Zulu, Xhosa, etc.<br \\/>\\nIronically, the south Africans got a mixed bag with English.  It is an outlier orthography whose spelling system takes 3 years to learn and brings out dyslexia in the brains of susceptible people.  It also needs many teaching resources and training.  By contrast Africaans (and all the African languages) are spelled consistently, so basic reading can be learned in 4 months or so.<br \\/>\\nThe best way for South Africans to learn English is to become fluent readers in one of the African languages (including Africaans, which dropped most of the earlier Dutch irregularities.)   The government has made this point and teaches in 11 languages.  But many people want the mark of status early on.  This is one reason why South Africa is doing much worse in basic skills than expected.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/02\\/22\\/south-africa-proof-that-language-in-school-can-be-a-source-of-grievance-if-not-done-right\\/#comment-11006","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/11006"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6914"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=11006"}]}}]'

pays attention to this serious subject<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/02\\/19\\/language-in-school-if-you-dont-understand-how-can-you-learn\\/#comment-10992","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8bb171cc6db716da6d714e26fe6c5de7?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8bb171cc6db716da6d714e26fe6c5de7?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8bb171cc6db716da6d714e26fe6c5de7?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8bb171cc6db716da6d714e26fe6c5de7?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10992"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6700"}]}},{"id":10984,"post":6700,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Helen Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2016-02-19T15:00:28","date_gmt":"2016-02-19T14:00:28","content":{"rendered":"<p>Obviously students learn content in a language they know well.  But the donor agencies confuse multiple variables and unfortunately give poor advice about &#8216;mother tongue&#8217; instruction.  <\\/p>\\n<p>Language issues must be disentangled from orthography.  The trouble with English, French, Portuguese is orthographic complexity.  It takes 3 years to teach English spelling and 100 days to teach in transparent orthographies.  And complex orthographies may bring out dyslexia in the brains of susceptible people. <\\/p>\\n<p> Students at risk must learn reading in a transparent orthography.  This advantage trumps language, as several neurocognitive studies have shown (see one by Perfetti, just a few days old at SSSR(.<\\/p>\\n<p>Low-income children in Liberia, for example, may speak liberian English best.  But it is probably more efficient to teach them reading in a local language like Kpele that they may not know.  Then transfer to English past automaticity, which the English orthography can be taught most efficiently.<\\/p>\\n<p>Also, are speakers of other languages permanently at a disadvantage?  We tend to make this decision from our own adult perspectives. The blanket advice to teach in &#8216;mother&#8217; tongues ignores the facility with which children up to age 8 or so acquire more than one.  Many Africans are multilingual.  So, is it worth making an all-out effort to teach in the 36 or so languages of Uganda?  Or is it ok to teach in 4 regional ones?  (all are transparently spelled).  <\\/p>\\n<p>This question begs for research-based answers.  The donors have never commissioned (to the best of my knowledge) any studies on how children&#8217;s  language knowledge evolves, when they learn it from environmental interactions.  How many words do they learn per month,how fast do they comprehend?   Without such data, we should not be advising governments.<\\/p>\\n<p>This blog should furthermore be advocating for targeted research to answer these questions.  There is neurocognitive methodology and equipment that is able to give answers, and it&#8217;s high time it got put to use.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/02\\/19\\/language-in-school-if-you-dont-understand-how-can-you-learn\\/#comment-10984","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10984"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6700"}]}},{"id":10983,"post":6874,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Muqadas programs<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/02\\/18\\/the-pal-network-learning-journey-beyond-assessment-to-action\\/#comment-10983","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/4065072562601b92c54e1c9846cc057e?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/4065072562601b92c54e1c9846cc057e?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/4065072562601b92c54e1c9846cc057e?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/4065072562601b92c54e1c9846cc057e?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10983"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6874"}]}},{"id":10977,"post":3919,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Abuumundhir","author_url":"","date":"2016-02-17T15:55:46","date_gmt":"2016-02-17T14:55:46","content":{"rendered":"<p>Education is a necessary but not sufficient factor to eradication of poverty. For me, poverty is deeply rooted in people&#8217;s culture. What we need is a systemic change in people&#8217;s attitude to work and change of behaviour. In most of the African countries, corruption is deeply rooted in the culture and education has not managed to reduce it. Among the most corrupt are those who have seen more blackboards, whiteboards and flipcharts.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2013\\/10\\/17\\/we-will-never-eradicate-poverty-without-quality-education-for-all\\/#comment-10977","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/9f274f48375a5448ed289e6d06c0f7d6?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/9f274f48375a5448ed289e6d06c0f7d6?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/9f274f48375a5448ed289e6d06c0f7d6?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/9f274f48375a5448ed289e6d06c0f7d6?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10977"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/3919"}]}},{"id":10974,"post":6765,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Carlos","author_url":"","date":"2016-02-17T04:16:27","date_gmt":"2016-02-17T03:16:27","content":{"rendered":"<p>If someone can help  with ideas    to improve  education  and  fight  corruption, how to contact  the  top people?  Now  almost nobody  has  email,   only  twitter  and facebook<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/02\\/11\\/big-hopes-for-education-and-yet-more-big-targets-at-the-world-humanitarian-summit\\/#comment-10974","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/1fb28dfa65c18949636d3c1914d8ba62?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/1fb28dfa65c18949636d3c1914d8ba62?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/1fb28dfa65c18949636d3c1914d8ba62?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/1fb28dfa65c18949636d3c1914d8ba62?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10974"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6765"}]}},{"id":10971,"post":6722,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"vastav","author_url":"","date":"2016-02-16T21:42:33","date_gmt":"2016-02-16T20:42:33","content":{"rendered":"<p>hi little children friends<br \\/>\\nthanks<br \\/>\\nregards<br \\/>\\nvastav<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/02\\/08\\/books-for-every-child-the-global-book-fund\\/#comment-10971","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c7563e80b2d168e4de20d8e216369a2e?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c7563e80b2d168e4de20d8e216369a2e?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c7563e80b2d168e4de20d8e216369a2e?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c7563e80b2d168e4de20d8e216369a2e?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10971"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6722"}]}},{"id":10936,"post":6782,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"vatsav","author_url":"","date":"2016-02-14T19:24:34","date_gmt":"2016-02-14T18:24:34","content":{"rendered":"<p>hi<br \\/>\\nif education is outsourcing then we will  be similar to  apes<br \\/>\\ncheck out some facts about education   <a href=\\"http:\\/\\/allusauniversity.blogspot.in\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow\\">here<\\/a><\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/02\\/12\\/what-happens-if-an-education-system-is-outsourced\\/#comment-10936","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c7563e80b2d168e4de20d8e216369a2e?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c7563e80b2d168e4de20d8e216369a2e?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c7563e80b2d168e4de20d8e216369a2e?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/c7563e80b2d168e4de20d8e216369a2e?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10936"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6782"}]}},{"id":10917,"post":6782,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Helen Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2016-02-12T17:02:19","date_gmt":"2016-02-12T16:02:19","content":{"rendered":"<p>In about 7 years it will be called a mistake, but by then the profits will have been earned and invested, the staff involved will have been promoted or retired.  So, no one will be held accountable.<\\/p>\\n<p>A &#8220;lessons learned&#8221; evaluation will be written as a retrospective.  Statistically significant differences will be cited, at the 0.05 or 0.01 level.  These will be meaningless in practical terms, but the project will be deemed a qualified success. <\\/p>\\n<p>The issue is not privatization or costs.  It&#8217;s assumptions about how people process information:   working memory and cognitive load of teachers and students.  And the curriculum is standard English, a language of complex orthography and significant distance from the patois used in Liberia.<\\/p>\\n<p>Judging from testing elsewhere, the unqualified teachers probably read around 90 wpm (e.g. grade 3 in the US) and understand perhaps half of what they read.  They are supposed to hold in working memory the content of the scripted lessons and interact with students at the same time. For widespread effects, they should interact with ALL students, not just with the best few.  All these choices are excessive, given brain limitations.  <\\/p>\\n<p>Attention to the controversial issues may make onerous reading\\/langaguage\\/math issues appear details.  So the students may not get material that is more easily learnable.<\\/p>\\n<p>What to do instead (with or without Bridges?)  Lots.  For starters, real experimentation with teachers&#8217; cognitive load and probability of production in class of what we want them to do.  For the students, very detailed phonics-based reading in English and use of transparent orthographies to the extent possible. Tons of practice on mental math, etc.  All this could indeed be written up in scripted lessons.  But determining the dosage needs a good dose of cognitive science.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/02\\/12\\/what-happens-if-an-education-system-is-outsourced\\/#comment-10917","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10917"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6782"}]}},{"id":10885,"post":4331,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"ccruz2016","author_url":"","date":"2016-02-09T10:06:38","date_gmt":"2016-02-09T09:06:38","content":{"rendered":"<p>Reblogged this on <a href=\\"http:\\/\\/girls-matter.org\\/photo-blog-the-state-of-girls-education-around-the-world\\/\\" rel=\\"nofollow\\">Girls Matter &#8211; Learning for the development of girls and women<\\/a>.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2014\\/03\\/14\\/photo-story-gender-summary-of-the-20134-efa-report\\/#comment-10885","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e3a059b267a740e5e87c08d3a0ff8600?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e3a059b267a740e5e87c08d3a0ff8600?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e3a059b267a740e5e87c08d3a0ff8600?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/e3a059b267a740e5e87c08d3a0ff8600?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10885"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/4331"}]}}]'

**********World Education Blog - Page:88**********

b'[{"id":10880,"post":6315,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Daniel Tau","author_url":"http:\\/\\/www.bocodol.ac.bw","date":"2016-02-08T14:30:33","date_gmt":"2016-02-08T13:30:33","content":{"rendered":"<p>I cant agree more with the findings mentioned supra. However we need to deploy a mode of education delivery that enables us to access all and sundry. We still have millions of people who remain unreached with education because of the elitist mode of education that the world has chosen to largely use. With the use of Open and Distance Learning many more people would be accessed and enabled to benefit from education. They would also become part of the noble course to a more tolerant, creative, civilised and self-sustaining society<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2015\\/11\\/16\\/education-is-indispensable-in-strengthening-the-bonds-that-hold-communities-and-societies-together\\/#comment-10880","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/01137e69e7417a73b8ad0b086b393a32?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/01137e69e7417a73b8ad0b086b393a32?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/01137e69e7417a73b8ad0b086b393a32?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/01137e69e7417a73b8ad0b086b393a32?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10880"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6315"}]}},{"id":10879,"post":6722,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Helen Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2016-02-08T12:52:25","date_gmt":"2016-02-08T11:52:25","content":{"rendered":"<p>The book initiative is very good, but supplementary books are useful only for those who already know how at least how to decode.  Why?<\\/p>\\n<p>Imagine that you live at the end of a long, winding footpath. It leads to a paved road 1 km away. From there you can catch a bus to go to stores that sell anything you want.  But you must somehow learn to find your way to the road, step by step.  And you must walk at a reasonable speed, before night falls. <\\/p>\\n<p>Imagine that a wealthy donor hears of your need to get to the stores and sends you a nice car.  The car cannot get to your house.  The footpath is too narrow!  A donor may spend a billion $$ to send cars to take all rural residents to big cities. But those living along footpaths must still walk to a road wide enough for the cars to cross.  The richer ones may get to the cars faster by horse, but the road is still the same.  If the donor evaluates the utility of the cars without thinking of the footpath to be traversed, the results will be zero.<\\/p>\\n<p>Our neuronal circuits work that way.  Few connections can be made at a time, so for beginning readers the pathways are narrow.  They must decode letter by letter and get much practice in order to decode faster.  As they do, the visual word form area gets activated, that recognizes words as if they were faces. Then reading becomes effortless, automatic. This brain area enables fast transport to the stores of knowledge.  That&#8217;s when the various types of supplemental books are useful.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/02\\/08\\/books-for-every-child-the-global-book-fund\\/#comment-10879","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/60ae1d5f6a1c8573397d974d958b0a03?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10879"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6722"}]}},{"id":10859,"post":6680,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"mfrancopt","author_url":"http:\\/\\/mfrancopt.wordpress.com","date":"2016-02-03T10:09:06","date_gmt":"2016-02-03T09:09:06","content":{"rendered":"<p>Reblogged access to free education to their citizens. The debates have been going on for the last three decades in parliaments and constitutional reviews, with very little change. This is a shame! while the argument has been lack of resources, we see broad day light the primitive stealing of public resources by African leaders and their collaborators. They impoverish their citizens and incapacitate them to the point of perpetual slavery. This state of  dehumanisation, has made it impossible for parents access education for their children. But if we to answer the Question honestly, Africa can provide at least Basic Education to its citizens free. <\\/p>\\n<p>What is required first and foremost is  for the People is get organised and demand from the leaders at all levels, accountability on the use public resources. Foreign countries should begin the process of exposing those &#8216; Leader thieves&#8217; and help repatriate such  resources for the provision of education to our children and the development of Africa!!<\\/p>\\n<p>Our leaders  should know that indeed, time will catch up with those who believe that drink and wine  at the expense of the children of great Africa.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/01\\/27\\/can-africa-afford-free-education\\/#comment-10805","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8548e4deb6a359950132d60599a096f9?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8548e4deb6a359950132d60599a096f9?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8548e4deb6a359950132d60599a096f9?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/8548e4deb6a359950132d60599a096f9?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10805"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6557"}]}},{"id":10794,"post":6557,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"jimmyoluoch","author_url":"http:\\/\\/jimmyoluoch.wordpress.com","date":"2016-01-27T14:17:54","date_gmt":"2016-01-27T13:17:54","content":{"rendered":"<p>Good question. Redman","author_url":"","date":"2016-01-21T10:28:57","date_gmt":"2016-01-21T09:28:57","content":{"rendered":"<p>Yes textbooks need to be up to date, innovative (in terms of pedagogy and learning approaches) and sensitive to the diverse language needs of the students who will be using them. We obviously have no qualms with any of this. Harris","author_url":"http:\\/\\/gravatar.com\\/rayharris57","date":"2016-01-20T11:25:45","date_gmt":"2016-01-20T10:25:45","content":{"rendered":"<p>Agree totally with you -before just asking for more textbooks -start looking at the needs of students, the relevance of the textbook, appropriateness given cultural, geographic and education contexts in which they are to be used etc<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/01\\/19\\/how-we-could-triple-the-availability-of-textbooks\\/#comment-10732","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10732"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6526"}],"in-reply-to":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10731"}]}},{"id":10731,"post":6526,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"John Clegg","author_url":"","date":"2016-01-20T10:34:53","date_gmt":"2016-01-20T09:34:53","content":{"rendered":"<p>The supply of textbooks is clearly very important. However, a first order issue is whether the textbooks can be read by learners and therefor used in the classroom. In countries in which learners learn in a second language (L2), and have low ability in that language, textbooks are often unreadable and thus unused. The textbooks are normally written as if they were intended for native speakers of the language; learners have nothing like the L2 reading ability they need to understand them and teachers therefore do not use the books. This is the case for example in Rwanda where research by the British Council shows books in primary schools, while supplied to schools, remaining unused. Research in Rwanda by the University of Bristol shows that textbooks used in grade 4 &#8211; the first year of English-medium schooling &#8211; are designed for native speakers and have a readability score, amongst native speaker readers, of well above grade four. Low-L2 ability readers cannot therefore read them. Research in Tanzania shows similar results. Experience generally in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) shows that textbooks are published as if designed for native speakers and demonstrate none of the characteristics which they should show if designed for L2 users. In addition, in SSA learner reading ability in L2 is widely shown to be low: Uwezo evidence for 2013 shows that in Uganda for example, fewer than 4 in 10 children aged 10-16 years display literacy skills at a Grade 2 level. Other evidence in SSA shows that reading events in the classroom are in general rare: learners are thus not being asked to read. A combination of few opportunities to read, low reading ability in L2 and textbooks which are unreadable is a significant matter which will result in books remaining unused. It is important to improve textbook supply (as is notably the case in Rwanda), but improvements in this respect are wasted if learners (and often teachers) cannot read the textbooks and if, as a consequence, they are not used. It is notable that both governments and NGOs tend to be unaware of this crucial issue &#8211; it is not, for example, mentioned in this paper. A great deal of money spent on textbooks is being wholly wasted on textbooks which may be efficiently supplied but unusable. In L2-medium education, for example in SSA, much more attention needs to be paid by education authorities and NGOs to the design of textbooks to make them usable by both teachers and learners.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/01\\/19\\/how-we-could-triple-the-availability-of-textbooks\\/#comment-10731","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/14b07778ff73d8729d8720e1d80a7114?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10731"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6526"}],"children":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments?parent=10731"}]}},{"id":10721,"post":6526,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Hj Khairiltitov Zainuddin","author_url":"http:\\/\\/mytitovblog.wordpress.com","date":"2016-01-19T12:59:07","date_gmt":"2016-01-19T11:59:07","content":{"rendered":"<p>Textbook in Malaysia is provided free to all school pupils. Beginning 2008, under the Textbook Loan Scheme, all pupils will get a textbook for all subjects they study for free (loan). (<a href=\\"http:\\/\\/www.ibe.unesco.org\\/National_Reports\\/ICE_2008\\/malaysia_NR08.pdf\\" rel=\\"nofollow ugc\\">http:\\/\\/www.ibe.unesco.org\\/National_Reports\\/ICE_2008\\/malaysia_NR08.pdf<\\/a>)<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/01\\/19\\/how-we-could-triple-the-availability-of-textbooks\\/#comment-10721","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/455bf2f831e8c3f7073e24241b843d10?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/455bf2f831e8c3f7073e24241b843d10?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/455bf2f831e8c3f7073e24241b843d10?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/455bf2f831e8c3f7073e24241b843d10?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10721"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6526"}]}},{"id":10719,"post":6526,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Ray Harris","author_url":"http:\\/\\/gravatar.com\\/rayharris57","date":"2016-01-19T11:33:35","date_gmt":"2016-01-19T10:33:35","content":{"rendered":"<p>Although I would not criticise the notion that schools need more textbooks -lets ensure that these textbooks not only are up to date but reflect more innovative learning approaches. Secondly perhaps we can compliment this with a more &#8216;home grown&#8217; and contextualised approach by providing materials for teachers\\/parents\\/students to make their own books. These can easily be used to extend the use of local languages, where appropriate.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2016\\/01\\/19\\/how-we-could-triple-the-availability-of-textbooks\\/#comment-10719","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/be826caada6463738040d9068e6f563d?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/10719"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6526"}]}},{"id":10682,"post":6495,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"Helen Abadzi","author_url":"","date":"2016-01-15T08:20:17","date_gmt":"2016-01-15T07:20:17","content":{"rendered":"<p>None of this is doable without using the science of how people learn, particularly at the low end.  Unfortunately thousands of generalists and &#8220;eminent persons&#8221; were asked about goals, but no cognitive neuroscientists were included. So the targets are fuzzy and doable only from a middle-class perspective.<br \\/>\\nAnyway, the UN has until 2030 to figure this out. By then someone may think of asking I do like and appreciate the idea of GEM. Most importantly, there is huge need for global level awareness amongst high level politicians like PMs and presidents, UN agencies&#8217; heads, development donors as well as social movement leaders about how to deliver quality basic education to all as their basic needs. How to establish education as equalizer rather than divider of society? How to stop commodification of education from local to global level &#8211; need for monitoring progress on these backbone issues. I expect this independent expert team not just to play around statistics and produce another global report, which does not show any direction. Democratization of education is very crucial, addressing inequalities through education is possible and imperative. It is high time to build robust public education campaigns in every country in the mode of social justice movements, only then can we connect it with SDGs. Countries to put in place action plans,fast track effective implementation,put key performance indicators(KPI) in place to measure progress at every stage,and to know if you are really on track.<br \\/>\\nIn Nigeria we need to sustain political commitment on the part of successive Government to honour all legally binding agreement signed between the International Development Partners and the host Government so as  to ensure continuity<br \\/>\\n Secondly, the aspect of quality assurance  need to be strengthened to ensure a package delivery that meets up with internationally accepted best practices\\/standard, to ensure money for value audit.<br \\/>\\nThirdly,we must  think outside the box to look for alternative ways of funding to augment Government budgetary provisions<br \\/>\\n They are expected to bring money into families. Ekanayake","author_url":"http:\\/\\/sbekanayake.blog","date":"2015-11-06T10:22:44","date_gmt":"2015-11-06T09:22:44","content":{"rendered":"<p>Let me commence by quoting Marie &#8216; It is time to find better ways to reform education and equip young people with employable skills and abilities&#8217; . This is really the need of the day. We educate but for what? For how long is yet another question. On the other hand, however much we educate the child keeping them in school for almost 13 years what do most of them get or benefit if they have to get back to the field and mange life in the traditional way. Hence why Marie desires  reforms or what we could call &#8211; &#8216;refolutionery&#8217; changes and reforms.  Some of the changes suggested are as follows<\\/p>\\n<p>The duration of the school universally is determined by someone for a specific period 12\\/13 years and primary to 5 years or so.Why not develop a curriculum and TT for a shorter period of duration which could be 4 years of primary and 5 year of secondary saving 3 to 4 years of wasting the time of the majority of children in the developing countries. Parents require them at the field sooner for them to be helpers,. A condensed curriculum would be equally strong to the task if the correct methodologies are followed. If more practical approaches are adopted to teach, which the children would be very happy (following  Paulo Freire&#8217;s pedagogical principles) This approach will save time, funds and be more realistic avoiding frustrations. Obviously we waste more money and time to bring about a few to succeed at the end of the day. No doubt the humanity needs the services of the brilliant but one should sacrifice the greater majority. Hence new strategies have to be identified. <\\/p>\\n<p>UNESCO has been promoting NFE and LLE as an option to teaching and learning and has spent time and funds to highlight the value of these options all over the world. These are highlighted in this volume as well. Hope the member countries would use these approaches to bring about quality learning, practically useful and avoiding frustrations amongst millions of children leading to achieve EFA goals with in the stipulated period.<br \\/>\\nS.B. Ekanayake Monitoring is important and necessary for achieving quality assurance, but I think monitoring alone or by itself, is not enough for promoting education quality and future sustainable development.  If we want to ensure quality education that leads to sustainable development and life success for next future generation, we need to do more than one thing and each of us, whether you are a teacher or a parent, a leader or policy maker, a students or guardian, must be  all get involved and committed to education reform. <\\/p>\\n<p>The key is to  sustainable development is to ensure that from the time the child begins learning (formal or informal) training to the time one graduates or  drops out of school..they have acquired a certain level of hard and soft skills for survival.   So, in stead of  designing school curriculum, programs, or courses focusing on reading, writing, mathematics or accounting, training at all levels of education must engage and relate to changes in the world or life experiences to make it meaningful for students.  Traditionally, schools used to be seen as non-profit organizations because of their nature and interest in educating,  empowering and equipping people with knowledge and skills. <\\/p>\\n<p>However, as the world changes, the focus is much more put on making money rather than quality of service and student learning outcomes.  Increasing enrollment and getting more money is not bad,  but  the challenge of unemployment facing many  young people graduating from colleges is worsening.  out of 5 graduates 3 are jobless or underemployed.  We cannot solve this problem by using the same curriculum, instructions or culture used 20 years ago.   It is time to find better ways to reform education and equip young people with employable skills and abilities. <\\/p>\\n<p>  In order, to secure and promote education quality,  change is necessary. we need to monitor and evaluate  education systems and learning environment and processes.   Doing so, will not only promote education quality ,  but it will also help in increasing young people&#8217;s opportunities  lifelong  learning, social and economic sustainable development.<br \\/>\\nSr. Marie Nakitende  Ph.D.<\\/p>\\n"},"link":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/2015\\/11\\/04\\/education-2030-framework-for-action-lets-get-started\\/#comment-9892","status":"approved","type":"comment","author_avatar_urls":{"24":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a39ede720acf283753f9fcc3abb37467?s=24&d=mm&r=g","48":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a39ede720acf283753f9fcc3abb37467?s=48&d=mm&r=g","96":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a39ede720acf283753f9fcc3abb37467?s=96&d=mm&r=g","128":"https:\\/\\/secure.gravatar.com\\/avatar\\/a39ede720acf283753f9fcc3abb37467?s=128&d=mm&r=g"},"meta":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments\\/9892"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/comments"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"post_type":"post","href":"https:\\/\\/world-education-blog.org\\/wp-json\\/wp\\/v2\\/posts\\/6294"}]}},{"id":9884,"post":6294,"parent":0,"author":0,"author_name":"S.B.
